title: Teach your kids about giving
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Teach your kids about giving

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 326
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you are committed to teaching your kids how the world operates, and you should be, teach them about money.You can use financial principles to teach everything from math problems to social issues. That's because money is about values, relationships, choices and self-worth.And while teaching your kids important values to guide their lives is of the utmost importance, when all is said and done those values are more likely to be caught than taught.You have to live what you teach.If there is one thing that will ruin your kids' lives, it's greed. Teach them while they're young how to pull the drain plug on greed, and you will have prepared them in a very important way to not only survive, but to also thrive in the real world.The antidote for greed is giving away part of the three T's - your time, your talent and your treasure. Everyone, no matter how young or poor, possesses all three.Time: You get 24 hours every day, 10,080 minutes or 604,800 seconds every week.Talent: This is what you can do. Everyone has special talents, things they are good at doing.Treasure: This is what you have, your possessions. It's your money, and also your toys, clothes, collections - everything that you own.Are you bewildered? If you have never been a "giver" it may seem quite odd for me to suggest you should just give away any of your time or your stuff. But that is exactly what I mean.If you want to make sure you are never defeated by greed, learn to be a giver.When you give to others it helps you to be grateful for what you have. Giving is the way to stop feeling sorry for yourself. Instead of misery, you feel joy. In place of dissatisfaction you find contentment.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on teaching children values and financial principles, which aligns with educational content rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Backpack giveaway draws big crowd in Goldsboro
content:
Backpack giveaway draws big crowd in Goldsboro

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 20 | Section: News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GOLDSBORO - CASA of Caroline and Caroline Pride partnered for the third year to set Caroline County Public School students up for success by holding their third annual Backpack Giveaway in Goldsboro on Wednesday, Aug. 30. Representative from both organizations and the Town of Goldsboro set up by the old railroad station. In less than 2 hours, 110 backpacks filled with supplies like notebooks, rulers, pens and pencils, and other items necessary for successful academic learning, were distributed to children and families.This year the Town of Goldsboro got involved by donating money toward the supplies and providing crafts and activities for kids to do to get them in the back-to-school mindset."We wanted to get involved this year because we could see the real need in our community and are always looking for more ways to reach out to our residents and help them with resources," said Jeannette DeLude, town manager of Goldsboro."The town is so happy that CASA of Caroline and Caroline Pride have brought this event to our town. The North County area is often overlooked, and we, the town and its council, are thrilled that we can help families in need in this part of Caroline County and encourage everyone to also come out for our Fall Fest on Oct. 7 in the same location," she said.This is the third year these two agencies have brought school supplies to the northern part of the county.Amy Horne, executive director at CASA of Caroline, said, "We know that the kids our program serves are involved with multiple systems - the court system, the child welfare system, the health care system, and the school system. As a result, returning to school can be difficult and unpredictable.Our goal is not only to advocate for kids in the courtroom but also in the classroom. By ensuring the children in our community have all the supplies they need to learn and perform in the classroom, we are setting them up for success." Having a backpack and school supplies on the first day of school is important for young scholars to feel like they fit in with their peers. Students who feel they fit in at school are more likely to participate in school activities, have friends, perform better academically and have good mental health."As a member of a vulnerable population that is targeted by bullies, I know what it's like to feel left out.I don't want any kid in Caroline County to start their school year feeling left out because they didn't have a backpack or any supplies on their first day of school," said Angel Perez, CEO of Caroline Pride.Ashley Powell from Greensboro Elementary helped pack the backpacks.Numerous businesses and individuals donated items and money to make the program a success."I'm so proud to be a part of this community that gives back to those in need," Perez said."Yes, it's a community effort, and we're all responsible for keeping our eyes on kids and making sure they have what they need to feel safe, set up for success, and to thrive," Horne said. 
 
 Caption: CONTRIBUTED PHOTO

title: Create a mouth-watering holiday feast - St. Michaels classes pair students with star chefs
content:
Create a mouth-watering holiday feast - St. Michaels classes pair students with star chefs

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Learn techniques and tips from trained chefs that are sure to have your holiday guests' palates dancing with joy with two courses beginning this fall and offered by the St. Michaels Community Center and Chesapeake College.Led by community center Executive Chef Kerri Clear, the St. Michaels community of star chefs will be sharing and showing the techniques they use during the holidays to excite you and your guests and families during this special time of year."Our participants raved about our inaugural culinary classes this past spring, so we're really excited to be offering these holiday cooking courses this fall," Clear said. "Our class sizes are kept small so that participants can work alongside trained chefs in an atmosphere that builds confidence in the kitchen and camaraderie among our participants." "Preparing the Perfect Holiday Meal: Turkey & the Fixins" is class CET 272 9A and takes place on Wednesday, Nov. 1, from 6-9 p.m. In this class, participants will work alongside experienced chefs to focus on exciting holiday meals including salt brining, turkey roasting and carving techniques, preparing butternut squash and Yukon gold "mille feuille," 1,000 roasted layers, Farmer's Market vegetable hash, seasonal vinaigrettes and pecan pie."Preparing the Perfect Holiday Meal: Roasting a Leg of Lamb" is class CET 273 9A and takes place on Wednesday, Dec. 6, from 6-9 p.m. In this class, participants will work alongside experienced chefs to focus on roasting a leg of lamb and preparing vegetable ratatouille, the perfect potato puree and exquisite holiday meringues.Each class takes place at the St. Michaels Community Center and includes two hours of cooking lessons and one hour for a family-style dinner with students and instructors sharing the prepared meal together.Course fees are $95 per participant, per class. Class sizes are limited, with advanced registration with Chesapeake College made at chesapeake.edu/ce-search and entering the class number.Donations to the St. Michaels Community Center's annual fund and proceeds from its Treasure Cove Thrift Shop, located on Railroad Avenue in St.Michaels, help provide essential human services, programs and community events for people in St. Michaels and from throughout Maryland's Bay Hundred area. The nonprofit is currently undergoing an adaptive redesign of its building, with architectural renderings, new programming information and more at stmichaelscc.org/future.

title: St. Michaels library to feature tax stamps
content:
St. Michaels library to feature tax stamps

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 179
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Ron Lesher will be the guest speaker for the October Lunch & Learn series at the St. Michaels Branch at noon on Monday, Oct. 2.Ron Lesher is a longtime stamp collector, exhibitor, and a nationally and internationally accredited judge of stamp exhibits. His column, The Tax Collector, has appeared more than 170 times in The American Stamp Dealer & Collector.He is a life member of the American Philatelic Society, which in 2021 bestowed upon him the Luff Award for distinguished philatelic research. Lesher will discuss The Taxation of Legal Alcohol During National Prohibition, 1920-1933.Legal alcohol during National Prohibition included medicinal alcohol which could be gotten with a doctor's prescription and sacramental wines, both of which were taxed.In addition to the tax stamps for alcohol and wine, there will be examples of prescriptions for alcohol that were filled at the Jackson Pharmacy on Tilghman Island.The Lunch & Learn speakers series is sponsored by the Friends of the Library.Coffee and dessert will be provided. For more information, visit tcfl.org or call 410-745-5877.

title: Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: A13 | Section: News 
 
 676
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties came together virtually Monday to discuss a $79 million project to build a new Technical Center at Chesapeake College.Each county must decide whether or not it wants to submit a letter of intent to the Maryland Higher Education Commission to provide local funds for the facility before a Sept. 28 meeting at the Department of Budget and Management. The meeting, according to Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, is an opportunity to get the project "to the next level" by getting it put on a state list of capital projects.The state has agreed to pay for 75% of the capital project.With these letters of intent, each county would agree to providing local funds for the other 25%. In an email, Coppersmith said that once state funding has been allocated and approved, each supporting county would need to pass appropriations to fund the local share of the capital project.The facility would be more than 90,000 square feet. Of that total, 52,000 square feet would be assignable space. Currently, construction is set for 2026. The center will be located next to the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center."Our problem right now is we've got so much equipment crammed in these spaces, there's not a lot of room for students," Coppersmith said of the current Queen Anne's Technical Building during the meeting.According to meeting documents from a Queen Anne's County Commissioners meeting Sept. 12, the new facility "will house programs such as electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary, skilled office/administrative support and marine and construction trades training." Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian chaired the meeting between counties Monday evening. Fithian said that while the new facility would be great to have on the Eastern Shore, Kent County does have concerns about the financial aspect of the project.Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter said the cost of building the new facility is what strikes him most."I would really like to have a little bit more information about where that number is coming from," he said.Coppersmith said the estimated cost includes furnishing the building. He added that the equipment is not a part of that estimate."Existing equipment that's useable and still in date, we would just move into the new facility and obviously we would raise money - private funding, public grants, etc.- to upgrade our equipment once we get the building built and we're ready to move in," Coppersmith said.Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. acknowledged that the price of the project is a concern, but said he feels confident they will be able to receive more money from the state for the project.Later in the meeting, Wilson said that the Queen Anne's County Commissioners had already voted last week in favor of providing letter of intent.Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said Dorchester County would have to vote against sending a letter of intent at this time. Pfeffer acknowledged that it is a "great project" but said that fiscal responsibilities in the county are keeping them from being able to send a letter of intent. Pfeffer said Dorchester County commissioners would be willing to send a letter of support for the project without a binding fiscal commitment.Fithian said each county is going to have to make its decision individually."We're all going to have to sit down with our finance office and really see what we can do," he said.During the meeting there were talks of possibly submitting a letter, signed by all five counties, detailing the benefits of having this new facility in order to obtain addition funding from the state.Toward the end of the meeting, Talbot County Council member Keasha Haythe said she will be voting in favor of Talbot County submitting a letter of intent."As a Chesapeake College alum, I believe it's very necessary and needed," she said. "And considering how the labor force is doing a dive right now, this labor force is needed. We definitely have to be forward thinking to be able to accommodate the future needs of our children and those that are in high school currently." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a $79 million technical center for Chesapeake College and the counties' decisions about funding it, making the primary focus higher‑education infrastructure. While county officials are involved, the core subject is the educational project.

title: Commission president: 'I'm on the fence with this' - Breeding balks at Caroline's share of $94M building replacement
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Commission president: 'I'm on the fence with this' - Breeding balks at Caroline's share of $94M building replacement

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 917
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - With Caroline County's other spending priorities on the front burner, Chesapeake College's $79 million funding request to the five Mid-Shore counties to construct a new technology center was met with hesitation by the Caroline County Commissioners at their Sept. 19 meeting.But the deadline is quickly approaching to make a decision about an over $3.8 million request the county is being asked to fund as its share for a new - and the commissioners agree is necessary - technology building.A virtual meeting was held Sept. 18 between leaders of the college and of the five counties that support the community college in Wye Mills.Earlier in the month, Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith made his case to the Caroline County Commission in Denton.The "renovation project for the Queen Anne's Technical Center is well past its due date for either a heavy renovation or absolute replacement," Coppersmith said on Sept. 5.He asked for "statements of support or letters of intent from each of (the) support counties." Those letters are due before Sept. 28. The project has been submitted to the Maryland State Department of Budget and Management, which will consider it, along with a list of other state projects, on Sept. 28.At their Sept. 19 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners agreed to draft a letter of intent to support the project, as long as the intention is specifically worded as non-binding.The programs housed in the 2-story, 90,000 square-foot building will include electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary and marine and construction trades training.The state will pay for 75% of the project, with the remaining 25% to be funded by the five counties, and the percentages determined by each county's population. The state's contribution would be just over $59 million.At both the Sept. 5 and Sept. 19 meetings, Commission Vice President Larry Porter supported funding the project, but expressed concern about future unknown costs associated with the 2021 Blueprint for Maryland's Future.Also at the Sept. 5 meeting, Commissioner Frank Bartz supported the project. "I support this, but Kirwan's going to be the big challenge down the road, but I think our community needs this. I think our young adults need this to offer them more opportunity." Kirwan is a nickname for the Blueprint."I really do, very seriously, understand the financial impact that this project will have on the region we serve," Coppersmith said on Sept. 5.As of Sept. 18, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties agreed to help finance the project. However, Dorchester County declined, and Kent and Caroline had not announced their decisions. A simple majority of counties is needed to approve funding the project.Caroline could join the Queen Anne's County's bond, but the county's interest on the bond over 20 years would increase the final cost to over $6 million."And that is on top of the HPAC (Health Professions and Athletics Center) building that we currently pay approximately $110,000 on, so that will put our payment for facilities at $420,000, roughly, until 2034 when the HPAC drops off," said Caroline County Finance Director Daniel Fox.Commission President Travis Breeding was not fully convinced at yesterday's meeting. "This just kind of popped up two weeks ago," he said."I agree with the consensus of everyone on the call that the building is needed," Breeding said. "But I'm not sure yet how it falls into my priority list. One of my major concerns is and I want to get a few more answers from the college before I vote on it." Breeding said he wanted to know "is how much our local Career and Technology Education Program will be able to utilize the facility during the day." "I am concerned that we have Federalsburg Elementary School, and part of that school was constructed in the 1930s," he said. "We have Lockerman Middle School, Denton Elementary School (and) Ridgely Elementary, all constructed in the 70s as well, and we have a CCTC building at North Caroline High that was constructed in the 1960s. Not to mention, we have a detention center build looming on the horizon, whether we see this regional agreement through." "So, I'm concerned with our ability to take on this much debt," Breeding said. "I don't want to hamstring future boards with a $312,000 payment for the next 20 years, because that will be a line item that they will have no control over, and they will be forced to fund. And I'm concerned about Blueprint. I'm on the fence with this, and I'm going to do a lot more research into next week." Porter said he didn't support the HPAC building project, but he supports the new technology center build. "I think while this opportunity is available, we should utilize it," he said. "If these students are successful in receiving this training and these certifications, they would be able to stay in this county and not have to go somewhere else." Porter said he believed, based on Fox's figures, the county "would be in a position where we would not have to borrow the entire amount." "I'm also cautiously optimistic about the ability of Del. Ghrist to get some Blueprint credit for this," Porter said. "I'm not counting on it, not because I don't think he can't do it - I just don't count on things that are not concrete." The commission will make a final decision at its 9 a.m. meeting on Tuesday, Sept. 26, in Room 106, 109 Market St., Denton. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT
 
The Caroline County Commissioners hosted a presentation by Chesapeake College President Clifford Coppersmith Sept. 5. In this screenshot, Coppersmith, lower right inset, explains the need for a new technology center. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Chesapeake College's request for funding to build a new technology center and discusses its impact on students and training programs, making education the primary focus, with secondary relevance to local government budgeting and economic considerations.

title: Tyranny Of The Loud At Washington College
author: David Reel
content:
Tyranny Of The Loud At Washington College

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: David Reel | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With great shock and even greater sadness, I read media accounts of protestors disrupting a recent presentation at Washington College in Chestertown.The presentation featured Dr.Robert George, the McCormick professor of jurisprudence and director of the James Madison Program in American Ideals and Institutions at Princeton University.While Professor George has deeply held conservative beliefs which he does not shy away from expressing, he is also a frequent conversation partner with Cornel West, a progressive professor and political activist. They have appeared together at colleges and universities around the country, arguing for civil dialogue and a broad conception of campus freedom of speech as essential to the truth-seeking mission of academic institutions.Of his longtime friend West has said: "Robby and I struggle over many issues, but at the deepest human level, it's hard to find anyone with his kind of integrity and genuine concern for others."Progressive Supreme Court Justice Elena Kagan has said this about Professor George: "He is one of the nation's most respected legal theorists and the respect he has gained is due to his sheer brilliance, the analytic power of his arguments, the range of his knowledge, a deeply principled conviction and a profound and enduring integrity."No stranger to threats of bodily harm, Professor George was once targeted with death threats for views on abortion.So how was Professor George treated during his presentation at Washington College? Extremely poorly is an understatement.The protesters at his presentation did not quietly carry signs and engage in civil dialogue with Professor George following his remarks. Instead, media at the event reported the following: "The protesters marched in, with campus security allowing them passage.Shouting from the protesters started right away, breaking up the professor's talk."The media reported the protesters waved flags, waved signs, blew whistles, played music and danced. They did not stand down until Professor George's presentation ended prematurely, and he [George] was escorted from the room.After this shameful treatment Professor George observed that in all his years visiting numerous colleges and universities including Berkeley, Yale and Harvard (hardly bastions of conservatism), he never had this happen before.After this event, he observed that "when intimidation works, they'll continue to do it."Indeed, they will. Intimidation at this event did work, and there is no reason to believe the protestors will not do it again with anyone who does not embrace their views or asks them to consider other views.That being the case the following questions need to be addressed by the leadership of Washington College.What has been or will be the college's response to the protestors willful disregard for the following Washington College core values?"We share these values of our founding patron, George Washington: integrity, determination, curiosity, civility, leadership, and moral courage. We develop in our students' habits of analytic thought and clear communication, aesthetic insight, ethical sensitivity and civic responsibility.What has been or will be the college's response to the following comment by one protestor at the event after an email was sent to all students reminding them that it would be a violation of the Student Honor Code to disrupt a speaker?"Are you going to tell me that WAC (Washington College) can expel every single one of us?Absolutely (expletive) not!" Why did campus security decide not to intervene with timely and appropriate steps to deal with the protesters well before their disruptive behavior resulted in a premature end of the event?Post event a college spokesperson said, "The protesters took issue with homophobic and transphobic statements that Professor George has made in the past."Is the spokesperson implying that Washington College agrees with the protester's interpretations of and opinions on statements made by Professor George in the past? How committed is Washington College to free speech, civil discourse and ensuring students are exposed to a wide range of views that may challenge how they think and what they think?One can hope that going forward Washington College will walk their talk on their core principles and student honor code to help ensure this recent tyranny of the loud will never happen again. 
 
 Caption: WILL BONTRA GER
 
Robert P. George in his lecture: "The Truth Seeking Mission of the University."
 
WILL BONTRA GER
 
Protesters and the audience interact creating mixed reactions in Hynson Lounge. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a protest at a college event and questions the institution's response, focusing on campus free speech and academic environment, which aligns most closely with the Education topic.

title: Get Outdoors Day celebrated at Hazel Discovery Center
content:
Get Outdoors Day celebrated at Hazel Discovery Center

 September 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EDEN - The Hazel Outdoor Discovery Center, a haven for wildlife and outdoor enthusiasts, announced its celebration of Get Outdoors Day on Saturday, Sept. 30, from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m. In collaboration with more than a dozen local organizations, this free event promises to be a thrilling experience for kids and families seeking adventure, education and a profound connection with the great outdoors.Nestled amidst the fields and forests of Eden, the Hazel Outdoor Discovery Center offers an idyllic setting for those yearning to unplug their kids from the online world.This Get Outdoors Day event presents a unique opportunity to immerse yourself in nature's wonders, with activities designed for every age and interest.Get Outdoors Day features more than a dozen free activities led by local experts to help your kids connect to nature.Activities include kayaking, sporting clays, archery, fishing, mountain biking and rock climbing.Under the supervision of trained instructors, participants can test their skills, challenge their limits and ultimately create lasting memories.Education is at the heart of this celebration, with engaging interactive displays taking place throughout the day. Experts from local universities and non-profit organizations will share their knowledge on topics such as wildlife, marine biology and the importance of preserving our natural heritage.To cater to the event participants, the Hazel Outdoor Discovery Center will offer a hayride, free hot dog BBQ and free t-shirts for kids (while supplies last). Parents can rest assured that their little ones will be both entertained and educated in a safe and supervised environment.There is no need to register for this free, family-friendly event. For more information about the Hazel Outdoor Discovery Center, please visit HazelOutdoors.org.

title: 'Fantastic job this summer' - Summer school program to expand next year
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'Fantastic job this summer' - Summer school program to expand next year

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 919
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Based on the success of the 2023 summer education program and continued grant funding, Caroline County Public Schools' leaders are aiming to teach 400 more students next year.Presenting statistics and anecdotal comments about the program at the Sept. 5 meeting of the Board of Education, Lindsey McCormick, director of College and Career Readiness, gave "huge shout-outs and kudos" to the 75 certified teachers, 15 instructional assistants and seven site coordinators who "chose to give up portions of their summer and continue to work with our students." Instructional assistants also received additional training this year.Caroline County School Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons praised McCormick's leadership."Lindsey has done a fantastic job.Her team has done a fantastic job this summer, he said. "This (report) is an absolute testament to that."McCormick said 100 Caroline County Recreation and Parks staff helped with the 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. elementary summer camp called Jurassic Jamboree, which attracted 50 more students this year than in 2022."They're a tremendous partner," she said.The summer lessons and activities were designed for elementary, middle and high school students, with special programs for students with disabilities and multilingual learners.McCormick said the five-week time frame for summer programming was essentially the same as last year's, running from June 23 to July 27. Altogether, 916 students participated.Elementary students numbered 747 and attended sessions at four elementary schools (Federalsburg was closed for renovations). The average attendance was 14 days of the 19-day program.Participating in the elementary programming were 70 multilingual learners, 49 of whom attend Greensboro Elementary School.In the morning, students participated in both Reading Eggs and Moving with Math or Agile Mind; the Agile Mind math program was introduced for fifth grade students. When the teachers left, students had lunch, and in the afternoon, Recreation and Parks staff led enrichment activities.Secondary students attended only morning sessions. McCormick said one of the goals was to "boost our middle school program.""We raised our numbers to 40 students, and I was thrilled with that," she said. She praised after-school coordinator Deja Thompson for implementing what McCormick envisioned."Our middle school students had 45 minutes a day where they could rotate through, by choice, some CTE (Career and Technology Education) mini-sessions," McCormick said, adding that "one of the large pushes" in the Blueprint For Maryland's Future is more career exploration starting in middle school through high school.McCormick added comments from both teachers and parents to her PowerPoint presentation. One parent noted, "My seventh grade son didn't want to 'give up' his summer but over the course of five weeks, he only missed three days. He was extremely excited about the CCTC programs he was able to see.""I thought it was just great that our students had the opportunity to be exposed to some of our different CTE programs," she said. "The CTE teachers themselves came to the middle schools to do that."Middle school students attended a tri-county, career enrichment day in Dorchester County that McCormick called "amazing."Simmons explained the that Dorchester program is funded by the Mid-Shore Regional Council and is led by People for Change, "an organization out of Prince George's County of largely minority business owners and professionals who run STEM sessions."High school students were offered summer "credit recovery" courses, and 131 participated and passed the courses, 92 from North Caroline and 39 from Colonel Richardson."It was less students this year, which you could say is a good thing because if you are doing credit recovery, you want less students," McCormick said. Students can take credit recovery courses during the school year, as well as repeat courses to earn credits needed for graduation.The program for students with disabilities from elementary through high school increased by 30, with 127 students participating, 102 at the elementary level, and 25 secondary students.CCPS Food Service provided breakfast and lunch for all students, as well as lunch for elementary students, or nearly 15,000 meals. Health rooms were staffed with nurses and health assistants, and School Based Wellness Centers were open.McCormick expects next year's program to be the same duration."Nineteen days is amazing.It's not too short, and it's not too long," she said.Because some classrooms had waitlists, McCormick said her "goal is to increase summer programming by 400 students, so I have to have about 1,200 to 1,300 students next summer."A 21st Century Grant is pending to help fund the program.This year's program was funded by the American Rescue Plan Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief (ARP ESSER) Fund, food services and in-kind in use of buildings, according to CCPS Communications Officer Sandi Barry."We have this funding for one more year, and we want to make sure we maximize it.," Simmons said. "We will continue to look for grant opportunities working with our partners, with Recreation Parks, with the YMCA, if possible.""We will continue working with our partners, but we're going to maximize everything we can to make it make it work, make it sustainable, and then have the great data to then go to the grant sources to keep the funding coming in," Simmons said. 
 
 Caption: A big bounce house and slippery slide cool off Preston Elementary School students who attend the 19-day summer program.
 
A little game of checkers is a great way to connect during summer camp at Greensboro Elementary School.
 
Lindsey McCormick, CCPS director of College and Career Readiness, presents results of the Summer School program.
 
These two friendly Greensboro Elementary School Hornets are not in a stinging mood during summer camp.

title: Raskin leads recognition of Banned Books Week
author: Josie Jack; Capital News Service
content:
Raskin leads recognition of Banned Books Week

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josie Jack; Capital News Service | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Mary-land, and Sen. Brian Schatz, D-Hawaii, introduced a bill Wednesday calling for the national recognition of Banned Books Week, which is Oct. 1-7, and the condemnation of banning books in school libraries.The bill recommends that local governments and schools "protect the rights of students to learn and the ability of educators and librarians to teach" and calls for upholding the First Amendment but does not include a unified national protocol for dealing with book bans."You know, the proper response to hating a book in a free society is you don't read the book," Raskin said at a Capitol Hill press conference Wednesday.The bill, which has 40 co-sponsors in the House and 15 in the Senate, echoes bills the lawmakers introduced in the last session of Congress but neither measure passed.Instances of book banning increased by 33% from the 2021-2022 school year to the 2022-2023 school year, according to the nonprofit PEN America. Books such as "The Bluest Eye" by Toni Morrison and "Gender Queer: A Memoir" by Maia Kobabe repeatedly have been targeted by critics. Many titles that receive so-called requests for review involve themes of race, sexuality and sexual abuse.Between July 1, 2022, and June 30, there were 3,362 instances of book banning in public libraries and in schools, according to PEN America.Florida accounted for 40% of the book bans. Top states where book bans were instituted were Texas, Utah, Missouri and Pennsylvania.The Senate Judiciary Committee earlier this month held a hearing on book bans, where senators and five witnesses discussed balancing the freedom of speech of parents and taxpayers with those of students, teachers and librarians. The hearing examined book ban policies at the state and local level.The debate did not include the introduction of federal policies on book bans nor a tangible, federal solution. Sen. John Kennedy, R-Louisiana, asked witnesses Cameron Samuels, a student at Brandeis University and co-founder of Students Engaged in Advancing Texas, and Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias to provide a clear solution; neither did."The discussion we've been having for me, it's a little too conceptual, or I don't know, metaphysical," Kennedy said.The federal government has not passed legislation to create a unified procedure on book bans. Book ban and review policies and decisions are currently made at the local government level.On June 12, Illinois passed a law that makes libraries that ban books ineligible for state-funded grants. It is the first state in the country to take such action and could pave the way for future federal legislation."It's my hope that other states, that others may look toward Illinois and see the value in adopting our legislation as a model to stop banning books in its tracks and to protect the right to read freely without fear of retribution," Giannou-lias said at the legislation's signing. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a congressional bill and state actions addressing book bans in school libraries, focusing on students' right to learn and educators' ability to teach, which aligns primarily with education policy.

title: Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties came together virtually recently to discuss a $79 million project to build a new Technical Center at Chesapeake College?Each county must decide whether or not it wants to submit a letter of intent to the Maryland Higher Education Commission to provide local funds for the facility before a Sept. 28 meeting at the Department of Budget and Management. The meeting, according to Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, is an opportunity to get the project "to the next level" by getting it put on a state list of capital projects.The state has agreed to pay for 75% of the capital project. With these letters of intent, each county would agree to providing local funds for the other 25%. In an email, Coppersmith said that once state funding has been allocated and approved, each supporting county would need to pass appropriations to fund the local share of the capital project.The facility would be more than 90,000 square feet. Of that total, 52,000 square feet would be assignable space. Currently, construction is set for 2026. The center will be located next to the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center."Our problem right now is we've got so much equipment crammed in these spaces, there's not a lot of room for students," Coppersmith said of the current Queen Anne's Technical Building during the meeting.According to meeting documents from a Queen Anne's County Commissioners meeting Sept. 12, the new facility "will house programs such as electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary, skilled office/administrative support and marine and construction trades training."Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian chaired the meeting between counties Monday evening. Fithian said that while the new facility would be great to have on the Eastern Shore, Kent County does have concerns about the financial aspect of the project.Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter said the cost of building the new facility is what strikes him most."I would really like to have a little bit more information about where that number is coming from," he said.Coppersmith said the estimated cost includes furnishing the building. He added that the equipment is not a part of that estimate."Existing equipment that's useable and still in date, we would just move into the new facility and obviously we would raise money - private funding, public grants, etc. - to upgrade our equipment once we get the building built and we're ready to move in," Coppersmith said.Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. acknowledged that the price of the project is a concern, but said he feels confident they will be able to receive more money from the state for the project.Later in the meeting, Wilson said that the Queen Anne's County Commissioners had already voted last week in favor of providing letter of intent.Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said Dorchester County would have to vote against sending a letter of intent at this time. Pfeffer acknowledged that it is a "great project" but said that fiscal responsibilities in the county are keeping them from being able to send a letter of intent. Pfeffer said Dorchester County commissioners would be willing to send a letter of support for the project without a binding fiscal commitment.Fithian said each county is going to have to make its decision individually."We're all going to have to sit down with our finance office and really see what we can do," he said.During the meeting there were talks of possibly submitting a letter, signed by all five counties, detailing the benefits of having this new facility in order to obtain addition funding from the state.Toward the end of the meeting, Talbot County Council member Keasha Haythe said she will be voting in favor ofTalbot County submitting a letter of intent."As a Chesapeake College alum, I believe it's very necessary and needed," she said. "And considering how the labor force is doing a dive right now, this labor force is needed. We definitely have to be forward thinking to be able to accommodate the future needs of our children and those that are in high school currently."

title: Counties sue social media over mental health in schools - Talbot among 10 counties claiming classroom distraction
author: Christina Walker; Capital News Service
content:
Counties sue social media over mental health in schools - Talbot among 10 counties claiming classroom distraction

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Christina Walker; Capital News Service | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1088
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A "boring and pointless" education.That's what students at Henry E. Lackey High School in Indian Head, in Charles County, tell their English teacher Nicholas Gray they're receiving while they distract themselves with TikTok videos, "snaps" on Snapchat and endless scrolls through Instagram during class."It is difficult to convince [students] that learning is more impactful and important than the brand new video that will entertain them," Gray said.With that thought in mind, Charles County this month joined nine other Maryland school districts in a lawsuit against the world's social media giants: Google, Meta, ByteDance and Snap Inc. Other school districts in the state that have joined the court action are Anne Arundel, Baltimore City, Carroll, Cecil, Harford, Howard, Montgomery, Prince George's and Talbot."Hopefully this lawsuit provides pressure for some action in terms of how to better create products that are geared to children," said Maria Navarro, superintendent of Charles County Public Schools.CLASSROOM DISTRACTIONThe lawsuit accused several social media platforms of targeting and manipulating youth so they stay engaged for excessive amounts of time - and that's exactly what educators see in Charles County classrooms."(Social media is) a huge distraction in our schools and in our classrooms," said Cheryl Davis, principal of Henry E. Lackey High School.The teachers do their part to plan effective, instructional uses for technology in the classroom, Davis said, but personal devices get in the way.Gray said he prohibits the use of cell phones during instructional times and tries to create engaging lessons so that students will not be tempted to use their devices or go on social media.However, he said, the biggest problem plaguing his students is self control and their failure to regulate personal behavior."Students are lacking the ability to express their emotions in a positive way," Davis said. "We see a lot more negative expressions."Students have gotten more angry and aggressive, Davis said. In a developmental part of their lives, they often fail to pause for a moment and look for resources or constructive ways to express their emotions."There is no respite," Gray said. "Students leave for the day and the talking/anger continues onto Instagram or Snapchat, and then the students come to school upset over what is on social media."Several Charles County educators said more physical altercations have occurred because of social media conflicts."Snapchat scares me," said Brian Street, a father of two Piccowaxen middle schoolers."I've seen several fights at school on Snapchat."On top of that, two staff members at St. Charles High School were injured Thursday after they intervened in a physical altercation between students that started over a social media post, according to a letter that Principal Tammika Little sent out to parents."Please monitor your child's electronic devices and social media accounts," Little said.MENTAL HEALTHNot surprisingly, school officials in Charles County and elsewhere are alarmed at how social media affects child development and mental health. That concern is also reflected in the lawsuit, which alleges that companies are aware of the negative impacts the platforms have on children's mental health, but they choose to prioritize profit.Students go through developmental changes from elementary school to middle school, where their focus shifts from their parents to their peer group. Navarro said this is when children start pushing their own boundaries and understanding how to become an adult.As students become more self-sufficient, they begin building confidence - but social media usage during this stage can interrupt a child's growth, Navarro said."A fake reality, at those pivotal developmental ages, has more of an impact on behavioral health," Navarro said. "It also isolates you."Navarro said social media augments the insecurities children face at pivotal ages, and research seems to prove that point. Researchers at Facebook found that Instagram, in 2021, made one in three girls feel worse about their bodies, according to the Wall Street Journal.Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic further isolated children and left many in a more fragile mental state.According to the Centers for Disease Control, in 2021, suicide was the second leading cause of death for people ages 10 to 14.Charles County educators said social media contributes to the mental health crises that some young people endure. Inappropriate social media interactions continue to create disruptions in the buildings all over the county because children these ages are not developmentally ready for the responsibility, Davis said."Students lack the maturity to be able to handle social media," Davis said.That being the case, Davis said schools must make mental health a priority or else their true purpose will not be achieved."We are here to educate students," Davis said. "If students are not in the right mindset, then it's much more difficult for them to access education."Searching for solutions While voicing support for the lawsuit, Charles County educators are looking elsewhere for more prompt solutions to the problems social media causes in the classroom.Davis pushed for parents to be a part of the solution."You pay for the phone, you own the phone, put some apps on there that allow you to control access," Davis said.Parents should be monitoring their kids' devices to make sure they're safe, Davis said, and it is not just her who feels this way."It's not a school thing, it's a parent thing," Street said.He said that while he does monitor his kids' social media usage, it is a parents' decision on how active they want to be in controlling it.Navarro said Charles County Public Schools has many resources for parents to learn how to be tech savvy so they know how to keep their children safe. In addition to limiting screen time, she said parents should be encouraging kids to physically play, talk and participate in sports and extracurricular activities with other kids.Navarro said when to allow children to have devices is a parent's choice."My job is to inform and educate them about the implications of those decisions," Navarro said. She said she wants students to reach their full potential, but right now social media makes it harder for them to do that.That's where the lawsuit could help.Navarro said that if the district gets any compensation from this lawsuit, the school system intends to expand resources for the growing needs of behavioral health.And even in these early stages, Navarro said, the lawsuit serves an important purpose."It sends a message," she said.The message: that everyone - from social media companies to educators to parents to students - must be alert to the harm that social media can do to young people. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on school districts filing a lawsuit over social media's impact on classroom distraction and student mental health, making it primarily about education policy and school environments.

title: Dorchester schools gain proficiency on tests
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester schools gain proficiency on tests

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 901
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Dorchester County Public Schools saw an increase in English language arts scores on the spring 2023 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, assessments compared to the year before.Math data showed a few significant increases along with some slight changes in proficiency compared to the year before.During a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting, Jodi Colman, director of curriculum, instruction and assessment for Dorchester County Public Schools, shared data from the spring 2023 MCAP assessments.The MCAP assessments are statewide and administered to students starting in grade three through high school.Data broken down by individual schools is not yet available to the public.ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTSFor grades three through six, there were significant increases in the percent of proficient learners in English language arts from the year before.The MCAP assessment uses four levels to measure student performance."Proficient learner" is the third of four levels. Level one is a "beginning learner," level two is a "developing learner," and level four is a "distinguished learner."Students who fall into levels 3 and 4 are considered proficient in the subject. In Dorchester County, the percent of students that fall into level 4 for the English language arts and math categories are between 0 and 5%.For the level three proficient learner category in English language arts, compared to Spring 2022 data:▪ Third graders increased to 31% from 26.4%.▪ Fourth graders increased to 32% from 27.6%.▪ Fifth graders increased to 33% from 26.8%▪ Sixth graders increased to 33% from 22.2% - a 10.8% increase.▪ Seventh graders decreased to 20% from 24.1%.▪ Eighth graders decreased to 27% from 29.2%.Along with seventh and eighth graders, there was a drop in the percent of proficient learners for the English 10 assessment compared to the previous year. The percentage dropped from 36.4% to 35%.Colman said the state average growth for English language arts was 2.9 percentage points.Dorchester County's average growth was 4.1 percentage points, she said."So we grew significantly, or doubled, the amount that the rest of the state did," she said. "It put us at the eleventh spot [in the state] as far as growth is concerned."Laura Aberg, DCPS supervisor of reading and English language arts for K through 12, spoke after Colman presented on the English language arts data."I'm excited to see all the growth for our younger students," she said."Our secondary students, we need to do some work to get back to the levels of growth that we like to see."Aberg said the district has implemented more diagnostics at the beginning of the year to identify those "reading gaps" so they can be addressed sooner for secondary students. She also talked about getting ready to enroll students in grades six through eight, as well as tenth graders, in MCAP tutorials.Aberg said she hopes to see even greater growth for younger students in the future since the district has implemented a foundational reading program that aligns with the science of reading, or the research behind how students learn to read.Board Member Theresa Stafford asked Aberg what the district did differently last year that might be attributed to the growth in proficiency for elementary students.Aberg mentioned multiple changes including the use of DIBELS test data to "help drive instruction" and getting teachers trained in the science of reading.MATHWhen it came to MCAP math assessments, grade seven and Algebra I saw significant increases in proficiency. The percentage of seventh graders that were considered proficient learners increased to 11% from less than 5% the year before. The percentage of Algebra I students that were considered proficient learners increased to 10% from less than 5% the year before.For grade six, there was a decrease in proficient learners, compared the year before, from 10% to less than 5%.For the other math assessments in the county, there was a mix of slight increases, slight decreases and constants in the percentage of proficient learners compared to the previous year. These include:▪ Third graders decreased to 20% from 20.3%▪ Fourth graders increased to 15% from 14.6%▪ Fifth graders increased to 14% from 12.2%▪ Eighth graders stayed at less than 5%▪ Geometry students stayed at 0%▪ Algebra II students decreased to 0% from less than 5%Colman said that while the state average growth for math was 2.5 percentage points, Dorchester County grew 2.0 percentage points.DCPS is focusing on improving math scores for third graders, sixth graders and Algebra I students this year, she said."Those were kind of the focus areas as far as the data," Colman said.She said there is a focus on third grade because it is the first group of students to take the MCAP assessments and there is a need for those students to gain a better understanding of the assessment.At the middle school level, Colman said the math coach is working with teachers and modeling lessons. The math coach is also working and planning with Algebra I teachers."So she's kind of targeted certain grade levels to try to impact some of this data," Colman said.After Colman's presentation on the math data, Board Member Chris Wheedleton talked about the importance of recognizing the data, good and bad, and talking about how the data can be improved for next year."I'm really pleased to see what you all are doing with this, how you've organized it," he said. "But then, it's really about the action."

title: Carey Wright appointed interim state superintendent
content:
Carey Wright appointed interim state superintendent

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Board of Education voted unanimously on Wednesday evening to appoint Carey Wright as the interim State Superintendent of Schools for the remainder of the current term through June 30, 2024. Wright will begin her service as state superintendent by Oct. 23, 2023, pending the completion of onboarding logistics.Most recently, Wright served for nine years as the state superintendent of schools in Mississippi."I am honored to be appointed to this position and am excited to work on behalf of the teachers, leaders and students of Maryland. Maryland is well-positioned to provide a world-class education system for all its students and to ensure each student's success," Wright said. "I am confident that by establishing strong relationships and partnerships across the state we will witness strong, equitable educational outcomes for our students. I welcome the opportunity to be an active participant in this endeavor."Under Wright's leadership, Mississippi's Quality Counts grade for education improved from an F to a C, improving its ranking from 50th to 35th. Her work reform efforts to improve literacy instruction for children Pre-K through third grade produced significant improvements in literacy rates in Mississippi, with the largest gains in fourth grade literacy on the National Assessment for Educational Progress."I am thrilled to welcome Dr. Carey Wright as Maryland's Interim State Superintendent. She is an exceptional leader who will guide Maryland's education system into its new chapter," Gov. Wes Moore said. "Dr. Wright brings exemplary expertise to this role and I am confident that she will be a dedicated leader committed to transparency, accountability, and partnership to improve education outcomes in every corner of Maryland, just as this state deserves."Wright has long been an enthusiastic advocate for early childhood education and in Mississippi implemented the first publicly funded Early Learning Collaborative program, which earned the state recognition from the National Institute for Early Education Research as one of only seven states in the nation that meet all or most quality standards for early childhood education.Wright brings to the position decades of service as a Maryland educator with stints in Prince George's, Howard, and Montgomery County Public Schools as a teacher, principal, director of special education, and associate superintendent. Prior to serving as superintendent in Mississippi, Wright served as the chief academic officer in DC Public Schools. Wright obtained her bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Maryland, College Park."Dr. Wright is a Maryland educator and a national leader of education reform. She has the experience and expertise to lead Maryland through implementation of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and through our state's commitment to educational equity and improving outcomes for all students," State Board President Clarence Crawford said. "We are confident in her ability to lead our school system through this transition period, to be focused on transparency and accountability, and to continue building towards the improvements in results in our schools that we all know are necessary."Wright will receive a salary at an annual rate of $350,000, which will be prorated to the amount of time she serves from now through June 30, 2024. The joint State Board and MSDE Transition Team will support Wright as she is onboarded, and the national search for a permanent state superintendent of schools will continue in the coming months. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'My purpose was fulfilled' - Caregiver awarded scholarship
content:
'My purpose was fulfilled' - Caregiver awarded scholarship

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON - When Casey Hart walked into a Wilmington hospital three years ago, she told medical staff that she was going to die. All of a sudden, this professional caregiver was on the other side of needing care.Hart, a resident of Worton, had developed sepsis after a surgery in 2020, and needed around the clock care in her recovery. "If it wasn't for my two aunts," Hart stated, "I wouldn't be here right now." Hart's aunts went to work, re-arranging the home to make it more accommodating for Hart's care. "They bathed me, brushed my teeth and hair," said Hart. "I owe them the world." This traumatizing experience gave Hart a better insight into what her clients go through, how vulnerable they are.Hart, a Worton resident, works for Griswold Home Care, a business founded over 40 years ago by Dr. Jean Griswold in suburban Philadelphia. Some of Hart's clients are simply looking for companionship while others require more involved personal care services.Hart was recently awarded $3,000 in scholarship funds after winning the company's 2023 National Caregiver Scholarship Program, in partnership with its nonprofit organization, the Jean Griswold Foundation. She plans on using it as she pursues a RN nursing degree.The Griswold National Caregiver Scholarship Program is intended to offer financial support to family caregivers, professional caregivers, and those interested in pursuing a career in the care industry. Hart was nominated for the scholarship for being an exceptional caregiver in the Worton area of Kent County. Hart feels lucky to be a part of the Griswold Home Care family."Their support has pushed me toward success. I wouldn't trade what I was doing for anything in this world." Hart began caregiving at an early age, taking care of her niece who had special needs. Though she tried working in retail, her heart just wasn't in it. When she began delivering professional care to clients, she knew this would become her life's work."My purpose was fulfilled," said Hart.Part of the joy she finds from her work is getting to know the stories of her grateful clients."The veterans share details of coming home from war," she said. Another memorable client was a woman who was paralyzed when a drunk driver hit her on the night of her senior prom."She had every right to be angry, but she was just happy that she was saved," Hart said. "I believe that there is always something to learn from everyone I serve." "Our founder Jean Griswold believed in lifelong education and the importance of providing growth opportunities for our care professionals. Post-pandemic, the crucial role played by caregivers became obvious, and the Jean Griswold Foundation Board of Directors felt strongly about refocusing its mission to support them financially through scholarships," said Michael Slupecki, CEO of Griswold, and Jean Griswold Foundation Board member."Money is often the only thing standing between a motivated caregiver and a degree or certification.If we can help elevate the care profession through education, it benefits not only Griswold, but everyone across the country. Because if you haven't yet needed the support of a caregiver, you absolutely will someday." 
 
 Caption: CASEY HART 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a caregiver receiving a scholarship to pursue a nursing degree, highlighting educational support and career development, making Education the primary focus, with health and business aspects as secondary.

title: 'We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged' - Library director 'shocked' by efforts nationwide to remove controversial books
author: Laura Tayman
content:
'We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged' - Library director 'shocked' by efforts nationwide to remove controversial books

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 791
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kent County Library's Executive Director Arnessa Dowell participated in "7 Questions to Ask the Library's Executive Director," while traveling to the branches of North County, Rock Hall and Chestertown and sharing her ideas with county citizens and answering questions they had. Kent County News had the opportunity to ask her questions as well.Dowell was hired in early 2021, when the Kent County Library, like everything else across the country, was trying to adapt to the new norm of living with Covid.Q: What has been your biggest challenge as Executive Director?A: "I got acclimated to everything very quickly," said Dowell. "I oversaw the return of the senior team, putting library staff in place, and finally opening the branches back up." Dowell thanks the community for their support and was pleased that the library has since increased its growth."We've definitely seen an increase in library patrons, with over half the residents now owning a library card," she said.As the world began to get back to the new normal, Dowell and her team shifted focus to upgrading technology and making more of it available to county residents. Today, she and the library's board of directors are now working on improving their current program offerings; developing solutions to the issues raised by patrons in a recent survey; and focusing on how the library is identified in the community today.Q: What are you focusing on currently?A: "I want residents to feel we are inclusive," said Dowell, "like our libraries are really for everyone." New programming, a new website, and more technology for increased access to information for residents are planned for 2024. There are also ongoing discussions about future plans for the Rock Hall branch location.Q: Why did you become a librarian and why did you come to Kent County?A: Dowell says she was born in Mississippi, but grew up in Germany with her military family.Most of Dowell's extended family lived in Maryland, and she moved back and started working at Goucher's and then Towson's libraries. When her mother became ill, it was her librarian friends that got her through it. "They were wonderful and really made me want to work in that profession," said Dowell.Her commitment to increasing the opportunities for residents of a rural area is why she took the Executive Director position in Kent County. She cited examples that have been put in place to support that goal, like the Kent County free laptop program and expanding the e-library offerings.Q: What has been your greatest success so far at Kent County Library?A: Dowell was very excited about the results of this year's summer reading program. Over the course of nine weeks, registered summer readers embraced the "All Together Now" theme at 75 summer library events."Last summer, readers logged over 700,000 minutes, so this summer we set our sights even higher at 850,000 minutes," said Dowell. "The final count for this summer was over 900,000 minutes read!" Q: What is coming up in the fall for Kent County Library?A: Dowell said all county libraries of Maryland have partnered with Maryland Humanities in the "One Maryland One Book" program that aims to bring communities together through the shared experience of reading, discussing, and exploring the themes in a single book. This fall's chosen features author Tommy Orange's work "There There." Released in 2018, the book tells the stories of twelve Native Americans as they converge toward the Big Oakland Powwow. Critics have called it "a riveting portrait of the urban Indian experience." I'm excited to share that the Kent County Library will hold a special presentation with Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott, the first Female Chief of the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians," said Dowell, "She will be speaking about the past, present, and future of the Nause-Waiwash on Maryland's Eastern Shore." Q: What is your feeling about the movement to ban books in other areas of the country?A: "I am just shocked," said Dowell. In fact, Kent County Library will be participating in the American Libraries Association's Banned Books Week this fall. "We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged that are still on our shelves. Books help people learn and open a door to creativity," Dowell said. "I believe that everybody deserves a voice, and I feel like representation matters." Q: What is your favorite book?A: Dowell said the answer was a simple one-"Oh, the Places You'll Go" by Dr. Seuss. "It's really the theme of a library's purpose," said Dowell. "A really good book or technology at your fingertips can take you anywhere in the world." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Arnessa Dowell, executive director of Kent County Library, visited all branches last week to provide information for and to get input from library patrons. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline schools, grounds spruced up over summer
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline schools, grounds spruced up over summer

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 450
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - While students and teachers took time off during the summer, Caroline County Public Schools Department of Operations personnel were busy sprucing up buildings and grounds.At the Board of Education's Sept. 5 meeting, Director of Operations William Mengel presented a slide show featuring the projects completed over the summer of 2023.Mengel said the operations teams "did a remarkable job getting these buildings ready for for today and beyond." They include:▪ ADA-compliant ramps for the tech center's transition portable, Colonel Richardson High School and the Denton Elementary School portable and sidewalks at Greensboro Elementary School.▪ Refinished high school gym floors with new mascot logos.▪ Cafeteria remodeling, which included four kitchens upgraded with new line serving equipment; two kitchens redesigned for increased student flow and better line service efficiencies; painted ceiling grids, new ceiling tiles, walls, doors and LED lighting in six cafeterias; and a fullsize wall mural mounted in the Federalsburg Elementary School cafeteria.▪ Smoke and vapor sensors installed in all secondary schools.▪ Safety clean-ups, which included tree removals at North Caroline High School and Lockerman Middle School.▪ CCPS branding, including 3-D logos and taglines on administration buildings and selected district vehicles.▪ New concrete pads and sheds at the Greensboro and Federalsburg Judy Centers.▪ Electronic systems installed at Preston Elementary School allowing remote access to HVAC systems at the building level. Personnel will be able to access via their computers or iPad devices from anywhere.▪ Visitor bleachers at Colonel Richardson High School with seating capacity up to 150 people; will last for at least 80 years without safety concerns or compromise.▪ CCTC Agriculture Room: custom designed and built in-house wall cabinetry with locking doors made with recycled materials.▪ Purchase of two athletic field mowers.▪ Roof replacements: Federalsburg Elementary School-58,000 square feet and 98% complete; North Caroline HS - 178,000 square feet; phase 1 is 95% complete.▪ Unexpected projects: Colonel Richardson High School visitor bleachers foundation, severe flooding in the front of Colonel Richardson Middle School in two different places, fire sprinkler pipe; leak in the front lobby at the Family Support Center, removed Lockerman Middle School portables; and Ridgely elementary school next-door white house and property donated by William Moore and used for fire training by Ridgely Volunteer Fire Department.

title: 'You are a 10!' - Speaker motivates, inspires at Talbot schools
content:
'You are a 10!' - Speaker motivates, inspires at Talbot schools

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - International motivational performer, speaker and author Alex Boyé visited Talbot County Public Schools last week to inspire students in healthy thinking and interactions with others.ParentGuidance.org, a company that offers parents guidance and therapeutic support for youth mental health and suicide prevention efforts, partnered with TCPS to bring Boyé to speak with students in fifth through 12th grade."Alex Boyé was phenomenal," said TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi."We are so grateful to be able to share his wisdom with our students. His energy, enthusiasm, and talent are the perfect combination to deliver such an important message." On the "You Are a 10!" school tour, Boyé talks with students about his experiences of being the son of a single Nigerian immigrant mother in the United Kingdom, his challenges growing up and succeeding as an international motivational performer and author.He also performs many of his hit songs to amplify his message of hope, optimism and self-worth."With the current youth mental health climate across the world, and as a father of eight, it is important to me that our youth understand their worth, and they are a 10," Boyé said. "It is a privilege to tell my story of being the ultimate underdog, coming out on top, and helping students get through their struggles." Boyé's "You Are a 10!" book and video was recently released with overwhelming success, garnering positive reviews from school districts and students from across the nation.Boyé is known for his dynamic African-infused music and covers that have garnered millions of views on YouTube.He competed on "America's Got Talent" in 2015 and was named Rising Artist of the Year and grand prize winner in a music contest sponsored by Pepsi & Hard Rock Café in 2017.The "You Are a 10!" school tour is provided by the Cook Center for Human Connection and ParentGuidance.org, and was funded by the MD Aware II grant. Representatives from ParentGuidance.org were on hand during the tour to support teachers, parents, and students with additional

title: Talbot Mentors celebrates recent college graduates
author: Contributed

Talbot Mentors celebrates recent college graduates

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 550
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Three long-time participants in the Talbot Mentors mentorship program graduated from college during the 2022-2023 school year.Tabius J. Wilson, Jr., who joined Talbot Mentors in 2013, graduated Cum Laude from Hampton University last spring. During his time at HU, Wilson majored in liberal studies, minored in leadership studies and took on several leadership roles, including serving as president of the Hampton University Student Government Association and as vice president of the Eastern Regional Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.He was named a merit scholar and a W.D.C.Harvey scholar, as well as receiving the First Annual Gamma Lota Darrell K. Williams Leadership Award. This fall, Wilson will be attending George Mason University's Antonin ScaliaLaw School, where he has been awarded a full-ride scholarship.Randei Collins, who also joined Talbot Mentors in 2013, is a proud Washington College graduate.When applying to WAC, Collins was accepted into the esteemed Washington Scholars Program and received a full-ride scholarship.She went on to major in communications and media studies with a concentration in business and organizational communication.She also completed minors in both writing and marketing.Collins was very involved in campus life, serving in the Beta Pi chapter of the Alpha Chi Omega sorority, the Black Student Union, Cleopatra Sisters, Rotaract Club and the American Marketing Association.She received many honors for her academic achievements, including membership in the National Society of Leadership and Success, the Marketing Honor Society and the National English Honor Society.Collins also interned for the Library of Congress Publishing Office, the Cherry Tree Young Writers Conference, and in the fields of integrated communications and analytics.She is currently pursuing career leads and, after a much deserved gap year, plans to enroll in the Emerging Media graduate program at Loyola University.Taylan Brooks joined Talbot Mentors in 2016 and graduated from Morgan State University in the fall of 2022.Brooks earned his bachelor of science degree in information systems with Summa Cum Laude honors and was proud to be titled the Fall 2022 class salutatorian with a GPA of 3.94. He was also the Fall 2022 recipient of the President's Second Mile Award for his outstanding leadership and participation in student affairs.During his undergraduate experience, Brooks served in various leadership roles and organizations including: vice president of the MSU's Association of Information Technology Professionals, Morgan's Male Initiative on Leadership and Excellence, the National Society of Collegiate Scholars and the Clara I. Adams Honors College Honors Society. His motivation and hard work landed him a full-time position as an associate IT business partner at Textron Systems, a leading defense and aerospace technologies and services corporation located in Hunt Valley.Additionally, Brooks has been accepted in the graduate program at the University of Maryland Global Campus, where he plans to pursue his master's degree in cybersecurity technology.Talbot Mentors applauded Wilson, Collins, and Brooks on their achievements and expressed gratitude for their mentors, Mr. John Strickland, Ms. Anne Davis, and Mr. Jordan Loyd, who supported them on their academic journeys."Mentorship is a gift to both the mentee and the mentor," said Talbot Mentors Executive Director Kentavius Jones. "Both parties benefit greatly.Graduation provides a special opportunity to celebrate the accomplishments of our youth and the contributions of our mentors.Maintaining such lasting relationships takes real dedication and these occasions are testaments to the impact of those bonds."

 EASTON - Easton High and St.Michaels Middle High schools have announced achievement results for the graduating class of 2023.
