title: Howie sworn into vacant Board of Education seat
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Howie sworn into vacant Board of Education seat

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Anna Howie was sworn in as the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education at a work session Monday evening.The swearing in came nearly a week after Howie was appointed to the seat by Gov. Wes Moore following the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.Howie will serve on the board until early December 2024, when a newly elected member is sworn in.After being sworn in by Talbot County Circuit Court Clerk Kathi Duvall at the work session on Monday, Howie took her seat at the table and the board went into a closed session.Before the board went into closed session, Board President Emily Jackson welcomed Howie to her new office."We're all excited that you're here," Jackson said."And we've got a lot of work to do, so roll up your sleeves." Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.According to a press release from Talbot County Public Schools, the Talbot County native, who lives in Easton with her husband and children, has 21 years of experience in K-12 education.Howie has a bachelor of industrial engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology and a master of arts in supervision and administration from the University of Phoenix. She is currently pursuing a doctorate in organizational leadership from the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, according to the press release.The Talbot County Education Association endorsed Howie for the appointment."We submit this recommendation without reservation and with our heartfelt belief that she is an ideal candidate who will serve our community well," Andrew Burke, TCEA president, said in a letter to the governor.

title: Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - When Queen Anne's County history teachers Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders first began recruiting students for National History Day years ago, there wasn't a lot of convincing students to participate."We knew we had to up our game," said Anders. "Now the Upper Shore region is second in the state for participation." National History Day is an event that encourages students to develop research, analysis, presentation, and social skills while working on a historical project. Open to students across the Shore, including Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, working individually or in groups, Junior Division (grades six-eight) and Senior Division (grades nine-12) students select a topic related to an annual theme. Information on the competitive event is distributed to students by their history teachers.The 2024 NHD theme is "Turning Points in History." There are five different types of projects that students complete: documentaries, exhibits, performances, and websites that can be done as a group or individually or papers that may only be done individually.Research is key, so the two teachers partnered with the public libraries in the participating Upper Shore counties of Queen Anne's, Kent, Talbot, and Cecil."Schools have limited research options," said Hayman, "so we turned to the county libraries who have more resources." During the fall season, as students begin picking a theme and looking for information, the teachers make themselves available at libraries across the region on specific dates so that librarians and History Day staff can provide assistance with finding research options, accessing online databases, or browsing materials.Hayman said the students learn valuable skills "like how to analyze information, to make sure sources are reliable, and to form their own opinion." Last weekend, Hayman and Anders visited Queen Anne's Library on Kent Island. Next up is the Talbot County Free Library in Easton on Oct. 21 from 9 a.m. 1 p.m.; Queen Anne's County Library in Centreville from 9 a.m. 1 p.m. on Nov. 4; and the Learning Resource Center at Chesapeake College on Nov. 12 from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.The actual contest is March 23, 2024, at Chesapeake College. Judges from the Upper-Shore community include teachers, professors, and museum staff. Students who place are then able to participate in the state finals on May 4 at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.The hard work of Hayman and Anders has paid off. "We saw that at the beginning the winners were always from the western shore," said Anders."Now we send more students to the state event than everyone but Baltimore County." Hayman said the program helps make history more real and interesting to students."You don't usually have students thrilled to be in history class," said Hayman. "Students who participate sometimes find their true passion." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders, both history teachers at Centreville Middle School, visit Queen Anne's County Library Kent Island branch on their first stop helping students from the Upper Shore with their History Day project research.

title: Washington College receives $54.7 Million from Hodson Trust - Guarantees $30k+ scholarships for students with a 3.3+ GPA
content:
Washington College receives $54.7 Million from Hodson Trust - Guarantees $30k+ scholarships for students with a 3.3+ GPA

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Washington College announced the largest gift in the College's 240-year history: a $54.7 million gift from The Hodson Trust to provide financial support for students. The Hodson gift will grow the College's scholarship endowment to approximately $170 million and its overall endowment to $325 million, strengthening the College's ability to make a college education more affordable to students from all backgrounds."This generous gift from The Hodson Trust is truly transformative for Washington College," said President Mike Sosulski. "Access to an outstanding educational experience is a pressing issue for many families today. The Trust's support of our students' financial needs expands our ability to ensure access to a wide range of potential students, particularly those who are first-generation or come from underserved communities." As a result of the Hodson gift, Washington College will guarantee a minimum scholarship of $30,000 per year ($120,000 over four years) to any incoming student with at least a 3.3 grade point average who applies by Dec. 1. Students may qualify for more aid based on their academic performance. The Hodson Trust Washington Scholars endowment, which provides full tuition, fees and the cost of room and board for students with significant financial need, will also benefit from this gift."We are excited to be able to offer this scholarship opportunity to deserving students," said Vice President for Enrollment Johnnie Johnson. "It will allow us to continue to grow the diversity of our campus community and enhance the intellectual environment of the College. These scholarship funds will help us recruit more of the best and brightest students to Washington College from Maryland, the mid-Atlantic region, and beyond." Support for financial aid opens new opportunities for students and their families who think an education at a private college is out of reach.Because private colleges like Washington provide significant student financial aid when compared to public universities, the cost of a private education becomes more affordable. For the current academic year, Washington College provided $40.6 million in total financial aid with the average student aid totaling $45,745, compared to the University of Maryland, whose published average student aid is $9,074.The gift is part of the dissolution of The Hodson Trust. Established in 1920 by Colonel Clarence Hodson, the Trust has been a longtime supporter of Washington College and its largest benefactor, having now donated more than $150 million to the College since 1935.For almost 90 years, The Hodson Trust has contributed to Washington College in a number of ways, including establishing or contributing to endowments that support student scholarships; undergraduate research and internship stipends; faculty chairs, salary enhancement, and professional development funds; and the College's signature academic centers. In addition, The Hodson Trust contributed to the construction of Hodson Hall, Hodson Boathouse, the John Toll Science Center, and the Lelia Hynson Boating Park.The Hodson family has a long and illustrious legacy at Washington College.Colonel Hodson, his daughter, Lelia Hodson Hynson, and granddaughter, Sally Hynson Hopkins, served on the Washington College Board of Visitors and Governors. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chapel District Elementary renovation design plans move to state for review
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Chapel District Elementary renovation design plans move to state for review

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education approved the design development submission for the Chapel District Elementary School renovation and addition at a Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening.The design development plan needs to be submitted to the state for review by Nov. 1. TCPS Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said this submission is the next milestone in the design process.Before the board voted unanimously to submit the design development plan, Shafer and Adam McDonald, project manager and architect from design firm Hord Coplan Macht, gave a presentation to update the board on plans for the project, including the schedule and estimated project costs.McDonald explained that the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and 16,600 square feet of additions.Three total additions at different corners of the building will add additional learning space."The additions are also going to help us enhance the overall design of the building," McDonald said.Since the board's last update on project plans, McDonald said they have made changes to the addition on the north corner of the building to "work better with the existing utilities" during construction.A traffic pattern has been formalized, and a first submission has been made to the State Highway Administration to create an additional curb cut to separate the parent entry loop from the bus drop."To help alleviate some of the traffic concerns that come with a shared entrance," McDonald said.The design plans for outside also include an extension to the parking lot to provide more space for parents dropping off students.Inside the building, McDonald said that most spaces will remain in the same areas as they are pre-renovation.The main change, he said, is that the media center will move to the front of the building and the art classroom will take over where the current media center is.Currently, bidding for the project is expected to take place in April and May of 2024. Construction would begin in June of 2024 and is estimated to take about two years.The estimated cost of construction and site work is $25.18 million. State and county funding for this will come out of FY2025 and FY2026 budgets. With additional expenditures, for things like design costs, the project is expected to cost $29.97 million.Shafer said this estimated cost is $1 million less than the state projection for the project."So I feel like we're within where we want to be," he said, adding that this is still just a projection and the real numbers will come when they bid the project out.After the presentation, board members asked questions.Board Member Deborah Bridges asked about the plan for the school's roof."The slanted roofs really have me worried," she said, expressing concern about drainage.Shafer said the pitched roof is not near the courtyard."The architect will make sure that any kind of drainage that's coming off the roof, whether it's roof drain or exterior drain, is properly sized to accommodate that water shed," he said. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT

title: It's in the family - Anna Howie speaks on joining Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
It's in the family - Anna Howie speaks on joining Board of Education

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 551
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Education is in Anna Howie's blood.Specifically, Talbot County education is in Anna Howie's blood.Her grandfather and mother taught in the district.Her mother was even her sixth grade language arts teacher at Easton Middle School.When Howie, the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education, went to college, she wanted to be an engineer.However, a career in education just kept chasing her.In college, she became involved with something called 'The Algebra Project,' where she taught students algebra concepts.For a college internship, she worked with students at a middle school.At a college ministry meeting, Howie remembers the speaker saying, "someone in here, you're an engineering student.And you know God told you you're supposed to be a teacher.'" Although she graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology in engineering, she unsurprisingly found teaching eventually. Her first job in education was teaching at a middle school.Now, Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.Monday, she was sworn in to the Board of Education after being appointed to the District 5 seat by Gov. Wes Moore. The appointment comes after the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.W hen she learned of the appointment, Howie told her husband first. He was so excited he switched a flight he had for a conference so he could watch her get sworn in on Monday.Howie herself was excited and honored."A little scared at the same time, because this is a huge undertaking and it's extremely important," she said.Howie talked about the importance of being able to support students' social and emotional and mental health, especially after COVID-19."Schools are safe places for a lot of our students," she said. "If I'm hungry, if I'm angry, if I don't know where I'm going to go to sleep tonight, I can't learn." Social and emotional learning is one of the Board's priorities this school year. Its other priorities are increasing academic achievement and teacher retention."There are teacher shortages everywhere right now, and it's so important that we retain the teachers," she said."Because when you have to continually hire new teachers, there is that onboarding process and there is that learning curve." Joining the board, Howie is continuing her mother and grandfather's legacy in Talbot County Public Schools.When Howie was 18, her mother died from breast cancer. She remembers the funeral being "packed" with former students and teachers from the district."There are teachers in this school district that knew my mom when she was here and they come up to me all the time and they're like, 'Your mother would be so proud,'" Howie said, tearing up.With two meetings under her belt so far - a work session on Monday and a regular meeting on Wednesday - Howie is feeling welcomed by her fellow board members.She appreciates the organization of the meetings."Everything went very smooth," she said.Although she's been on the board for less than a week, Howie has already been thinking about whether she will run for the position when her seat is up next year. She doesn't have an answer yet, though."I have definitely, definitely put a lot of thought into that," she said. "This is such a wonderful opportunity." 
 
 Caption: ANNA HOWIE

title: QA Advocates for Youth appoints new director
content:
QA Advocates for Youth appoints new director

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE - Queen Anne's County Advocates for Youth Inc. announced it has appointed an executive director and elected three new board members.Outgoing board member Judy Corchiarino of Grasonville has agreed to stay on in the new executive director position, Advocates President Angela Price said. The position, like that of board members, is a volunteer one.Corchiarino will oversee the day-to-day operations of the nonprofit organization and serve as liaison with its member agencies.Corchiarino is a retired food service executive, who has lived in Queen Anne's County for over 20 years. She has two children and four granddaughters.In addition to Advocates, Corchiarino is active in Chesapeake Republican Women and Queen Anne's County Council for Children and Youth and a volunteer for Centreville Day and Make a Difference Day.The three new members elected to the Advocates Board of Directors are Lynn Engelmeyer of Grasonville, Carol Franks-Randall of Centreville and Erin Coyne of Stevensville.Marjorie Lynn Engelmeyer is a native Marylander. She has been a resident of Homeport in Grasonville since 2010 and is a member of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in Chester. She grew up in Perry Hall and was educated in Baltimore County Public Schools.Engelmeyer received her Bachelor of Arts and Master's in Secondary Education and Spanish from Towson University. She taught Spanish in Baltimore County Public middle schools and high schools for 30 years.Outside of the classroom, Engelmeyer became a member of Kiwanis and served on committees that supported children's needs. Although retired, she said she wanted to continue supporting efforts of groups that emphasized children's achievement and success, so she became a citizen member of the Queen Anne's County Council for Children and Youth and now QA Advocates for Youth.Carol Franks-Randall, a retired educator, worked for 35 years in New York.During her professional career she worked as a special education teacher and administrator, elementary principal, superintendent and college professor.In 2009, she and her husband, Robert, retired to Centreville.Franks-Randall has written three children's picture books. In addition, she writes a monthly column for the Bay Times/Record Observer, reviewing children's books, and hosts a podcast where she interviews children's book authors and literacy experts. She has established a YouTube channel which showcases read-alouds of her books, and she has been interviewed on the radio and by newspapers in the area.Since moving to Centreville, Franks-Randall has joined a number of volunteer organizations, and said she is delighted to be on the board of QA Advocates for Youth.Erin Coyne describes herself as a recently retired elementary school teacher; proud mom of Chris, a microbiologist in San Diego; a daughter of Bev Coyne; and a blossoming gardener.During her 28 years of teaching, she taught both in private and public school settings; the past 16 years of which were in Queen Anne's County.She has been a volunteer within Queen Anne's County and myriad organizations based in Maryland.She plans on continuing work with organizations that focus on the well-being and education of children."We are excited to have Lynn, Carol and Erin join us in our mission to facilitate programs and projects that benefit local youth and their families," Price said. "They bring a wealth of knowledge and experience with them and will be a great asset to our board." Other board members include: Chris Perkins of Queenstown, vice president; Mary Walker of Stevensville, secretary; Wayne Humphries of Stevensville, treasurer; Jenny Crossley of Sudlersville; and Carol D'agostino of Chester.Members of the Queen Anne's Advocates for Youth Board of Directors are elected to three-year terms and may serve two consecutive terms. The board holds quarterly meetings and may vote by email as needed on matters that arise between meetings. Subcommittees meet on an as needed basis.Interested in making a difference for children and families?Want to become a part of QA Advocates? Contact any board member or email qaadvocates@gmail.com.The Advocates board welcomes all donations to benefit local families. Anyone interested in sponsoring Advocates' partner programs are invited to send a check to Queen Anne's Advocates for Youth Inc., 110 Channel Marker Way, Suite 101, Grasonville, MD 21638.

title: Chesapeake Forum to host final classes of fall semester
author: Contributed
content:
Chesapeake Forum to host final classes of fall semester

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 12A | Section: News 
 
 342
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The fall semester is wrapping up at Chesapeake Forum, but there is still time for a few more classes. There are still spots open for William Messner's lecture on the "Rise and Fall of the Talbot Boys Memorial" and for "Integrity and Effective Leadership" at the USNA.Join Messner on Tuesday, Nov. 14, from 1 to 2:20 p.m. as he lays out the factors that prompted the Talbot Boy's statue's removal last year.As he explains, the pre-WW I period marked the zenith of racism in the nation. Especially in the South, this period saw the institutionalization of segregation and the utilization of extra-legal means, such as lynching, to insure the maintenance of the racial order.Not coincidentally, throughout the South, memorials to the Confederate lost cause appeared, often in the form of statues of Rebel soldiers. Talbot County was not immune to this pattern of activity, as a memorial to those county residents who fought for the Confederacy - the Talbot Boys - was constructed on the Courthouse lawn in Easton.A century later the statue, one of the last in the South still standing on public grounds, was dismantled, the result of a decade of agitation on the part of Black residents and their allies who demanded the erasure of all vestiges of the old racial order.The event will be hybrid, in person at Easton Family YMCA or via ZOOM.It is $20 to reserve a spot. To register, visit https://chesapeakeforum.org.On Wednesday, Nov. 15, travel to the US Naval Academy for a lecture on how ethics and moral reasoning guide behavior, while integrity defines how individuals conduct their daily lives.Taking from both classical and contemporary thought in moral philosophy, Jeff Macris, Ph.D., the deputy director of the Stockdale Institute, will show how the USNA seeks to provide its future Naval officers with the ability to understand the moral complexities of leadership."Integrity and Effective Leadership" is a field trip to the USNA by carpool or private vehicle from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. It costs $20 to participate.To register, visit https://chesapeakeforum.org. 
 
 Caption: JEFF MACRIS
 
BILL MESSNER

title: Denton collegian earns Meoli scholarship
content:
Denton collegian earns Meoli scholarship

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4B | Section: News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 REHOBOTH BEACH - The Meoli Companies has awarded $10,000 in scholarships to five employees who recently graduated from local high schools.Among them is Faith Johnson of Denton, who is attending Penn State University in State College.Johnson, a graduate of North Caroline High School, played defense for six years on North Caroline's field hockey team. She started working in 2021 at McDonald's in Denton, "where she strived to build relationships with people from different backgrounds and experiences," according to an Oct. 11 press release.She is studying veterinary medicine with the goal of becoming a veterinarian.Recipients were selected based on their demonstrated leadership, participation in local community activities, work experience, experience in overcoming challenges, and who and what has inspired them."Often, we are the first job for many of our high school employees, said Michael A. Meoli, owner and operator of The Meoli Family McDonald's Restaurants."Nothing pleases us more than to see them go on to future success and to support that journey." With its scholarship program, Meoli Companies supports "hardworking employees who are headed to college," according to the press release.Headquartered in Rehoboth Beach, Meoli Companies owns and operates 25 McDonald's restaurants across the Delmarva Peninsula.The other scholarship recipients included Jonathan Brittingham of Selbyville, Delaware, who is attending the University of Delaware in Newark, Delaware; Henry Grote of Selbyville, Delaware, who attending Liberty University in Lynchburg Virginia; Monique Payne of Dover, Delaware, who is attending Delaware State University in Dover; and McKenzie Tubbs of Millsboro, Delaware, who is attending the University of Delaware.The scholarship application asked students questions which focused on the employee's overall story, their presence in the community, challenges they have overcome and plans for their education."While we respect the importance of a student's GPA as a demonstration of their commitment to learning, we consider many more attributes to ensure we have a well-rounded picture of the individuals we consider for a scholarship," Meoli said."The response was overwhelming and speaks to the incredible stories these graduates have to share," he said. "For nearly 30 years, we've been committed to delivering a gold standard experience for our McDonald's customers each and every time they visit our restaurants, and that starts by hiring outstanding people." "It's not just about the food we serve or the restaurants we serve it in. It's about the communities in which our restaurants operate. Each of our communities is unique and we strive to find ways we can make the greatest impact in every one of them," Meoli said.

title: Exploding pumpkins take center stage at WC - Annual event draws crowds with explosions and ooze, encouraging STEM participation
author: Contributed
content:
Exploding pumpkins take center stage at WC - Annual event draws crowds with explosions and ooze, encouraging STEM participation

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 419
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - On the afternoon of Oct. 27, the Washington College Chemistry Club hosted its annual exploding pumpkins event on campus, to the delight of a large crowd who had gathered to revel in science-based gourd detonation.The event, which is conducted in conjunction with the American Chemical Society Student Affiliates Club and GAMMA ETA Chemistry Honor Society, draws Washington College students, students from Kent and Queen Anne's Country public schools, and combustion-loving Eastern Shore community members each year ahead of Halloween.Students put together several experiments to test the best way to either explode designs into pumpkins to create unique jack-o-lanterns or generate emissions of various ooze and smoke to come out of unique designs.This year, methods used to induce cool explosions and Halloween-themed demos included glow-in-the-dark luminol, color changing acid and base paired with dry ice, liquid nitrogen, and elephant toothpaste (a foamy substance caused by the rapid decomposition of hydrogen peroxide using potassium iodide or yeast and warm water as a catalyst)."We take immense pleasure in sharing the wonders of chemistry with our students and the promising leaders of tomorrow," said Sarah Arradondo, Washington College Assistant Professor of Chemistry. "For nearly a decade, our campus has eagerly anticipated the annual tradition of using science to infuse Halloween with excitement. The Chemistry Department at Washington College is committed to uniting the community through captivating autumn experiments and thrilling displays of chemical phenomena." Washington College's Chemistry department regularly conducts events and activities to engage the local community in the wonders of using science in an effort to encourage more interest in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) related degrees and careers.In November, the department will host AP students from Queen Anne's High School to tour and conduct experiments in their stateof-the-art lab.For more information on Washington College's chemistry department and degree options visit https://www.washcoll. edu/academic departments/chemistry/index.php.

COURTESY OF WASHINGTON COLLEGE

title: Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities
author: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service
content:
Black and Hispanic faculty underrepresented in universities

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Nira Dayanim; Capital News Service | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 816
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Black and Hispanic communities are underrepresented among university faculty at Maryland's six largest public universities, according to the 2021 Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS).This analysis does not include Maryland's online universities or historically black colleges and universities.IPEDS is an annual data collection system run through the U.S. Department of Education.These findings align with trends across the country, data shows.The U.S. Census projects that 32% of Maryland's population are Black and 12% are Hispanic.At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs - University of Maryland, Baltimore County; University of Maryland, College Park; Towson University; Frostburg State University; Salisbury University and St. Mary's College of Maryland-less than 6% of the total faculty are Black and less than 5% are Hispanic, as of 2021.According to Laura Perna, Vice Provost for Faculty at University of Pennsylvania and a researcher on college access, faculty underrepresentation is a widespread issue, though the specifics differ by university.Across Maryland, faculty demographics vary widely. At Towson University, 7% of faculty were Black in fall 2021 and 3% were Hispanic. At Frostburg State University, those numbers were about halved, with 4% Black faculty and almost 1% Hispanic faculty.Prior to 2022, Maryland's education code allowed individual public universities to implement their own plans for "cultural diversity," which ranged in length and breadth. In 2022, a new code was instituted, requiring public universities to ensure that faculty, staff, and administration demographics reflect the state's diverse population.Between 2016 and 2021, the percentages of Black and Hispanic faculty at the universities included in the analysis both increased by just under a percentage point."It really is amazing how little progress there has been in some ways on this," said Perna.According to Dr. Kimberly Griffin, Dean of University of Maryland's College of Education, many people assume that faculty will diversify alongside the student body. This "trickle up" system is unrealistic, she says.The problem is multifaceted, says Griffin. Academia is tasked with generating a pool, hiring inclusively, yielding candidates, onboarding hirees, retaining them, and ultimately, promoting them. "We have to do more in all of those spaces," says Griffin, whose research has focused on issues of diversity, equity and inclusion in post-secondary education.According to Perna, one roadblock is "invisible labor" faculty of color often take on work that requires time and energy, but does not fit academia's standard promotion metrics."We should be looking at to what extent our definition of merit is very narrow," said Perna.Underrepresented minorities often spend more time serving on committees and mentoring students of color, labor that often goes unrecognized, says Perna. Come time for promotions, publications and course evaluations are weighted more heavily.As the student body has diversified, the gap between representation among students and faculty has widened, straining faculty of color.As of fall 2021, Black students made up 17% and Hispanic students made up 8% of the student body at the universities included in the CNS analysis. That was an increase of 10% and 19% since 2016, respectively.Faculty demographics remained stable.In 2021, the resulting ratio of Black students to Black faculty members was 60:1. The ratio of white students to white faculty members was 15:1.According to Griffin, while it's crucial for students of color to have role models and mentors of color, there isn't enough faculty of color to shoulder that responsibility alone."That's a load everyone should share," she said.A lack of diversity also impacts faculty of color pursuing tenure. At Maryland's six largest in-person public universities, not including HBCUs, in 2021, 71% of tenured professors were white, 5% Black, and 4% were Hispanic, according to IPEDS.A lack of diversity among tenured faculty can make it harder for some faculty of color to find mentors as they pursue tenure, though many members of academia, like Griffin, are trying to combat this by developing intentional mentoring policy."Mentorship that helps you build a sense of connection and community in your unit and in your college is also really important for helping folks get to tenure," said Griffin.Katharina Maisel, a bioengineering professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, co-authored a list of best practices for increasing diversity alongside several other faculty members in the STEM field.According to Maisel, diversifying the faculty, especially tenure and tenure track, takes intention at every stage of the process, from inviting people to apply, inviting people for internships, and checking your shortlist to make sure you're not just inviting people from Ivy League schools.But it's possible.In science, technology, engineering and math, says Maisel, a tendency to be overspecific in job listings can discourage faculty from underrepresented backgrounds.Using rubrics to evaluate a candidate for hiring or promotion can help ensure an objective set of criteria, helping reel in internal biases, Maisel said."If you as a department are really actively interested in increasing the diversity of your faculty, there are things you can do," Maisel said. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses faculty demographics and underrepresentation of Black and Hispanic professors at Maryland public universities, which is primarily an issue within the education sector, though it also relates to race and diversity.

Kimberly Griffin (Dean, University of Maryland's College of Education)

 BALTIMORE - Maryland Humanities, a statewide, educational nonprofit, welcomed nine new members to the organization's Board of Directors recently, including Easton resident Jill Ferris.Ferris and the other new board members join nineteen other volunteers in service.She is the vice president of education and interpretation at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum. Previously a teacher in Queen Anne's County, she received the 2014 district teacher award from Maryland History Day, a program of Maryland Humanities.Ferris has also been awarded the Queen Anne's County Outstanding Teacher Technology Award, Colgate University's Award for Excellence in Teaching and a Fulbright Fellowship to Taiwan. She is an active member of the Chesapeake Curling Club and coaches junior curling.She has her masters of arts in history museum studies from the Cooperstown Graduate Program at State University of New York at Oneonta."I have been actively engaged with Maryland Humanities' numerous programs and initiatives since I first moved to Maryland in 2011," Ferris said. "From my first involvement as a volunteer judge for Maryland History Day, my connections have grown and deepened over time. I am excited to be a part of the continued success of Maryland Humanities now in this new capacity!" According to a press release, Maryland Humanities creates and supports bold experiences that explore and elevate our shared stories to connect people, enhance lives, and enrich communities.For more information, visit www.mdhumanities.org.

STUDENT BRIEFS

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8A | Section: News 
 
 405
 Words

 McIntyre named to Iowa State Dean's ListAMES, Iowa - Reilly Hawkens McIntyre of Denton was recognized for outstanding academic achievement by being named to the Iowa State University fall semester 2022 Dean's List. McIntyre is in his third year and majoring in animal science.Students named to the Dean's List must have earned a grade point average of at least 3.50 on a 4.00 scale while carrying a minimum of 12 credit hours of graded course work.Area students named to Frostburg Dean's ListFROSTBURG - The following students from the area have been named to the dean's list at Frostburg State University in recognition of outstanding academic achievement for the fall 2022 semester: Arianna Cintron, of Ridgely, with the distinction of a 4.0 grade point average.Alexandria Embert, of Marydel.Reagan Mangum, of Federalsburg.Bailey Werner, of Ridgely.Mackenzie Werner, of Ridgely, with the distinction of a 4.0 grade point average.To be eligible, a student must undertake a minimum of 12 credit hours and earn a cumulative semester grade point average of at least 3.4 on a 4.0 scale.Holloway, Vickers make dean's listCONWAY, SC - Taylour Holloway of Denton and Aireal Vickers of Preston were named to the Dean's List at Coastal Carolina University for the Fall 2022 semester.Students who make the Dean's List have achieved a grade point average of 3.5 or higher (3.25 for freshmen) for the semester.Carroll named to Widener University dean's listCHESTER, PA - Widener University congratulates Jalen Carroll of Greensboro or achieving dean's list status during the fall 2022 semester.Bisesi named to Chi Alpha Sigma Athletics Honor SocietyKUTZTOWN, PA - Sydnie Bisesi of Denton was named to the Class of 2023 Pennsylvania Alpha Omega Chapter of Chi Alpha Sigma in the National College Athlete Honor Society at Kutztown University this past spring. The honoree also must achieve at least junior academic standing by the fifth semester or seventh quarter, as determined by the certifying institution, and must have achieved a minimum cumulative grade-point average of a 3.4 (on a 4.0 scale).Murray awarded chiropractic degreeDAVENPORT, IOWA - Travis Murray of Denton graduated with a Doctor of Chiropractic degree from Palmer College of Chiropractic's Florida Campus in Port Orange, Florida, on March 24, 2023.

title: STEM festival engages youth in science, math and more
author: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat
content:
STEM festival engages youth in science, math and more

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS - This past weekend, Chesapeake College in Wye Mills, hosted the sixth annual STEM Festival in the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center.What is STEM, you ask?It's the acronym for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math.The festival was open to youth of all ages, and admission was free. Sessions were offered for a myriad of STEM related topics, including 3D printing and the makerverse, Python coding, and lego robotics GeoCaching, a CDL simulator, a tour of the Health Professions laboratory and an Art and Sciences tour were also offered. The event has seen steady growth since its inception in 2017.Part of the Maryland STEM Festival 2023, sponsored by University of Maryland Extension, 4-H, and Family & Consumer Sciences, Navonne Owen, UME/4-H educator for Caroline County, heads up the event, along with a crew of dedicated educators from the Mid-Shore and the college.Owen estimates this year's attendance topped approximately 250 students and adults. She was happy to say, "Many of the attendees come year after year, especially the younger folks who have an interest in STEM related topics." "We hope to offer topics here to augment what students are exposed to in school, or topics which might ignite an interest - maybe prompting students to go out and discover more about a topic on their own," she said.When asked about the role Chesapeake College was playing in the event, Owen was quick to say "Chesapeake College has really grown a lot in recent years. It's a hidden diamond here on the Shore - a resource which is sometimes overlooked. There are so many options here now for local students, with cost effective options for completing various fields of study." Maryland 4-H has long been a champion of STEM education, offering comprehensive support to engage young people in these critical fields.The program's commitment to fostering STEM skills and interests is evident in a variety of initiatives and activities designed to inspire curiosity, innovation and lifelong learning.To this extent, 4-H offers a wealth of STEM-focused clubs and projects, providing youth with opportunities to explore their interests in subjects like robotics, computer programming, environmental science and more.These clubs allow for hands-on, experiential learning that goes beyond the classroom.4-H hosts STEM camps and workshops that immerse young participants in the world of STEM through engaging and interactive activities.These programs not only educate but also excite and encouraging youth to pursue further studies and careers in STEM.With the help of educators like Owen, 4-H organizes and supports various STEM competitions and events, such as science fairs, robotics challenges, and engineering contests. These competitions promote critical thinking, problem-solving, and teamwork.For more information on similar events or for the 2024 STEM Festival, contact the University of Maryland Extension for Caroline County 4-H Office at 410-479-4030 or by emailing Navonne Owen at nowen@umd.edu. 
 
 Caption: ERIC SYLVIA
 
Emory Woods examines a slide through a microscope while mom Stephanie and Vicki Burchfield of the Caroline County Public Library look on.

 Talbot County Retired Personnel Association announced they presented their Fine Arts Awards to Julie Hawley, the music director, and Shawn Leffler, an art teacher, both at Easton Middle School.Hawley is currently the choir director and general music teacher at the middle school. Over the years, she has performed as a soloist, in countless choirs, and in leading roles in both musicals and operas.She attended the University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music as a vocal performance major and later transferred to Duquesne University, where she graduated in 2010, to complete her bachelor's degree in music education.Hawley began her teaching career with Caroline County Public Schools in 2011. She earned her master's degree in education with a focus in teacher leadership in 2018. In 2020, Hawley began her current position at Easton Middle School with Talbot County Public Schools and was most recently the musical director for "Chicago: Teen Edition" at Easton High School.She also serves as the music director for St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Cordova.Singing is her biggest passion, and she said she feels extremely lucky to be able to share her vocal and musical knowledge with her students every day. In her free time, she enjoys spending time with her husband, daughter and two dogs.Leffler believes creative people are the future of our society.He has been teaching at Easton Middle School for the last two years and in Talbot County since 2011.He has spent the last 21 years teaching students in pre-K through college and finds extreme joy sharing artistic stories and building relationships with his students.Leffler graduated from Buffalo State College with degrees in art education and humanities with a German minor in 2001. title: Detecting problems with old plumbing and pipes
author: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors
content:
Detecting problems with old plumbing and pipes

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - From providing a hot shower at the end of a long day to taking the wastewater out of our home without a smell, the indoor plumbing system is an unsung hero of our everyday lives.We rarely stop to think about the complexities involved in providing a clean glass full of water from our sinks until we step in a puddle on the floor.The indoor plumbing systems in our homes have been constructed throughout the past 150 years of many different materials, and some of those materials have lasted better than others.Daniel Morris, a certified master inspector with Blackwater Home Inspectors, is a preferred partner with Mid-Shore Board of Realtors and will relay some of the materials that throughout the years have shown to be deficient and how to identify them.When referencing residential plumbing, we generally are talking about our supply piping and drain piping. Let's talk about two materials found in the Mid-Shore area that have common issues, polybutylene piping and galvanized steel.Polybutylene piping was introduced in the late 1970s and used through the mid-1990s. Gray in appearance when installed in a home, the lettering "PB-2110" is often printed on the pipe.It was a flexible, cheap and easy to install material. The piping was installed in millions of homes throughout the U.S. because of those qualities.However, polybutylene piping has shown that it is more prone to leaks and deterioration of the pipe material itself. Several class action lawsuits against the manufacturers have taken place, and at this point, the pipe is considered obsolete and in need of replacement.Mobile homes and manufactured homes were often plumbed with this piping material, and it is still common to find these materials today. If you live in a home built in the 80s or 90s, take a second to look under your sink to see if you see any exposed gray piping.Galvanized steel was a product introduced in the 1940s. It consisted of a steel pipe that was dipped in a zinc coating to prevent corrosion.However, over time, with water running through the pipe, the zinc coating on the interior of the piping can wash away. This leads to the piping corroding on the inside and slowly closing the pipe in.Oftentimes, rust particles are introduced into the water running through the pipe, contaminating the water. It often will restrict the flow of water and result in a loss of water pressure.This piping can be identified by a dull, grayish/silver appearance.When the pipe is scratched it will be shiny, as opposed to lead, which will be dull in color.To best test the performance of this pipe, it is recommended you run multiple water fixtures for two minutes and watch for noticeable dips in water pressure. This piping material is past its lifespan at this point, and replacement of the material is recommended.All water pipes can leak, not just the two that are described above.Plumbing leaks are not just a minor inconvenience but can often lead to structural damage to a home if the leak is not caught quickly.There are several pieces of technology now that can help detect these leaks before they become an issue.There are small water alarms that can be placed in areas to detect any leaks and whole house leak detection meters that are installed on your water main and can shut off the water to the home if a leak is detected.Even some water heaters are coming installed with leak detectors.If you have questions about your plumbing system, a plumbing contractor or even a local home inspector can often be of assistance.Morris can be reached at 443-528-1633. The company website is Blackwaterhomeinspections.com.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors is happy to partner with many firms related to the real estate industry. For more news and information check out our website, midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
 
The zinc coating on galvanized steel pipes, such as those shown above, can erode over time, causing the pipe to corrode.
 
MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
 
Polybutylene piping was often used in mobile and manufactured homes in the 1980s and 1990s. It is more prone to leaking than other materials. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Elks provide Veterans Day assembly for Easton Elementary
content:
Elks provide Veterans Day assembly for Easton Elementary

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Local veterans representing all branches of the military shared their personal experiences and perspectives with fifth grade students at Easton Elementary school on Wednesday, Nov. 8.Michael Feehley, who served in the Army, coordinated the event on behalf of the Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Office.He began by explaining that Veteran's Day is celebrated on Nov, 11, which was originally recognized as Armistice Day. The date is significant because fighting between the Allied countries and Germany ended on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918, marking the end of World War I."Stop and think about this day, Veterans Day, celebrating all the service and all the sacrifice of the U.S. Military Veterans," Feehley said to the students. "Veterans sacrificed so that you and I have the freedoms we enjoy today." Each of the seven fifth-grade classes at the school provided one question for the veterans to answer.Brian S. asked "what advice would you give an individual who was considering entering the military?" Jasiah P. asked "what is the most positive thing that happened to you because you served in the armed forces?" "The military gave us the chance to do something we had never done or would never do, like go to the Philippines, or for me, to learn about C-4 and other demolitions, fly in planes and helicopters, or be on a ship." said Mike Detmer, a former Marine and member the Dorchester County Council."It also gives you a chance to grow close to people. When you go through training and hardship or danger with other people, just like when you're on a football or soccer team, you feel a closeness with them. I have brothers who I love a lot, but I feel extremely close to my Marine brothers." "When you have served in the military, you know that you've accomplished something," Detmer said, "and you are serving something much bigger than yourself.You can see how proud all of these gentlemen are about what they've done. But it's not as much pride in what they personally have done, as it is pride in what they have been a part of. That is why I would encourage you to think about it." At the end of the assembly, the students presented cards to the veterans, which will be delivered to patients in a Maryland VA hospital during the holidays."Students in fifth grade across Talbot County write letters to veterans as part of their fifth grade service learning project," said Jeff Bell, Easton Elementary fifth grade teacher. "It is only appropriate that we get those letters to veterans at this time of the year." 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF TALBOT COUNTY SCHOOLS
 
Students in fifth grade across Talbot County write letters to veterans as part of their fifth grade service learning project. Students at Easton Elementary presented their letters to the visiting veterans at the end of the Veterans Day assembly.

title: Board of Education to create Special Education Committee
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Board of Education to create Special Education Committee

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education has created a new committee to address updating, modernizing and funding special education in Talbot County Public Schools.In a unanimous vote, the board directed Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi to lead the charge in the creation of this new Special Education Committee. Board President Emily Jackson introduced the motion at Board of Education meeting Wednesday."I would like to create a committee focused on special education," she said. "As we all know, looking at Blueprint, the way that we are doing our budget and our funding is going to change."The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education. Jackson said this change in the way the budget is done means that there would not be a lot of specific line items "directly applicable to special education" in the budget."Combine that with the fact that our special education population has been growing rapidly," Jackson said to explain why she sees a need for this committee.Jackson said she would like the committee to do a holistic deep dive into what TCPS is currently doing regarding special education as well as what they could be doing. She said she would like the committee to look into modernizing the district's practices and come up with a full proposal for modernizing and funding special education in the county."I think that we all have talked a lot about how we need to approach special ed," she said.Jackson said she would like this committee to spend the year gathering information and come back next year, before budget season, with a proposal that includes what it would cost to modernize special education programming and how the district could fund it. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Talbot County Board of Education President Emily Jackson speaks about the need for a Special Education Committee at a Board of Education meeting Nov. 15.

title: Girl Scouts care for furry friends
author: Tamara Forte; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat
content:
Girl Scouts care for furry friends

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tamara Forte; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Excitement filled the Animal Care Shelter for Kent County in Chestertown on Nov. 11, as Claire Anderson-Schultz, Amelia Beach, Clara Gerber and Ayesha Tapia brought in lots of handmade supplies and needed items to the shelter. These four sixth graders earned their Bronze Award for Girl Scouts by setting their sights on helping the cats and dogs at the shelter.To earn their Bronze Awards, the girls from Troop 899 in Centreville had to complete 20 hours of service in a service project. Sharing a love for animals, it was easy to decide that the project would help animals in need. Claire's mom shared that Claire has been visiting animal shelters for years with her grandfather to spend time cuddling the animals after school.This past summer, the girls toured the facility to learn about what the shelter did and what it needed. From June to September, the girls worked independently and as a team to meet these needs. After reaching out and doing research, the girls learned the ACSKC had recently moved into a new building and had many needs.These needs included: a new cat tree, cat and dog toys, pet food and treats, new storage benches, and cleaning items. The girls explained the shelter had to throw out a beautiful, carpeted cat tree due to a sickness that had hit the shelter. The girls quickly began their mission to make a cat tree that was easy to clean and maintain.During these 20 hours or more of time, the girls strategized in meetings (in person and on Zoom) on how to meet these needs and then worked together to create and build the items needed. The cat tree was thoughtfully made, and with a little help from their parents, the girls found a plan that would use easy-to-clean PVC pipes. After making sure the pipes fit, they glued them together and painted them gold. The girls also made Velcro patches of fabric from reused clothing. "These fabric patches were made from my grandpa's old jackets and now they can be velcroed off and on for easy washing" explained Amelia.Shelter worker, Paige Tucker, said they currently have 109 dogs and cats at the animal shelter. Right now, there are 32 animals in need of homes. Allison Otadan, Shelter Media Coordinator, shared the shelter is "so grateful for the efforts of the girls" for the new cat trees and other pet items. She is excited for the new benches, as the current benches are all scratched up. At this shelter, there are special rooms for the animals to freely roam, but that also causes some of the items to get worn down and scratched. In addition to the cat tree and wooden benches, the girls sewed catnip toys, hand tied snuffle mats (where pet treats can be hidden and found), and collected lots of donations from their whole troop, grades kindergarten through fifth grade.If you would also like to help the shelter, they are currently in need of kitten food, cat food, dog food, and cat/dog treats. There is a complete Wish List on their website that includes the specific brands needed at https://acskc.org/ 
 
 Caption: TAMARA FORTE
 
The girls get to play with the cats that need homes at the shelter. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: High school students become college scientists
author: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com
content:
High school students become college scientists

 November 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com | Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Students from Queen Anne's County High School traveled to Washington College last week to work side-by-side with college chemistry students and get a feel for just how much fun science can be.This was the first year for the partnership developed by Michael Geoffroy, teacher of the Advanced Placement Environmental Science class and science department chair for the school. He reached out to Leslie Sherman, the W. Alton Jones Professor of Chemistry and Environmental Science for Washington College."Advanced Placement courses are college-level work for high school students," said Geoffroy. "I wanted my students to have the experience of using up-to-date technology and learn the processes of lab procedures, like independent work and safety." After donning goggles and lab coats, students began working with a freshman Chemistry class (led by the college's Chemistry lecturer Betsy Moyer-Taylor, the mother of one of the participating students, and assistant professor Jeremy Bard). Students were grouped with college students to complete the lab assignment of changing copper into various forms.A special visitor dropped by in the morning, Frank Keegan, Professor of Chemistry, Emeritus at Washington College who taught chemistry for over 40 years. Ceegan had a special visit with high school student Lucy Taylor, daughter of Moyer-Taylor, one of his former students, noting there were three generations of chemists there that day."I thought everything was pretty cool," said high school student Katie Harvey. "The equipment here is way more advanced." Students were working with multiple modern "hoods" or ventilated enclosures throughout the room used to trap and exhaust vapors and gases, something that most high school classrooms today cannot afford to provide.High schooler Raven Fairbanks said that she felt comfortable with the process. "We are following the same procedures we do in class." College student Terrance Vincent said he liked working with the younger students. "It's keeping me honest," he said. "I have to make sure everything is being done correctly." A brief Q & A with three upper level Chemistry majors followed with a tour of some of the fancier equipment in their facilities."My students loved hearing from the college students, and especially seeing that they were all double-majors. After our previous 'careers in chemistry' activity, I think it helped them to see the 'bridge' between themselves and those possible careers," Geoffroy said.Much of the discussion focused on the college students' workload (one was a student-athlete), as well as internships, jobs after college, and how their personal connections with their professors and advisors have helped them get those opportunities.Students were then treated to some liquid nitrogen demos from Sherman, applying some of the topics they had learned already."The big hits though were making (and eating) liquid nitrogen ice cream, and experimenting with different slime recipes," Geoffroy said.The group ended the trip with free t-shirts and lunch in the college's dining hall.Geoffroy said, "We had many discussions during and after the trip about college in general, and it sounds like Washington College did a great job selling itself to some of our students." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Queen Anne's County High School students Lucy Taylor and Hailey Gill and Washington College chemistry student Tarance Vincent watch for chemical reactions in a joint lab last week. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Education foundation established in Caroline - Four local leaders spearhead funding financial literacy opportunities for students
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Education foundation established in Caroline - Four local leaders spearhead funding financial literacy opportunities for students

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "Now we truly do have an education foundation in Caroline County, which is wonderful," Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons said at the Board of Education's Nov. 7 meeting.The announcement followed several months of work by four community leaders to establish the Caroline County Education Foundation, which was launched on Oct. 5.Tolbert Rowe, Robert Willey, Dr. James Orr Jr. and Wayne Cole spearheaded the effort.With the Blueprint for Maryland Education's unfunded mandate, school districts statewide are exploring funding streams beyond the traditional tax base.Other Mid-Shore counties with established education foundations are Kent and Talbot."The Caroline County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund is a subfund through the Mid-Shore Community Foundation," said Rowe, vice president of Bay Capital Mortgage based in Annapolis."Most importantly, I think it's a landing place that we can find philanthropic individuals and organizations we can solicit." A previous foundation was established in 1987, according to Willey, a Denton certified public accountant who took part in its inception."It was set up on a mini-grant system," Willey said. "The grants weren't supposed to be any more than $500, and they were to be awarded directly to classroom teachers to try to do projects that could not be funded through the school board's budget." "We started off great guns, and we operated for around 10 years, and then the board just got tired," Willey said. "We weren't able to recruit new blood and people with more energy and it just kind of died in the mid-90s." However, just over $8,000 remains in bank account once managed by the former foundation, an account which Willey still oversees.In a Nov. 18 interview, he said the new foundation will preserve the intent of the previous foundation's donors."Basically, it's the seed money that went into the educational fund that we've created with Mid-Shore Community Foundation," Rowe said in a Nov. 16 interview.During a conversation about Junior Achievement - a nonprofit providing financial literacy, work readiness and entrepreneurship education to K-12 students - Willey and Rowe decided it was time to reconstitute an education foundation with the Mid-Shore Community Foundation, of which Rowe is a director."We're focusing our efforts initially with financial literacy, career exploration (and) anything that will enhance children," Rowe said at the Nov. 7 meeting. "Much as Junior Achievement does, it's a shotgun approach. We want every kid to experience these things that will help them to make prudent economic career decisions." Orr said the group of four is currently working on bylaws. The purpose of the foundation "shall be to enhance, inspire and support educational opportunities in the area of financial literacy for all students attending Caroline County public schools," he said.On Nov. 16, Rowe said, "The four of us decided that, at least at this point, it would be more impactful to focus our efforts on a specific area like financial literacy, as opposed to everything, because we just don't have a lot of money.If we get more money, then we can expand the mission, but for right now we're going to hold pat with financial literacy." Rowe said the founders "will be setting up a meeting soon get our bylaws adopted and make decisions as to who could serve with us.If anyone knows of anyone in the community that would be good for this organization, we would love to have a conversation." "Times are changing, and this financial literacy piece is going to become so important and we're going to grow this fund," said Cole, chief financial officer of WIN Transport, Inc. in Federalsburg."Financial literacy obviously is very powerful," Simmons said."Caroline County is still one of the only systems in the state that requires all of our high schoolers to complete a full credit of a finance course before graduation, and I'm glad we have that, but at the same time, one only has to look at the current economic situation we're in to realize that one credit during your high school experience in one county on Maryland's Eastern Shore is not solving a fiscal issue that's in front of us everywhere.But financial literacy is a massive undertaking and needed." Simmons explained that CCPS was the first to sign a memorandum of understanding with Junior Achievement of the Eastern Shore regarding providing students opportunities at the organization's 25,000 square-foot regional facility under construction in Salisbury."It's a great center, but it's also a great program that they put together, working with businesses and communities across the Eastern Shore (and it's) great, strong curriculum coming in," Simmons said. The curriculum aligns with the Maryland State Department of Education's requirements.He said the foundation would be in a good position to help with costs associated with students getting to the facility."We are the furthest distance from the center and we have the highest degree of poverty," Simmons said. "We're the (school) system that has the most need with the least amount of funds to spend to get our kids there, and we have the greatest distance to drive to get there." He added that the Blueprint, which requires career exploration as well as dual enrollment, also requires counties to fund compliance with the legislation."We're required to pay for everybody's dual enrollment who are enrolled in our high schools," Simmons said. "The math in Blueprint doesn't add up. They did not take financial literacy." "That's where Blueprint stands right now, and we'll do our part," he said. He added that the foundation could "help support other things that we're trying to do." 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT
 
Denton businessmen Bob Willey, at the lectern, and Tolbert Rowe on Nov. 7 explain how the Caroline County Education Foundation will fund financial literacy efforts for students. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project
content:
CCTC AMP students present designs - Rashad Wilson's winning design adorns dartboard cabinet project

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY - The seventh cohort of Advanced Manufacturing Program students at Caroline Career and Technology Center recently presented design ideas for their current project, a dartboard cabinet.The winning design was created by Rashad Wilson, and was inspired by the doors one might find hanging in a saloon in the Old West."Rashad's dartboard design offers a new challenge for the class and me," teacher Keith Hale said.Although the students possessed the software and the capability to machine a three-dimensional object like the steer skull and horns, they had never attempted it before. "This design is more challenging than designs created by previous classes," he said.This particular project was generated three years ago when an AMP student approached Hale with the idea of manufacturing dartboard cabinets. Hale and the class were excited to make this idea a reality.Since then, AMP cabinets with dartboard with darts included have been one of AMP's most popular products, selling out even before they were presented.Each time AMP students manufacture a product, they follow the same template.It begins with research, mood-boarding and a product pitch. With dartboards, students research the history, rules and professional leagues in the game of darts. Then each student must come up with a design for the project, followed by drafting their design and placing it on a Mood Board.This Mood Board becomes a visual they can refer to as they present their product pitch.Business partners, school officials, parents and former students are then invited to watch the students' product pitches Oct. 26.One by one, students manage the difficult task of individually pitching the details and merits of their designs to the class and guests in attendance.At the end of the presentations, everyone votes and a design is chosen.The next step in the process is called "napkin sketching," which is a sketch of the product views and dimensions.These sketches are then taken to the computer aided drafting lab, where more accurate prints are made. From those prints, numeric commands are created that will drive a computer numeric control machine, which is a robot programmed to cut pieces out of stock material.Once complete, an audience is once again assembled for student presentations of the finished products, which are also offered for sale. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF CCPS
 
Advanced Manufacturing Program students at Caroline Career and Technology Center presented design ideas for their current project, a dartboard cabinet, on Oct. 26. The winning design was created by Rashad Wilson.

CCTC student Rashad Wilson presents his winning Advanced Manufacturing Program design for a dartboard cabinet.

Visitors and Caroline County Public Schools staff, including Lindsey McCormick, right, and school board member Donna DiGiacomo, second from right, attend an Advanced Manufacturing Program students' presentation Oct. 26 at Caroline Career and Technology Center.

title: Opening Doors (Again) For Literacy
author: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com
content:
Opening Doors (Again) For Literacy

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 718
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - This past September, Ashley Singer was holding a tutoring session with a student when they both began to sense a mechanical burning smell.After exiting the building and calling 911, they waited as local responders arrived.Crews quickly gained control of the smoke situation, but the damage had been done.Singer, Executive Director of Open Doors Partners in Education, said it was a saddening setback. "Though we had insurance, there was an estimated $40,000 loss of materials due to exposure to toxic smoke."Enter Associate Director Julie Blyman who had served as a crisis manager at a school."It was really catastrophic," said Blyman, "but then we got so much support from the community."Singer and Blyman met when they were at the Radcliffe Creek School. The school provided them literacy training and both found early on that tutoring was what they were meant to do. Their Open Doors Partners in Education is a literacy focused organization, founded in 2020 as a direct response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the resulting learning loss in local schools.As graduates of Kent County Public Schools and residents of the county, they were alarmed to watch students who were already struggling fall even further behind."We felt the need to do something to help and the decision was made to create a literacy focused nonprofit organization" said Singer. "We initially wanted to help students in first and second grade, a time when intervention can be most efficient and successful," said Singer, "but as word spread through the county, students of all ages, pre-k through 9th grade, were found on our roster."To date, the organization has assisted over 100 students in the Orton-Gillingham literacy method, a direct, multi-sensory, structured, sequential, diagnostic and prescriptive way to teach literacy when reading, writing, and spelling that does not come easily to individuals, such as those with dyslexia.When the fire happened, the two were amazed by the support of local community organizations, including Washington College, the YMCA, and Stam's downtown.It took only one day for them to take an offer from Emmanuel Episcopal Church to use their Sunday school classrooms.Knowing that they needed a more permanent location, the group worked with Sam Shoge of Rivers & Roads Construction to find an appropriate location. They toured office space in the Lynchburg building and worked with KRM Development Corp. to get the space ready as soon as possible.Open Doors depends on grant funding to exist and has worked with Kit Cares, Inc., a charity navigator and a fiscal sponsor for their 501©3 organization. The funding provides the organization the ability to offer free services to Kent County students."By partnering with local schools, we can provide intensive 1:1 structured literacy instruction at no cost to the families," said Singer."We hope to reach those students who might otherwise fall through the cracks."The organization is also working with a nonprofit consultant on a strategic five-year plan. "We would love to be working more with Kent Co. and Queen Anne's County Public Schools," said Singer. They would also like to enhance their bilingual program. "Research says the Orton-Gillingham literacy method is the best literacy training program for bi-lingual students," she said.Since the fire, the organization is in need of replenishing their paperback book library for students ages 5-16. The organization also has a wish list on Amazon.com.Why are Singer and Blyman so committed to their mission? Singer said, "It is the lightbulb moment when students discover why they want to read, when they realize that a book is an adventure, and they realize they can have many more."Blyman said it is all about why students come to the office for a session. "To know that they are coming here willingly after a hard day of school, that is really inspiring," said Blyman. "And it's very rewarding when we see that parents are so relieved that their children are ok to come here and know they will get the help they need."The Open Doors Partners in Education will have a ribbon cutting at their new location, 116-D South Lynchburg Street in Chestertown, on Dec. 1 at 5 p.m.For more information on Open Doors, go to www. opendoorsed.org. 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Ashley Singer, executive director, and Julie Blyman, associate director of Open Doors Partners in Education have opened their new location in Chestertown after a fire displaced them from their original office. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
