title: Teacher, Support Staff of the Year nominations now open
author: TALBOT COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS
content:
Teacher, Support Staff of the Year nominations now open

 February 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TALBOT COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS | Section: Life 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools has begun the process to select the 2024-2025 Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year.Any member of the community may nominate a candidate to apply to be Talbot's Teacher of the Year or Support Staff of the Year. The nomination forms are available on the TCPS website at tcps.k12.md.us/2024-teacher-and-support-staff-of-the-year/.
The deadline for nominations for both Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year is Friday, Feb. 9.
A teacher must meet the following requirements to be considered for the Talbot County Teacher of the Year:
Hold state certification in area(s) of assignment, Pre-K through 12th Grade;
Be a current full-time classroom teacher as defined by a teaching contract, to include: librarians, specialists, intervention teachers, ESL teachers, gifted education teachers, instructional coaches and special education teachers;
Have a minimum of six years of exemplary teaching experience (can include this current school year). The last two years must be with Talbot County Public Schools;
Plan to continue in an active teaching status for at least one year; and
Submit a professional resume that addresses the following: Education, Certifications, Experience, Leadership and Awards/Other Recognition.
The purpose of the Support Staff of the Year Award is to recognize an outstanding educational support professional for his/her contribution to the success of the learning community, and to focus public attention on the importance the individuals in these vital roles. To be considered for the Talbot County Support Staff of the Year Award, nominees must meet the following selection Criteria:
Must be full-time employees who have worked for TCPS for a minimum of two years. Any member of the community can nominate a Support Staff Employee.
An exceptionally dedicated, knowledgeable and skilled member of the Support Staff in a school or office;
Goes above and beyond the call of duty;
Is supportive of the learning environment;
Is employed in a non-certified, non-exempt position (A&S staff, exempt employees, teachers and licensed professionals are not eligible.)
The nomination forms for both awards must include a minimum 200-word statement about the nominee's qualifications.
"The Talbot Teacher of the Year and Support Staff of the Year recognition is truly a highlight of the school year," said, Dr. Helga Einhorn Assistant Superintendent for Teaching, Learning & Leading. "This event gives us the opportunity to celebrate some of our most outstanding educators for their innovation, dedication and commitment to our students."

title: Sense of urgency needed on school absenteeism
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Sense of urgency needed on school absenteeism

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 634
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Representatives from the Maryland State Department of Education, Maryland Association of Boards of Education and Public School Superintendents' Association of Maryland met recently with members of the Ways and Means Committee in the Maryland House of Delegates.At that meeting, all three advocacy groups expressed their support for fully funding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, also known as the Kirwan Report.
Along with the Blueprint for Maryland's Future there is another issue that has had and will have a significant impact on public education in Maryland.
That issue is chronic absenteeism.
The Maryland Department of Education defines chronic absenteeism as missing more than 20 days in a school year, no matter the reason.
WYPR, the public broadcasting corporation's flagship radio station in Baltimore, recently introduced a news report on this issue with the following lead in:
"Chronic absenteeism 'real concern' Maryland lawmakers and educators aim to address."
WYPR cited Maryland Board of Education data indicating that over one-third of Maryland K-12 students missed 10% or more school days last year, with 54.1% of Baltimore City students and 34.7% of Baltimore County students hitting that mark.
The consequences of chronic absenteeism are serious and long lasting.
Maryland Board of Education President Clarence Crawford has observed that "chronic absenteeism can adversely impact a child for a lifetime." He noted research has shown that "chronic absenteeism impacts test scores, grades and children's ability to be able to graduate." He also noted "chronic absenteeism increases the likelihood of engagement with the criminal justice system."
Especially disheartening in the Maryland Board of Education data that nearly 35% of children in kindergarten statewide are chronically absent.
Sue Fothergill, a senior fellow at Attendance Works (a national nonprofit dedicated to raising awareness about the negative impacts of absenteeism), says: "In early grades, some of our families think, 'Well, it's just kindergarten, or it's just first grade, children can miss a few days here and there, it's not that big of a deal.' The reality though, is that those are the most important formative years, not just for learning to read, but learning social emotional skills and establishing habits that help those young people throughout their careers. When a child is chronically absent in kindergarten, they are less likely to be proficient in reading by third grade as at that point, teachers often switch to content-focused learning. It becomes much harder to catch a child up and be able to learn how to read as they matriculate through their years, because they've missed those formative years."
Gov. Wes Moore and state lawmakers are aware of and have already demonstrated a level of concern and action on this problem.
At a recent "Improving Student Achievement" event in Washington, D.C., Moore said, "We know that there are real obstacles we still have to address."
In the Statehouse and the state Senate, legislation has been introduced to establish a task force to study chronic absenteeism in Maryland's public schools.
The legislation as introduced, requires the task force to report its findings and recommendations to the governor and General Assembly by Dec. 1.
Going forward, local and state funding levels for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future will continue to generate enormous amounts of dialogue and deliberation at local governments throughout Maryland and in the General Assembly. That is to be expected as the Blueprint is a multi-year initiative that mandates a projected $3.8 billion increase above current levels of local and state funding for public education in Maryland.
A critical element of success in public education requires more than mandated increases of local and state funding.
It requires more than awareness of, concern about, and discussions on the issue of chronic absenteeism.
What is needed is a sense of urgency on action to address chronic absenteeism in every public school in Maryland.
David Reel is a consultant who provides counsel and services on strategy, advocacy and media on public affairs issues. He lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan
author: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The House Committee on Education and the Workforce has advanced a Republican-sponsored bill that includes measures repealing key aspects of the Biden administration's plans to make college more affordable.The College Cost Reduction Act, introduced by the panel's chairwoman, Rep. Virginia Foxx (R-North Carolina), passed on a party-line 22-19 vote.
The measure presents numerous programs intended to strengthen the integrity of higher education institutions across the country, but also would gut much of President Joe Biden's efforts to help students afford college. Democrats on the committee offered a series of amendments to the bill aimed at blocking the GOP repeals, but all were defeated.
"Unfortunately, President Biden has decided time and time again that the executive branch should also hold the legislative pen," Foxx said, "Congress has the task of creating laws that reflect the interests of the people. It is not the role of the executive pen."
Last August, the Biden administration launched the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) program, aiming to cancel debt to borrowers who originally owed $12,000 or less in loans and had repaid at least ten years of those loans.
The program is slated to begin in February, with 6.9 million Americans already enrolled, according to the White House.
Biden's original plan, as laid out in his 2022 executive order to cancel up to $430 billion in student loans, was blocked by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision last June. The court determined that the secretary of education lacked the power to issue debt relief on the scale described in the administration's plan.
Last September, Foxx introduced a resolution with Rep. Lisa McClain, R-Michigan, to nullify the SAVE plan, but the full House never voted on it.
Foxx's College Cost Reduction Act, introduced in January, would establish a streamlined data system to convey information about colleges, create a performance-based grant program, and hold academic institutions responsible for unpaid student loans.
In the committee meeting to consider the bill, Democrats introduced 30 amendments to alter some fundamental aspects of the legislation.
Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Virginia) praised parts of Foxx's bill, "such as codifying Postsecondary Student Success Grants and eliminating interest capitalization and origination fees on student loans," but the panel's ranking Democrat objected to some provisions that he said would make it harder for people to go to college.
Rep. Kathy Manning (D-Michigan) offered an amendment to strike language from the bill repealing Biden administration regulations to protect student borrowers during changes in ownership of academic institutions.
Another Biden administration regulation the Foxx bill aims to repeal is the 90-10 rule, which requires for-profit universities to secure at least 10 percent of their funding from non-federal sources. Rep. Mark Takano (D-California) introduced an amendment to strike this section from the final bill but was rebuffed by the GOP majority.
Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minnesota) offered a motion to remove the bill's rescission of Biden's SAVE plan, but that motion was defeated.
"The new (SAVE) program created by the Biden administration… creates a generous IDR (income-driven repayment) plan that Republicans now want to strip away," Omar said.
Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-Michigan) unsuccessfully tried to amend the bill with language streamlining the process of finding on-campus accommodations for students with disabilities.
Bonamici's proposal is part of a group of bills unveiled Monday by Democratic members of the education panel referred to collectively as the Roadmap to College Student Success. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a congressional bill affecting college affordability and student loan policies, which directly pertains to higher education issues.

title: Caroline students sign apprenticeship agreements
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline students sign apprenticeship agreements

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Public Schools recently signed on to four youth apprenticeship agreements, three in the CCPS Technology Department and one in the Chesapeake Culinary Arts Center.Four students and their parents completed the paperwork necessary to finalize the apprenticeship agreement:
Evamarie Vargas Villacorta, North Caroline High School junior, and father Norman Vargas (CCAC)Dana Velasquez-Cifuentes, North Caroline High School junior, and father Ediberto Velazquez (Technology)Lawrence (Will) Johnson, North Caroline High School senior, and parents Billy and Roseann Johnson (Technology)Wilson Clough, Colonel Richardson High School junior, and his parents Michael and Amy Clough (Technology)
Supervisor of Technology Jason Wielgosz and CCPS Food Services Chef David Murray signed the employer portions of the agreement, and CCPS Youth Apprenticeship Coordinator Eric Cook signed on behalf of the CCPS Youth Apprenticeship Program.
"This is an exciting day for CCPS and a long time in the making," said Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons.
Simmons explained that former Assistant Superintendent Milton Nagel envisioned CCPS — the largest employer in Caroline County — engaging in youth apprenticeships, and he laid the groundwork for it to happen.
Simmons thanked Cook and school counselors for their diligence in bringing the program to fruition, and Wielgosz and Murray for working through the logistics for apprenticeships in their departments. He said it all came together with "the right opportunities with the right students at the right time."
CCPS's Director of College and Career Readiness Lindsey McCormick and school counselors Ann Ferkler, Jacqueline Holtzman and Jennifer Reed attended the meeting to congratulate and support their students.
The Maryland State Department of Education sent representatives Tracy Kyttle, director of apprenticeships and industry-recognized credentials; Jennifer Griffin, career programs and apprenticeship specialist; and Pamela Clay, career and technical education associate. Shay Lewis-Sisco, career coach from Dorchester County Public Schools also attended to learn more about the CCPS youth apprenticeship process.
More information about the Youth Apprenticeship Program may be found on the Caroline County Public Schools website. Local businesses interested in partnering with Youth Apprenticeship or students and parents interested in the program should contact Cook at cook.eric@ccpsstaff.org.
All event photos may be viewed on the Caroline Flickr page, www.flickr.com/photos/142694579@N05/

title: New Fellowship of Christian Athletes club unites and inspires students
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
New Fellowship of Christian Athletes club unites and inspires students

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 712
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As inspirational music plays, students filled the classroom."Get in here and eat donuts! What are you doing buddy? What's up pal?" Jeff Simmons welcomes everyone with his energetic and contagious excitement.
It's 7:30 a.m. on a Tuesday morning. School won't begin for more than an hour. What brings middle schoolers, teachers and community members out early before school?
For some students in Queen Anne and Talbot Counties, it's a new club called Fellowship of Christian Athletes. This club, or huddle, welcomes not only athletes but anyone who wants to come and make a difference.
Although FCA may be new to some local schools, it is well-known around the world. For over 60 years, FCA has had one mission — "unite your two passions, faith and athletics, to impact the world for Jesus Christ."
Founder Don McClanen started FCA after reading that 30 million American youth had no religious training. McClanen began posting his articles in the locker room and praying before games. Soon, he was dreaming of a way for well-known Christian athletes to advertise their faith on television and in magazines the way they advertised other household products. Currently, FCA is in 115 countries with over 20,000 huddle meetings occurring around the world.
At their first huddle, Centreville Middle students spent time together in fellowship.
The "Walk Out Faith'' huddle activity included scripture readings, a memory verse and relevant questions asking teens how they can grow their faith while also building the community around them.
Seventh Grade Social Studies teacher Thomas Hayman helps oversee the FCA huddle with other school staff. A former church youth director and a current Queen Anne's County Public Schools Teacher of the Year finalist, Hayman is dedicated to teaching and investing in his students. His loyalty doesn't go unnoticed, Hayman's students said he's told them he would even "take a bullet" to keep them safe.
Hayman said it was fate that allowed him to meet Simmons, a former CMS tutor, at the school and fate that put him in this position. Hayman said he is looking forward to the fellowship afforded by FCA "to get together, have fun and see what kind of positive change we can make."
Simmons is the area director of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes) for Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
He said he had not heard of FCA until a friend suggested he look into it. After research and attending some huddle meetings, he said he was "blown away by what they were doing, how they were doing it, and the impact it had.
In his new position, Simmons has to annually raise his entire budget. The success here is directly linked to the local community's involvement, Simmons said.
With all the huddles happening, there were still many middle and high schools in both Queen Anne's and Talbot counties that had no FCA presence and did not have the same opportunities.
In this monthly email update, Simmons wrote, "There are 9 schools (middle and high) between both counties that do not have any sort of FCA on their campuses."
With the generous support of the community, the 2024 FCA budget for Queen Anne's and Talbot counties was fully funded.
"Thanks to God's provision, coming in the form of generous one time donations and support from those who signed on as Monthly Partners, we reached the amount needed to support the program's budget for 2024" Simmons said.
"In order to establish FCA programming in the remaining schools, we need to fully fund our FCA budget with recurring donations," Simmons shared. "Securing our annual budget with recurring monthly support will allow us to start planning for the future of FCA on the Eastern Shore. This will allow us to not only provide resources and support to the huddles that are already up and running, but also to establish a FCA presence in the schools without one currently."
"Your support, whether it be in financial contributions, prayer and encouragement," Simmons continued, "has confirmed this community's commitment to see Jesus glorified and lives changed through this ministry, and I am so grateful that we all get to be part of it. God is working on the Shore through these coaches, students, and leaders and I know that the best is yet to come!"
If you would like more information or would like to volunteer, email Jeff Simmons at jsimmons@fca.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a new school-based club for students and teachers, focusing on its role in the classroom and community, which aligns most closely with the Education category, with Sports as a secondary theme.

title: Talbot Board of Education passes FY2025 budget
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Talbot Board of Education passes FY2025 budget

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The proposed Talbot County Public Schools fiscal year 2025 budget is headed to the County Council for final approval.At a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening, board members voted to approve the budget and send it to the Talbot County Council.
The proposed unrestricted operating budget is $79.9 million dollars. This is a nearly $7.9 million increase from fiscal year 2024.
TCPS Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones said that while this seems like a larger increase than recent years, the increase is meant to offset a decrease in federal funding.
"This unrestricted budget coupled with the decrease in all of our federal programs nets to a 3.4% increase," she said.
This means that the district is asking for a total of 3.4% more money than it received for fiscal year 2024.
TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district is losing $4.8 million in grant funding for fiscal year 2025.
TCPS Director of Communications Debbie Gardner said in an interview that the $4.8 million came from two COVID-19 related grants — the Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief Fund and the Maryland Leads grant.
The proposed capital budget for fiscal year 2025 is $12.1 million. Capital requests include the renovation and expansion of Chapel District Elementary School, the installation of a turf field at Easton High School, the replacement of auditorium lights at Easton High School, the installation of a basketball court at Easton Elementary School, an update to the stadium lighting at Easton High School and a playground replacement at St. Michaels Elementary School.
Next month, the proposed budget will be presented to the County Council. A public budget hearing, held by the County Council, is set for May.
Board President Emily Jackson thanked TCPS staff for "the huge lift" of preparing the budget.
"Go forth and get this passed," she said. "You can do it."

title: TCPS gives Blueprint updates
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
TCPS gives Blueprint updates

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Updates regarding the Blueprint for Maryland's Future were shared at a Talbot County Board of Education meeting Wednesday.The Blueprint is a plan, passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021, that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state through increasing education funding by $3.8 billion each year over the next 10 years
Helga Einhorn, Talbot County Public Schools assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction, gave updates at the meeting.
Einhorn said the Maryland State Department of Education has approved the College and Career Readiness Standard.
The approved standard — which determines whether students are mastering the standards necessary to prepare them for dual enrollment, advanced placement, post-secondary education and careers — offers two options.
First, students can be considered college and career ready if they have earned a high school grade point average of at least 3.0 and either earned an A, B or C in Algebra I or scored proficient or above on the Algebra I Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
The second way students can be considered college and career ready is if they score proficient or above on the English Language Arts 10 MCAP and Algebra I MCAP.
Einhorn said that if students do not meet the College and Career Readiness Standard, a team from the school will meet with that student and their family to develop a plan to get them on track.
Einhorn said this new standard will go into effect immediately. However, she said the interim standard will also remain in effect until July 1, 2025.
The interim standard states that students can be considered college and career ready if they achieve certain scores on either the Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers, the early fall MCAP or the spring MCAP for both English 10 and either Algebra I, Algebra II or Geometry.
Another update Einhorn gave at the meeting is that the district has hired Sharon Gaskins as a strategic facilitator to support the district's efforts with the Blueprint.
"(Gaskins) has over 25 years in education and really has been a change agent working with organizations to ensure that they meet their goals," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said the district was able hire Gaskins using grant funding through the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board.
Einhorn also gave an update on a report that the district will need to submit to the Accountability and Implementation Board and MSDE by March 15.
The report will detail the district's implementation of the Blueprint so far. Einhorn said this includes discussing any challenges the district might be facing with implementation.
This report is a way for the state to monitor that school districts are "able to transform" through reshaping and adapting new polices and practices that create a more equitable system, Einhorn said.
"I'm here tonight to assure you that we will meet that March 15 deadline," she said. "And I look forward to sharing some of the findings in that report." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Sharon Gaskins (Strategic Facilitator, Talbot County Public Schools)

title: Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools
author: THE CONVERSATION
content:
Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE CONVERSATION | Section: National 
 
 1063
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Built in 1910, James Elementary is a three-story brick school in Kansas City, Missouri's historic Northeast neighborhood, with a bright blue front door framed by a sand-colored stone arch adorned with a gargoyle.As bustling students and teachers negotiate a maze of gray stairs with worn wooden handrails, Marjorie Mayes, the school's principal, escorts a visitor across uneven blue tile floors on the ground floor to a classroom with exposed brick walls and pipes. Bubbling paint mars some walls, evidence of the water leaks spreading inside the aging building.
"It's living history," said Mayes during a mid-September tour of the building. "Not the kind of living history we want."
The district would like to tackle the $400 million in deferred maintenance needed to create a 21st century learning environment at its 35 schools — including James Elementary — but it can't. It doesn't have the money.
PROPERTY TAX REDIRECT
The lack of funds is a direct result of the property tax breaks that Kansas City lavishes on companies and developers that do business there. The program is supposed to bring in new jobs and business but instead has ended up draining civic coffers and starving schools. Between 2017 and 2023, the Kansas City school district lost $237.3 million through tax abatements.
Kansas City is hardly an anomaly. An estimated 95% of U.S. cities provide economic development tax incentives to woo corporate investors. The upshot is that billions have been diverted from large urban school districts and from a growing number of small suburban and rural districts. The impact is seen in districts as diverse as Chicago and Cleveland, Hillsboro, Oregon, and Storey County, Nevada.
The result? A 2021 review of 2,498 financial statements from school districts across 27 states revealed that, in 2019 alone, at least $2.4 billion was diverted to fund tax incentives. Yet that substantial figure still downplays the magnitude of the problem, because three-quarters of the 10,370 districts analyzed did not provide any information on tax abatement agreements.
Tax abatement programs have long been controversial, pitting states and communities against one another in beggar-thy-neighbor contests. Their economic value is also, at best, unclear: Studies show most companies would have made the same location decision without taxpayer subsidies. Meanwhile, schools make up the largest cost item in these communities, meaning they suffer most when companies are granted breaks in property taxes.
A three-month investigation by The Conversation and three scholars with expertise in economic development, tax laws and education policy shows that the cash drain from these programs is not equally shared by schools in the same communities. At the local level, tax abatements and exemptions often come at the cost of critical funding for school districts that students from low-income households and who are racial minorities.
In Missouri, for example, in 2022 nearly $1,700 per student was redirected from Kansas City public and charter schools, while between $500 and $900 was redirected from wealthier, whiter Northland schools on the north side of the river in Kansas City and in the suburbs beyond. Other studies have found similar demographic trends elsewhere, including New York state, South Carolina and Columbus, Ohio.
The funding gaps produced by abated money often force schools to delay needed maintenance, increase class sizes, lay off teachers and support staff and even close outright. Schools also struggle to update or replace outdated technology, books and other educational resources. And, amid a nationwide teacher shortage, schools under financial pressures sometimes turn to inexperienced teachers who are not fully certified or rely too heavily on recruits from overseas who have been given special visa status.
Lost funding also prevents teachers and staff, who often feed, clothe and otherwise go above and beyond to help students in need, from earning a living wage. All told, tax abatements can end up harming a community's value, with constant funding shortfalls creating a cycle of decline.
INCENTIVES AND PAYOFFS
Perversely, some of the largest beneficiaries of tax abatements are the politicians who publicly boast of handing out the breaks despite the harm to poorer communities. Incumbent governors have used the incentives as a means of taking credit for job creation, even when the jobs were coming anyway.
"We know that subsidies don't work," said Elizabeth Marcello, a doctoral lecturer at Hunter College who studies governmental planning and policy and the interactions between state and local governments. "But they are good political stories, and I think that's why politicians love them so much."
While some voters may celebrate abatements, parents can recognize the disparities between school districts that are created by the tax breaks. Fairleigh Jackson pointed out that her daughter's East Baton Rouge third grade class lacks access to playground equipment.
The class is attending school in a temporary building while their elementary school undergoes a two-year renovation.
The temporary site has some grass and a cement slab where kids can play, but no playground equipment, Jackson said. And parents needed to set up an Amazon wish list to purchase basic equipment such as balls, jump ropes and chalk for students to use. The district told parents there would be no playground equipment due to a lack of funds, then promised to install equipment, Jackson said, but months later, there is none.
Jackson said it's hard to complain when other schools in the district don't even have needed security measures in place. "When I think about playground equipment, I think that's a necessary piece of child development," Jackson said. "Do we even advocate for something that should be a daily part of our kids' experience when kids' safety isn't being funded?"
A young student in the East Baton Rouge district told the school board that money going to tax breaks for corporations could provide better internet access or be used to hire someone to pick up the glass and barbed wire in the playground. But at least they have a playground — Hayden Crockett, a seventh grader at Sherwood Middle Academic Magnet School, noted that his sister's elementary school lacked one.
"If it wasn't in the budget to fund playground equipment, how can it also be in the budget to give one of the most powerful corporations in the world a tax break?" Crockett said. "The math just ain't mathing."
This article was written by Christine Wen, Texas A&M University; Danielle McLean, The Conversation; Kevin Welner, University of Colorado Boulder; and Nathan Jensen, The University of Texas at Austin. The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts.

title: Anti-war protests, rises in antisemitism magnify challenges for free speech on college campuses
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Anti-war protests, rises in antisemitism magnify challenges for free speech on college campuses

 February 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 408
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The war in Gaza after Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel has birthed contentious protests on college campuses magnifying debates around free speech and how universities should handle ramped up and controversial rhetoric — including antisemitism.The debate can pitt students' and staff's free speech rights — especially at public universities — against safety and harassment concerns voiced by other students and employees.
"I think we forget that there is the possibility that even protected speech can create a hostile environment. I think that's important," said Shira Goodman, senior director of advocacy for the Anti-Defamation League, which has seen a rise in reports of antisemitism since Oct. 7.
Goodman said protests and events on campus can potentially run afoul of Title VI of the federal Civil Rights Act that protects students and others of "shared ancestry" and other protected classes from mistreatment and harassment at colleges and universities receiving federal financial aid and other government money.
The U.S. Department of Education is currently conducting Title VI shared ancestry investigations at more than 40 colleges — including Johns Hopkins University, Harvard University, University of Michigan, Montana State University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, University of South Florida and University of Wisconsin-Madison.
On the other side of the issue, Haley Gluhanich, program officer for campus rights advocacy for the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, has seen an increase in calls from students and others across the political spectrum about their First Amendment rights being restricted.
"We are seeing events being canceled. We are seeing student organizations being de-chartered. We are seeing students and faculty members getting disciplined for social media posts for some comments made in class," Gluhanich said.
Protests against the war include criticism of U.S. and President Joe Biden's military and other support for Israel.
Gluhanich and Jane Kirtley, a professor of media ethics and law at the University of Minnesota, said even "hate speech" enjoys First Amendment and protections as long as it doesn't cross the line into more direct and specific threats or incites violence.
Kirtley worries about government actors (including at public universities) as well as wealthy donors discouraging speech they don't like.
She said that comes with peril and potential blowback.
"Once we open the door to allowing the government to tell us what thoughts aren't acceptable, we run the risk that, in the future, ideas with which we agree could be suppressed, as well," she said.
For a more expansive story on this issue check out StarDem.com and our e-edition on Monday, Feb. 26. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses protests, free-speech debates, and Title VI investigations on college campuses, which are core issues within the education sector.

title: KCPS calendar approved with post Labor Day start
author: Staff Writer
content:
KCPS calendar approved with post Labor Day start

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Kent County Board of Education has approved the calendar for the 2024-25 school year.As required by the State of Maryland, the approved calendar includes 180 instruction days for students. Two inclement weather days are built into the calendar.
The 2024-25 school year will begin with a staggered start.
Students in first through sixth grades and ninth-graders will begin school Tuesday, Sept. 3, the day after Labor Day. The first day for students in 10th, 11th and 12th grades is Wednesday, Sept. 4. Pre-kindergartners and kindergartners start school Thursday, Sept. 5.
Longer breaks during the year are Thanksgiving, Nov. 27 through Dec. 1; winter break, Dec. 21 through Jan. 1; and spring break April 17 to April 21.
Additional observed holidays are Martin Luther King Day Monday, Jan. 20; Presidents Day Monday, Feb. 17; and Memorial Day, Monday, May 26.
There are half days and days off in the calendar for staff professional development.
The last day of school is Thursday, June 12. That will be a half day for students.
The full 2024-25 calendar is available for view and download at kent.k12.md.us.
The calendar was developed with input from a committee led by Dan Hushion, supervisor of human resources, and comprising Kent County Public Schools staff and parents.
Staff and community input was sought through two online surveys throughout the development process.
Two drafts calendars were presented to the Board of Education at its meeting Feb. 12, both with post-Labor Day starts.
Survey results showed that of the 327 survey respondents, 75% preferred the calendar that ultimately received the Board of Education's unanimous approval during a meeting Feb. 12.
The other draft, which received 25% of the votes, had longer breaks throughout the school year with last day of school being Friday, June 20.

title: School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar
author: Connie Connolly
content:
School board adopts 2024-2025 calendar

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County students will be heading back to school before Labor Day this year.Offered two alternatives — a pre- or post-Labor Day start — the five-member Board of Education voted unanimously Feb. 6 to approve the pre-Labor Day calendar for the 2024-2025 school year.
English, Spanish and Haitian Creole translations of the calendar are posted on the Caroline County Public Schools website.
The school year start date is Wednesday, Aug. 28.
CCPS Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons presented the two calendars, along with results of a survey distributed to parents, teachers and staff.
While the current school year calendar began after Labor Day, the school board considered factors that mitigated against the later start, including the presidential election day, which necessitates closing schools Tuesday, Nov. 5, and Christmas falling on a Wednesday.
Fall sports practices will begin Aug. 14. Winter break will begin Dec. 20.
The calendar committee emailed a link to the survey Jan. 12 to over 5,400 parents, guardians and all CCPS staff members. A reminder email was sent Jan. 22, and the survey was closed Jan. 26. Some community members provided feedback, as well.
Although 75% of the 3,500 parents and guardians who responded favored a post-Labor Day start, 696 staff respondents, or 70% preferred a pre-Labor Day start.
Before reviewing the feedback, Simmons cautioned the school board, saying, "No matter what decision you make, you're going to make people upset, period. There is no perfect calendar, period."
Board member and retired Caroline County teacher Donna DiGiacomo favored the earlier start.
"So, one calendar starts Aug 28; the other starts Sept. 3, but the end date is just one day difference," DiGiacomo said. The adopted calendar gets "students in a routine quicker, and you have a shorter week when you start — you have three days, so everybody's not dead by Friday."
She said a 4-day first day of school "doesn't sound like a lot, but it's a lot."
Winter break begins with a half-day Friday, Dec. 20, and students returning to school Jan. 7.
"A hard shutdown over winter break for two solid weeks" would result in reduced heating costs and "significant savings" during "the hardest budget year we're going to have," Simmons said.
The post-Labor Day calendar would have had students returning Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025.
"This might not be a popular thing to say, but the reality is not a whole lot is going to get done on that Thursday and Friday," DiGiacomo said.
Other factors influencing the pre-Labor Day start were academic quarter dates and required parent-teacher conferences, which "we talked about ad nauseum," Simmons said.
Calling the process "wonky" and comparing it to a game of dominoes, Simmons explained the factors that prompted the calendar committee to go through "seven or eight drafts to get down to the two that made the most sense."
For example, the first quarter parent-teacher conference day will occur Nov. 5, even though it's election day, because the first quarter ends Nov. 8 and the conference day "has to fall before the first report card goes out, before grades are secured," Simmons said.
The adopted calendar has four inclement weather days built in. If they are not used, they come off the calendar.
State law, teacher contracts, mandatory conferences, state testing days, a set number of half-days, a mid-year transition day all dictate certain days off. Once all of the days off are built in, "it becomes a game of counting to 90 twice" to achieve a state-mandated 180-day school year, Simmons said.
DiGiacomo recommended surveying students next year and considering staggered starts for sixth grade and ninth grade students as they change schools.
"The pluses of draft two are just not as many as the pluses in draft one," said Rick Barton, president of the school board.
Although he liked "the idea of a longer break," school board Vice President Mark Jones was ambivalent.
"I honestly don't like either one of them, really," he said.
That ambivalence was reflected in the overall survey results, with 54% of all respondents preferring a post-Labor Day start and 46% going with the pre-Labor Day calendar.
Anticipating mixed reactions from the public and staff as well, Jones asked, "When do we want to hear complaints? Do we want to hear them right before the first day of school, or do we want to hear them after Christmas break? I think I'd probably rather hear them at the beginning of the year and get it out of the way."
To view the 2024-2025 CCPS school year calendar, visit www.carolineschools.org/page/ccps-school-calendar. The calendars are available in English, Spanish and Haitian Creole. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a school board decision about the academic calendar, which directly concerns the education system.

title: Thompson voted interim DCPS superintendent
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Thompson voted interim DCPS superintendent

 February 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education voted to appoint Jymil Thompson as interim superintendent of Dorchester County Public Schools at a Board meeting Thursday.Thompson, who has been assistant superintendent since September, will serve the final months of David Bromwell's term as superintendent.
"I'm humbled and I'm appreciative and I'm gracious that you have afforded me this opportunity," Thompson, who led the Board meeting Thursday, said. "I don't take this lightly, and I want to make sure that I do the best job that I can do."
Thompson stressed that this is not a one-person job.
"I need the whole district to help," he said. "I need the whole district to collaborate with each other."
Thompson — who came to Dorchester County in 2017, serving as assistant principal and then principal at Mace's Lane Middle School until 2020 — called Dorchester County "a diamond in the rough," saying that it will take a village to get the district moving in the right direction.
"Not saying that we aren't, and (that) we haven't made some progress," he said. "But I still think we've got some ways to go in order to make sure that we move from 23rd to the top-tier school district in Maryland."
On Feb. 16, the Board of Education announced that Bromwell would not be seeking reappointment when his term ends on June 30. A week later, on Wednesday, Feb. 21, the Board announced that Bromwell would be stepping down from his position, effective March 1.
Bromwell was officially appointed as superintendent in 2020 with a four year term. Before that, he served as interim superintendent for the district. In his time at DCPS, he has also served as a teacher in the district and as the principal of Cambridge-South Dorchester High School.
According to the Feb. 21 statement from the Board of Education, the decision for Bromwell to step down in March was "mutually decided" by him and the Board. In the Feb. 16 statement, the Board expressed gratitude to Bromwell for his years of service to DCPS.
Valerie Goff, DCPS communication and community outreach specialist, said Bromwell, who was not present at the Board meeting Thursday, had no comments at this time.
At the meeting, Board Vice President Susan Morgan acknowledged that the district is experiencing change "once again."
"But I do trust in our teachers, our administrators, our directors and, now, our interim superintendent, to keep us moving forward," she said. "Through everything we as a Board do, we always keep in the front of our minds what's best for all the children that we serve."
Board Member Chris Wheedleton said the search for the district's next leader can't happen without "recognizing the value of somebody who has given close to 40 years of service to the district."
"I want to thank Mr. Bromwell for his service and for what he has done," Wheedleton said.
Earlier in the meeting, Milton Nagel and Bill Middleton from the Maryland Association of Boards of Education presented on what to keep in mind when conducting a superintendent search.
Nagel told the Board that although it was not their reason for attending the meeting, MABE does conduct superintendent searches for its member districts.
"If the Board so desires to engage in that conversation about potentially having MABE do a search, we can certainly facilitate that," he said.
In a statement released later that night, the Board said it will begin the search for a new superintendent to take office July 1.
Toward the end of his remarks at the meeting Thursday, Thompson, who is also a board member of the Talbot County Board of Education, told the public that they will get mad at him.
"But I want you to also understand this — and I mean this from the bottom of my heart — that I'm always going to make the best decisions that I think are right for kids," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Responsible Fathers Initiative empowers, strengthens men
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Responsible Fathers Initiative empowers, strengthens men

 February 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 1210
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In late 2021, Ja'Shaun Wilson had a son on the way.At the time, Wilson, now 31, was incarcerated at the Talbot County Detention Center.
Already thinking ahead, he recalled wanting to try to figure out how to adapt to being a first-time father before he was released.
That's when he decided to participate in Inside Out Dad, a Responsible Fathers Initiative group held inside the jail.
"... I never really had any strong role models," he said. "So I just figured, what could it hurt by taking the class?"
To Wilson's surprise, the group's curriculum did more than just talk about fatherhood — it prompted him to reflect on himself more deeply and gave him the tools he needed to move forward when he reentered the community, ready to meet his son and be the role model he didn't have himself.
RESPONSIBLE FATHERSFounded by Corey Pack in 2019, the Responsible Fathers Initiative is a local nonprofit committed to helping enlighten men to the impact fathers have on a family and better prepare them for the duties and responsibilities of fatherhood.
The curriculum it uses was developed by the National Fatherhood Initiative, a broader nonprofit that offers evidence-based fatherhood programs, resources, training and more in an effort to increase fathers' involvement.
Inspiration for the local initiative began when Pack was asked to help out with an existing fathers' group in the detention center in 2019.
Pack is no stranger to fatherhood programming. In the mid-2000s, he headed a group in Cambridge for several years before turning his attention to local government, serving on the Talbot County Council for 15 years.
But still, a "burning desire" to get back into it lingered, he said, and his second chance came at just the right time.
"I think God knew my heart. He knew this was something I really wanted to get back into doing," he said.
The data behind a father's impact on a family was a motivator for Pack.
Pack said children born in a household without a responsible father are more likely to live in poverty, suffer from abuse or neglect, drop out of school, become involved with drugs and alcohol, and be involved with the criminal justice system.
"...The numbers are telling us (that) when we boil it all down, between race and region and religion and culture, it comes back to the family," he said. "When the family unit starts to crumble apart, then you see these other ills pop up in our society."
Pack started facilitating in-person groups for men in the detention center in 2019 and initiated a women's group, too, though the pandemic's arrival in 2020 hampered some progress.
With the help of Talbot County's IT department and the Department of Social Services, Pack pivoted into running all-virtual classes for men and women at the detention center throughout the year — a feat no other county in the state was able to do, he said.
Since then, the initiative has grown. Now, it includes three in-person groups inside the detention center, two for men and one for women, along with two community-based men's groups and two teen dads' groups, both of which are held in Easton and Cambridge.
Though the curriculums provided by the national initiative help with the lessons learned in groups, the Responsible Fathers Initiative leans on community partners to flesh out its offerings even more.
The Neighborhood Service Center in Easton, Delmarva Community Services, YMCA of the Chesapeake, the Talbot County Department of Social Services, the St. Michaels Community Center and Washington College, among others, are just some of those key partnerships.
"It would not work, cannot work, without the partnerships, without that synergy," Pack said. "The sum is greater than its parts."
HELP ON OUTSIDEThose partnerships with other community organizations and county agencies play a significant role in helping the Responsible Fathers Initiative's mission.
The fatherhood piece of the initiative aligned well with the Neighborhood Service Center's existing 2Gen program, which provides resources to support the whole family in an effort to increase self-sufficiency and break generational poverty cycles, said Dawn Phillips, who serves as the program's case manager and the center's Responsible Fathers Initiative coordinator.
The initiative's community group for fathers operates at the center's location on Port Street in Easton and provides meals and wraparound services to participants, including help with housing, transportation, food and financial literacy.
To Phillips, the initiative has been a "major contribution" in working to beat generational poverty cycles.
"The role of the father in the household is huge," she said.
Regardless of whether fathers are living with their families, the center being able to help men with better communication, improve self-esteem and support education and employment efforts can empower participants and break the cycle.
To Wilson, those supports were invaluable — he received help with enrolling his son in day care and obtaining a voucher for it, he said.
LISTENING, LEARNING, GROWINGWith multiple meetings running weekly both inside and outside of the detention center, the opportunities for group participants to grow in knowledge of themselves and the commitments and responsibilities associated with fatherhood are ample.
The curriculums in the detention center and in the community are similar, with focuses placed on self-awareness, self-care, fathering skills, parenting skills and relationship skills.
To Pack, the group serves as a supportive, judgment-free zone — a safe space where time is given to listen and be heard.
"... When they can come together in a group and they feel that they have some comfort there, they're being respected, they're not being judged, they're not being told that they're a deadbeat father or that they're worthless or they're not this or that, but allowed to be heard — I think that gives them the empowerment to come back," he said.
While in the detention center, Wilson always looked forward to going to the group, he said.
He recalled being prompted with "I am" statements, which are commonly used to provide affirmations and challenge negative self-perceived thoughts.
"I had the basis of 'I am Black,' 'I am a man,' but it made me dig deep for the next go around," he said. "I had stronger responses because it really made me think about how I view myself or wanted to view myself."
Being in the group with other men who openly shared their failures and strengths in being a father, along with how it affected them before and during their incarceration, provided a variety of viewpoints for Wilson to consider.
Holding himself accountable, learning the ins and outs of communication, body language and tone through the initiative's curriculum proved to be some of the key lessons Wilson still remembers today. Those lessons were especially beneficial with navigating co-parenting and having respect for each other, he said.
That work continued when he joined the men's group held in the community, too.
And although his son is just shy of 2 years old, Wilson knows he wants to be a role model — one who wants to make sure his son knows that it's OK to cry.
"... A lot of that is stigmatized, and I want him to know it's OK to show your emotions basically, because that's what a lot of us are taught not to do," he said. "I just want to let him know that it's OK to have emotions and to show them, and the proper ways to deal with them — that's the type of stuff I'd like to instill in him." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fatherhood program that provides curriculum, training, and educational resources to incarcerated men and the community, making education the most fitting category.

Dawn Phillips (Program Case Manager, Neighborhood Service Center)

title: Early learners meet with success at Kinder Connection
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Early learners meet with success at Kinder Connection

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — Kinder Connection, a licensed child care home in Betterton, not only has a strong community involvement, but its quick success is paving the way to expand its current impact.Owners Elizabeth and James Greenwell said, "We recognize that early childhood is the most important time for brain development and do our best to give lots of opportunities to learn and play. We are a family childcare home, not a center."
They opened just last summer. But over the years, Elizabeth has taught in a variety of childcare centers, in public and private schools, and at the university level.
"It was important to us to develop a program that included neurodivergent children and was based on best practice and research-informed play-based learning," she said. "We recognized that the most impact on learning happens in early childhood and sought to develop a program that combined community resources, learning experiences outside the classroom, and sensory-rich play."
A neuro-affirming, play-based, bilingual family child care located in Betterton, they are an MSDE-approved ASPIRE Pre-K and participate in the MD EXCELS and credentialing programs. With an extensive background in special education, their passion is providing quality care to diverse learners and serving families in their community.
Beyond the home, Kinder Connection participates in many field trips for not just the children but for the whole family.
"Since we have been open, we have taken children to Tuckahoe State Park hiking, the Delaware Children's Museum, the Garfield theater twice, the Galena Fire Department, the Sultana Foundation twice, Bespoke Chocolate, Talbot County Ice Rink to go ice skating, to a magic show, to library concerts and events, and to almost every park in the area," Elizabeth said.
Families pay a set field trip/holiday fee each week, and Kinder Connection coordinates everything. They also have had a variety of guest speakers come and talk to the children.
In less than a year, Kinder Connection is already making plans to expand.
"We are planning to expand our home by adding almost 600 square feet," Elizabeth said. "This will allow us the already licensed Kinder Connection to convert to a designated Large Family Childcare and separate the two classrooms from their home. The facility is currently licensed for eight children, and the addition will allow them to serve 12 children. The next step is finding funding for the addition and a large van or small bus so that will make weekly field trips easier."
With a current waiting list for future spots, children are accepted through the ASPIRE program, which provides grant funding through MSDE for free tuition for qualifying families of children ages 3 to 5. Kinder Connection also accepts Child Care Scholarships for low-income working families.
"We strive to have our program look like our community — we value having a variety of cultures, races, abilities, and socio-economic status represented," Elizabeth said.
In addition to school-year care, Kinder Connection runs a summer camp as well. "We run a 6-week summer camp where we enjoy immersing ourselves in art, music, and water play and take several field trips," she said.
Parents William Machande and Sarah Kalb said, "Kinder Connection has been truly extraordinary for our son's growth and development. We are so fortunate to have found Ellie and Jamie. They provide a comfortable, fun and productive environment for the children. They go above and beyond, and then some."
"I love that my three year old learns beyond the four walls of a room and spends a lot of time outside, learning in exciting and innovative ways. He's always excited to share his day," said Robert and Dana Smith. "Both Ellie and Jamie have included the families on fun field trips and in holiday fun. The Christmas program was such a highlight."
For more information, visit kinderconnection.org/. There is an upcoming open house for families of children ages 1 to 5 that are interested in fall care at 6 p.m. Monday, March 11. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Teaching & Transformation: Semester in the Chesapeake Classroom'
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Teaching & Transformation: Semester in the Chesapeake Classroom'

 March 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 495
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Washington College's Center for Environment and Society (CES) announces the grand opening of MuSE: A Community Museum, in downtown Chestertown. The space, located at 210 S. Cross Street, will host a number of rotating exhibits highlighting Washington College teaching, experiential learning, and research with opportunities for sharing, learning, and dialogue in a community space.Each exhibit will be informational, interactive, and highly visual, creating a dynamic space for learning and sharing for the Eastern Shore community.
"Facilitating shared knowledge and understanding to drive action for conservation and community resilience is at the core of our mission," said Valerie Imbruce, director of Washington College's Center for Environment and Society. "This new off-campus space will aid us in creating opportunities for active collaboration for both teaching and learning for our Washington College community, community organizations, regional K-12 educators, students, and interested visitors. We're excited to welcome the community into this new, innovative, and collaborative space."
Last fall, the Digital Scholarship in Museum Partnerships Project was the first collaborative effort featured in the Cross Street space, which hosted a collection of exhibits created by students from five museums in Kent County — Sumner Hall, The Waterman's Museum, The Worton Point Schoolhouse, Betterton Heritage Museum, and Kent Museum. With the goal of preserving and providing greater access to the local histories of our community, the exhibition highlighted the mission of the space by providing digitized looks into each museum, viewable through virtual reality with 360-degree virtual tours, digitized collections, oral history interviews, and interactive panels.
Opening on March 1, the first exhibit in the new, updated, and enhanced space will be "Teaching & Transformation: Semester in the Chesapeake Classroom." It will showcase the nature and culture of the Chesapeake Bay region through the final projects created by Washington College's Chesapeake Semester students. Their hand-drawn maps, visual journals, and other writing and visual arts will provide visitors a sense of the unique Chesapeake ecosystem, analyze solutions to environmental problems, and explore the nexus between science, policy, and people's everyday lives in the region.
"The Chesapeake Semester is such a unique opportunity afforded to Washington College by our location here on the historically, culturally, and ecologically rich Eastern Shore," said Sara Clarke-De Reza, education department chair and director of the museum, field, and community education minor. "This exhibit showcases our students' intensive interdisciplinary study of the Chesapeake Bay, and their comparative study in watershed communities in northern Belize. The students' hope for this exhibit is that it will highlight the lessons learned through classroom and field-based experiences across the semester in a way that expands visitors' understanding of the human and social dimensions of environmental issues in our region."
When exhibits are installed, MuSE will be open on First Fridays from 4:30-7 p.m. and on Saturdays from 8 a.m. to noon during the Chestertown Farmers Market. Requests for group showings will also be available. "Teaching & Transformation: Semester in the Chesapeake Classroom" will remain open through August 2024. For more information visit Laura Chamberlin at lchamberlin2@washcoll.edu. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Sara Clarke-De Reza (Education Department Chair and Director of Museum, Field, and Community Education Minor, Washington College)

title: Books rife with sexual content
author: Staff Writer
content:
Books rife with sexual content

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 384
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I first heard about the "Freedom to Read" Act, Maryland SB 0738, I was reminded of the words of one of our founders, John Adams : "Liberty cannot be preserved without a general knowledge among the people, who have a right … and a desire to know; but besides this, they have a right, an indisputable, unalienable, indefeasible, divine right to that most dreaded and envied kind of knowledge, I mean of the characters and conduct of their rulers." (A Dissertation on the Canon and Feudal Law, 1765)So when I heard of the "Freedom to Read" Act, I wondered what banned books were suddenly going to be made available to the students of Maryland. I assumed there must be some politically controversial books from the Cold War Era that had been suppressed.
It was disappointing when I discovered that the books which Maryland students are being encouraged to read are rife with graphic sexual content, ones which most parents deem inappropriate for their children. Last fall, parents in Carroll County questioned why books with graphic sexual imagery were being made available to children without parental knowledge or consent.
One is the autobiography of Jaycee Dugard, who was kidnapped and used as a sex-slave in a cellar for years. I have read Dugard's "A Stolen Life: A Memoir;" it as a story of heroism but only for mature readers since it is about a kidnapping and child rape. It does not belong in a school.
An article in the Easton Gazette (Feb. 2, 2024) provides details about the "banned" books which SB 0738 is intended to liberate. To quote: "These books have pornographic images or descriptions, the likes of which you could find in Penthouse magazine. The Carroll County Board considered the opinions of parents with children as young as elementary school who complained that these books demonstrating various types of sex such as oral, vaginal, anal, etc. were accessible to students. Some of the books portrayed graphic rape scenes or sexual experimentation in the story lines that were not appropriate for any minor child."
So when Maryland schools are struggling to achieve basic literacy, how is it helpful to have students' minds filled with images of rape, etc? Why are the wishes of parents ignored and disrespected? What is the agenda?
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Talbot County Republican Central Committee
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state legislative act affecting school curricula and parental concerns about book content, which directly relates to education policy and school reading material.

title: Dyer achieves Eagle Scout
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Dyer achieves Eagle Scout

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A crowd of family, politicians, civic leaders and Boy Scouts assembled in the Scout House on St. Mary's Square to present the Eagle Scout Badge to Vincent Thomas Dyer Sunday.Multiple candles were lit to commemorate different aspects of his journey that started when he was 5. This is the highest honor a Scout can achieve and only about four in 100 Scouts reach it.
Dyer's sash had 26 merit badges on it, and his final project was raising $2,000 to raise a flag pole honoring veterans in Cordova. Of course, this achievment took hours of input from his family, his Troop 741 leaders and his fellow Scouts.
"It is now time to formally present you with Scouting's highest badge of accomplishment. The symbol of your success is the Eagle Scout badge and neckerchief, which will now be presented by your parents," Scoutmaster Brendan Beers said.
One of the most touching moments was when his parents, Paul and Kimberly, attached the Eagle Scout pin. He then attached pins on them for being a supportive Eagle Scout mom and dad.
Vincent's brother Paul Jr., also an Eagle Scout, said, "What does the rank of Eagle Scout represent? To me it represents saying you are going to do something and then doing it. It represents goals realized, focus and strength of character. When the pressure is on and others would run around and panic, the Eagle Scout stays calm, cool and collected in the face of atrocity."
Another person who was there to guide and bear witness is Steve Bealefeld, assistant scoutmaster.
He said, "He is a hard-working young man who has always had his head on straight."
Vincent's father listed many of the places the Scout troop went to go camping like the C & O Canal, Dorchester County and Tennessee. The biggest test was a 10-day hike at Philmont in New Mexico.
There was a testament to Vincent's leadership in the field. He was said to be an excellent cook with a Dutch oven. He can make peach cobbler and chicken pot pie.
"When he was in the lead, you were never going in the wrong direction. In the spartan wilds of Philmont, this was no small feat. Vincent is an excellent navigator. Vincent's attitude was equally as unflagging as his physical stamina. There is a deep keeled steadiness to his emotional thermostat," scout leader JoRoy Lizewski said.
Then it was time for the politicians to offer large citations. President of Town of St. Michael's Commission David Breimhurst, Del. Tom Hutchison (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), community liaison to Andy Harris Mike Detmer and Maryland state Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) all spoke briefly. Vincent was given the United States flag and the Maryland Flag.
Vincent had the last word.
"I am so proud. I am happy that all my friends from 190 and 741 were here to celebrate this event with me, because it has been a long time coming. It is a bittersweet moment. I am glad I got Eagle Scout, but I will miss Scouting as a whole," Vincent said.
He tentatively has plans to attend University of Maryland at College Park in the fall. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a youth achievement (Eagle Scout) and community involvement in a scouting ceremony, which aligns most closely with youth development and educational activities rather than sports, health, or government policy.

title: Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union provides community, support
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union provides community, support

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Zulema Delacruz Martinez was a second-year student at Chesapeake College when LaSella Hall, director of diversity, equity and inclusion for Chesapeake College, approached her about starting a student-led union for the school's Latino community.Together, they started the Hispanic/Latino Student Union and have assisted in retention for the growing Latino student population at Chesapeake College.
The Hispanic/Latino Student Union hosted a night in late February to assist community members who were having trouble filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, commonly called FAFSA.
This form assists current and prospective college students to determine their eligibility for student financial aid.
Delacruz Martinez said that more than 90 percent of attendees applied for Chesapeake College. She assisted families from all age groups, including grandparents with limited knowledge of the internet.
For many first-generation immigrant families, there is a caution with filling out FAFSA, especially if the student's parents are undocumented, Delacruz Martinez said.
According to the federal student aid website, a parent's or spouse's citizenship status doesn't affect a student's ability to complete the FAFSA form.
Delacruz Martinez said she hopes to spread the message that higher education is reachable for immigrant families.
"I want to serve my community," Delacruz Martinez said. "I want to make sure that students and families are being taken care of and that they have the resources to know what to do. Because I went through that, I didn't have anyone to do that for me, and I was terrified. I was like, 'OK, let me make sure people don't go through that the same way I did.'"
LaSella Hall said he believes in the power of what student-led projects can do. He even developed his own method based on it.
The "Hall Method" focuses on empowering students, believing in their potential and guiding them toward success rather than just telling them what they can't do.
Hall said that if people don't understand where students are coming from or what they are going through, then telling them to succeed means nothing.
He recalls working with students in Atlanta who had parents addicted to drugs or students who had their lights turned off for three days. Hall said asking students to succeed academically was unreasonable when they had more significant issues they were worried about.
The Hall Method emphasizes having hard conversations, advocating for student voices at decision-making tables and leaving leadership of specific communities and cultures to members of those communities. Because of this method, Hall pushed hard to create the Hispanic/Latino Student Union.
"Student organizations really should be about advocacy and advancing the voice of those students," Hall said. "It should be about tackling really important issues that the students feel passionate about."
Delacruz Martinez notes that leading the Cinco de Mayo event made her work feel real and impactful to her school. Hall approached Delacruz Martinez when their organization was new, and all members were incredibly busy with school.
They met with members who didn't think they should do anything for the holiday because they didn't have the time, but Hall pushed Delacruz Martinez and other leaders to figure something out.
Delacruz Martinez got to work. She made phone calls, did research and was able to take 10 students in a rented van to celebrate Cinco de Mayo at a local Hispanic restaurant. It made Delacruz Martinez feel accomplished.
She said she wants to run her own nonprofit and, more than anything, positively impact her community.
"I think coming from a minority community and coming from a single-parent household, there's a lot of challenges," Delacruz Martinez said. "There were a lot of things I did not know, but the same with my community. I don't know if it's just resilience. I don't know if I'm just stubborn. But I think it's when you give us the opportunities, we'll take them on." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a college‑level student organization that helps Latino students navigate FAFSA and campus resources, which is primarily an educational initiative, while also addressing race and diversity issues.
