Zulema Delacruz Martinez (Chesapeake College Student)

title: The Navy's 'best kept secret'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content:
The Navy's 'best kept secret'

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 815
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — "Do your best. Remember to breathe. Remember why you are here.''On Saturday, March 2, this encouragement echoed through an almost silent room at the Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 7464 in Grasonville during the annual inspection for the Maryland Division of the U.S. Naval Sea Cadet Corps. While many 10 to 18 year olds relax at home on a rainy Saturday morning, 21 Sea Cadets and eight League Cadets stood at attention.
Their uniforms carefully pressed and prepared, shoes shined and haircuts and hairstyles well groomed according to the set regulations. They were prepared and ready for their yearly inspection.
The purpose of annual inspection is to prepare for combat. Although these young men and women are not going into combat, they are preparing to be productive citizens now while also preparing to be future leaders who positively impact the world around them.
Many do not know about this extraordinary program. But, some call it "the Navy's best kept secret."
Established in 1958 by the Secretary of the Navy, the U.S. Naval Sea Cadet Corps are comprised of young men and women aged 10 through 18.
There are two programs within Sea Cadets, the Navy League Cadet Corps for middle school students aged 10 to 13, and the Naval Sea Cadet Corps for ages 13 through the end of high school.
Through the program, values of discipline, accountability and teamwork are instilled, giving cadets a chance to step outside of their comfort zones and helping them thrive.
Today, the corps has 380 units and 9,000 enrolled. Although this program is supported by both the U.S. Navy and Coast Guard, the goal is not to recruit for the military but to create respectable citizens in life — no matter what their career path may be.
Lt. Maryjoe Phillips, Sea Cadet Corps supply, finance and division officer, explains that she started with this program about 10 years ago as a "drop off mom," when she would drop her daughter off to the Sea Cadet program.
Not knowing much about the Sea Cadet program, Phillips was recruited by the master chief to help.
Ten years later, she is one of the driving forces behind this Sea Cadet unit.
"The program means a lot because we are turning out really great young men and women that are going to be beneficial to our society," Phillips said. "We are raising patriots, which this country needs so badly."
She called the program "a breath of fresh air."
"With some of the turmoil going on in the world, I have seen these Cadets do some really amazing things," Phillips said. "I get so proud of them even though they are not children. I'm amazed at what can be done."
Starting with only five cadets in 2018, the program has grown to 29 cadets and is still growing.
In April 2018, the Maryland Unit formed and was commissioned in May 2022. Before this unit formed, many parents drove their children over the bridge to Annapolis for drills and training.
Kent Island High School senior, Evan Newcomer, explained how he started his Sea Cadet training as a League Cadet in Annapolis at age 10. His parents said there were many families traveling back and forth at that time.
Newcomer's parents asked to bring this program to Maryland's Eastern Shore. He now leads as a Naval Sea Cadet Corps petty officer second class.
His experience as a League Cadet and Sea Cadet has helped grow him into the leader he is now.
"I always had a dream of serving," Newcomer said, "and I knew the military was always appealing to me. And the whole mission of all the branches was something that kind of shined to me. My uncle was a Naval Academy Grad. He inspired me to pursue that course as well as the other, older cadets in the program. (They) impressed me and made me want to pursue that dream."
After Saturday's inspection finished, the unit and their families celebrated Evan's acceptance to West Point as a life sciences major studying pre-med.
Cadets and families come from Centreville, Easton, St. Michaels, Prince Frederick and everywhere in between, as the Maryland unit is the only unit on Maryland's Eastern Shore.
Interested young persons ages 10-17 can join a drill weekend to learn more about the program. The unit is looking for adults that can give trainings (gun safety, medical and public safety) or help develop a new marksmanship program. Any interested adult volunteers that could help the program run smoothly or hold a position are welcome to contact Lt. Maryjoe Phillips at pti00803@ gmail.com or visit seacadets.org

Any interested adult volunteers that could help the program run smoothly or hold a position are welcome to contact Lt. Maryjoe Phillips at pti00803@gmail.com or visit seacadets.org.

title: Student building projects impress judges
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Student building projects impress judges

 March 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A loud cheer arose as the team from Wicomico County Public Schools was announced as the gold cup winner in the architecture, construction and engineering competition held this week at Sts. Peter and Paul High School.The team's project was a plan for a Salisbury Riverfront Community Center and included site logistics, design, cost estimates and timelines to pitch their vision for a center on the Wicomico River.
"The judges were blown away by the projects," Judge James Cook said. "The industry is alive and well given what we have seen tonight."
What the judges saw were project proposals by four teams. In addition to the Wicomico County team, Easton, Sts. Peter and Paul, and St. Michaels high schools competed for the gold cup and scholarships.
This was the 20th annual competition for ACE Mentors, a group of professionals representing the architecture, construction and engineering industries.
Each team took the stage and pitched the case for their projects with slideshows.
The winning Wicomico project included landscape architecture and community art. The team presented the codes they would have to satisfy to create their building.
Andrea Suk, Wicomico county coordinator, was thrilled with her students' win.
"We have 15 full time students," she said. "These students are very interested in either architecture, construction or engineering."
The team worked with professional mentors in each of the ACE fields, mentors who volunteered their time to work with students.
"They give up their time to go into the schools and teach students about each of those fields and how they work together to create all the wonderful buildings and structures around us," Suk said.
The event was sponsored in part by the late Charles H. Thornton, a renowned structural engineer, educator and mentor who died in December. There were 26 other sponsors at different levels. The named scholarships were Easton Utilities, DBF/ACE Gerald Friedel Legacy, Lane Engineering, Griffith Family and CT Darnell Construction.
The platinum sponsors were the Whiting-Turner Contracting Co. and Willow Construction.
The St. Michaels High School project proposed a harbor floodgate to address global warming and the resulting flooding in town. The students proposed building a concrete wall with a 40-foot gate to let boats pass. The wall would go across the mouth of the harbor facing the Miles River.
Easton High students proposed a tourist-friendly oyster hatchery called Project Clarity in Easton Point Park. Part of their plan was to bring oysters back to that part of Easton Point.
The last project, presented by the Sts. Peter and Paul team, proposed building a castle in Wye Mills near the intersection of U.S. Route 50 and state Route 404. The castle would host jousting and mixed martial arts programming. The colossal structure was estimated to cost more than $80 million to build.
"Our project is 'The Castle,'" said Peter Anderson, a senior at Saints Peter and Paul. "I really wanted to push the boundaries of ACE and break the mold and push the boundaries. I thought a castle would be big, bold and abrasive."
The presentations were reviewed by three judges — James Cook, vice president and project manager at Rauch; Aaron Goller, a civil engineer at Easton Utilities; and Rick VanEmburgh, engineer for the Town of Easton.
Local engineer Sean Callahan is the president of Lane Engineering and a mentor in the ACE program.
"ACE mentors does a tremendous job of bringing young folk up and showing them the ropes," Callahan said. "It is great to see young folks get excited, and that is a part of what this is."
Another mentor working with students is Rebecca Saduk, a civil engineer for Easton Utilities.
"I wish I had had a program like ACE, and that is why I am so passionate about being a mentor," she said. "These kids are learning real life work habits and how to work as a team."

title: No one knows how to pay for Maryland's massive education reform
author: CAPITAL NEWS SERVICE
content:
No one knows how to pay for Maryland's massive education reform

 March 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAPITAL NEWS SERVICE | Section: State News 
 
 1537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland's Democratic-led legislature passed the Blueprint for Maryland's Future in 2021, vowing to pour billions of dollars into the state's public schools to offer universal pre-K, improve teaching and make sure students are ready for college or careers.But the General Assembly didn't outline a long-term plan to fund the ambitious 10-year education reform effort — which increasingly looks like a blueprint for red ink.
The Local News Network at the University of Maryland found that the Blueprint is already devouring hundreds of millions annually from the state's fund balance, which is on target to be fully drained in 2027.
And according to a state Department of Legislative Services fiscal briefing released in January, the state will start running a structural deficit in fiscal year 2025 that will multiply nearly sixfold by fiscal year 2029, when it will hit $2.93 billion. Not coincidentally, that fiscal briefing estimates implementing the Blueprint will cost more than $4 billion in 2029.
The General Assembly's plan for dealing with the cost crunch? There isn't one — at least not yet. Neither Gov. Wes Moore in his State of the State address nor any of the Democratic state legislators interviewed for this story have offered any potential solutions for the coming Blueprint cash crunch.
"Several years from now we're going to have to have a much more direct conversation about the long-term costs," said state Senate President Bill Ferguson, a Democrat from Baltimore City. "But we're not there yet."
Republicans, meanwhile, see the Blueprint as a budget-breaker.
"We cannot pay these billions and billions of dollars in extra monies — not just state but local as well," said House Minority Leader Jason Buckel (R-Allegany). "We can't pay for them unless you're going to talk about new taxes — and significant taxes."
The Blueprint's background
In 2016, then-Gov. Larry Hogan and the General Assembly created the Commission on Innovation and Excellence in Education to assess the public education system in Maryland and determine whether current funding schemes were conducive to student success.
Headed by William Kirwan, the former chancellor of the University System of Maryland, the commission came to the conclusion that an overhaul was needed.
"One of the 'aha' moments of the commission was really to face the fact that in Maryland, on what we call the Nation's Report Card, Maryland's score was about in the middle … and moving in the wrong direction," said Rachel Hise, executive director of the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board, a state entity that's making sure school districts adhere to the plan.
But Hogan had an "aha" moment of his own after Democrats crafted the Kirwan Commission's report into comprehensive legislation. In 2019, Hogan criticized the pending reform proposal, telling a group of county officials it would mean "billions and billions more in mandated spending increases for county and state taxpayers," according to The Frederick News-Post.
Hogan vetoed the bill creating the Blueprint in May 2020, saying he did not want to raise taxes amid the COVID-19 pandemic to fund the education plan. The General Assembly overrode his veto in 2021.
And the following year, voters elected a strong backer of the Blueprint — Democrat Wes Moore — to succeed Hogan, who is now running for a U.S. Senate seat.
On the first day of the current legislative session that began in January, Moore said he believes in the reform plan and he will work with the General Assembly to ensure the Blueprint is implemented properly and sustainably.
"I believe in the premise and the promise of the Blueprint. I think we need a world-class education system in the state of Maryland," Moore said. "I think that's going to be a prerequisite for us to be able to accomplish the economic goal that we're hoping for."
Lofty goals
In the state's 24 public school districts, the Blueprint and its lofty goals are already beginning to take shape.
Each school district has already drawn up a preliminary plan for how it will meet targets for offering pre-K, increasing teacher salaries and improving student performance. The Accountability and Implementation Board has approved all those plans after first asking for revisions.
The Blueprint is meant to revamp the state's education system by presenting the same opportunities for all students. With a law like the Blueprint, one size has to fit all to achieve its goals of maximizing reading and math skills, as well as increasing pathways into college, said Sen. Jim Rosapepe (D-Prince George's and Anne Arundel).
"So we want that for every kid across the state. We don't want variation of those goals," Rosapepe said. "Now, the details of how stuff is paid for — I mean, I think that's a conversation that will be ongoing."
Cheryl Bost, president of the Maryland State Education Association, said the teachers union is fully behind the Blueprint.
"We have a shared understanding that our goal is for students to succeed academically and become valuable citizens in our state and in our country," Bost said. "In order to do that, we have to make an investment in public education. I think for the most part, the Blueprint identifies where that money has to go."
What it doesn't do, however, is identify where the money will come from. Bost, whose union represents 74,000 educators in the state, acknowledged the concerns about the Blueprint's cost. But she indicated the increased spending on education is both needed and long overdue.
"We constitutionally have to provide a public education for all students, so the investment is needed," Bost said. "And when some people balk at, 'Oh, it's all this money' — well, we've been starving public education for many years."
The budget dilemma
The Blueprint remains fully funded in Moore's latest fiscal year 2025 budget proposal, leaving many lawmakers to turn their attention to other legislative issues this year. Ferguson, the Senate president, said in terms of current Blueprint funding, "we're more than fine."
But that's not so in the long term. The cost of implementing the Blueprint is projected to grow from $1.6 billion in fiscal year 2024 to $4.1 billion five years later, according to the Department of Legislative Services.
Meanwhile, the state's structural budget gap is set to balloon every year through 2029 — when Legislative Services expects it to be $2.9 billion and the Moore administration says it will be about $3.5 billion.
Closing that budget gap will be immensely difficult, said Christopher Summers, president and CEO of the conservative Maryland Policy Institute, who also said the Blueprint should be paused.
"Raising taxes (is) not going to solve this problem, and I think the governor knows that," said Summers, who has been critical of the Blueprint for years.
The Blueprint calls on school districts to increase education funding too, thereby prompting Summers to say that county budgets face the biggest fiscal threat.
But in Annapolis, lawmakers from both parties acknowledged that the General Assembly will have to make some tough decisions in the years to come as the Blueprint's bills come due.
"I think we know the reality that we're facing. And I think there's gonna be a lot of discussion about that," said State Sen. Guy J. Guzzone, a Democrat from Howard County. "I just don't know that there's an immediate answer."
One obvious solution would be raising taxes to cover the state's coming shortfalls. But Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey, a Republican from the Eastern Shore, said a solution lies in cutting back the demands of the Blueprint rather than paying for the sweeping overhaul as it stands.
"Republicans have stated very often that we need to move to a 'Blueprint lite' or you know, some type of education reform that takes some of the important components of the Blueprint, but at the same time is affordable and allows counties to make decisions on which parts of the Blueprint are more meaningful in each of their public school systems," Hershey said.
Democrats, however, back the current Blueprint, despite its cost. Del. Ben Barnes, a Democrat who chairs the Appropriations Committee, said legislators should start talking about a long-term payment plan for the Blueprint now. The shared values between the legislature and the governor will bring them together, Barnes said, to solve the Blueprint budget dilemma.
"This legislature, the governor, we share values, and those shared values include all the priorities of the Blueprint," Barnes said. "Getting to children who live in communities of poverty, taking care of special needs students, I mean, these are what we all ran on. And so I feel confident we'll find the revenue we need to support that program."
Several state officials have said they are looking to the Accountability and Implementation Board to issue recommendations regarding the Blueprint's budget challenges. The board has made policy proposals included in bills that, if passed this legislative session, would make adjustments to the law without changing the finances.
In addition, the board is set to release additional recommendations this legislative session.
"What the AIB has tried to sort of suggest is like, let's try to implement it the way it's intended. And if it doesn't work, if it's just no longer the right thing to do, then we need to change it," said Hise, the board's executive director. "But for many things, we haven't gotten to that point yet."
Capital News Service reporters Kiersten Hacker, Christina Walker and Ela Jalil wrote this article.
Capital News Service reporters Kiersten Hacker, Christina Walker and Ela Jalil wrote this article.

Cheryl Bost (president, Maryland State Education Association)
William Kirwan (former chancellor, University System of Maryland)

title: Local student wins national essay contest
author: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat
content:
Local student wins national essay contest

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DERECK SARIER Special to the Bay Times Record Observer / Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Viana Johnston, an eighth grade student attending Lighthouse Christian Academy in Stevensville, has been recently recognized as the national middle school winner of a Bill of Rights Essay contest hosted by the Stanley M. Herzog Foundation.The Herzog Foundation is a national organization dedicated to "advancing Christian education." The foundation enriches Christian (K-12) education by creating and leading various programs.
One of these programs was the 2023 Bill of Rights Essay Contest. All middle and high school students enrolled in a Christian school or those homeschooled in the U.S. were eligible to participate. Winners were selected from one middle school and one high school. Each winner would go on to receive $250 from the Herzog Foundation. The winners' schools also received an additional $250.
Participants were asked to answer these questions in three pages or less, "What made the Bill of Rights so revolutionary and unique when it was ratified? How has the Bill of Rights shaped our country?"
In an excerpt from Viana's eloquently crafted three-page essay, the middle school winner wrote, "The Bill of Rights is famous for that little, life-changing word: freedom, but what most people don't realize is that these documents weren't written overnight. Real people struggled, wrestled, and mulled over each word and phrase that went into the Bill of Rights, until it was finally ratified on December 15, 1791. Not only was it composed through much time and consideration but it secured the rights of people today granting our blessed country to grow, expand, and enter new times of innovation. It summarized what we stood for then and stand for now. It lets a person breathe, work, and earn their way to success."
The Herzog Foundation announced Viana, daughter of George and Cathy Johnston, as the middle school winner of the contest in December. Johnston received the prize money and a trophy for her achievement.
In a release announcing the winners, Herzog Foundation Chairman Todd Graves said, "The Bill of Rights was ratified over 230 years ago and still stands as a beacon for our most fundamental rights as Americans. It's crucial that all young students understand the significance of this founding document."
Kathy Guerra, head of Lighthouse Christian Academy, stated the school was initially in disbelief, as this was the first time their school had made an entry to a contest of this magnitude. However, they were not surprised that Viana had won, as she is a gifted writer who creates masterworks of art with her words. "Viana is an inquisitive, energetic, and ambitious student," says Guerra, who "seeks to excel in all of her subjects."
To learn more about the Herzog Foundation and the programs it has to offer, visit www.herzog foundation.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Target team will not see expansion this season
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Target team will not see expansion this season

 March 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 569
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Shawn Connolly, head coach for the Kent Island Clay Target Team, presented updates and hopes for expansion to the Queen Anne's Board of Education during their regular meeting March 6.Connolly celebrated the the team, who was featured in the fall issue of PullUSA Magazine.
Several of the students, along with Connolly, were interviewed for the national publication that is distributed to 36,000 students around the country in 37 states, he said. The Kent Island team is recognized as being the first public school in Maryland to join the USA High School Clay Target League.
"It was very cool to see ourselves in the spotlight," he said.
Connolly appeared before the board this month to seek approval to expand the team's student limit to accommodate growing interest in the sport.
School team limits are typically based on funding, transportation, or the nature of the sport, none of which are applicable in the target team's case, noted Connolly.
The team is self funded and participates at a private facility with all transportation, sponsorship and insurance covered, he said.
"I'm just trying to provide this sport to as many as I can," he added.
Connolly noted the official league rules mandate a ratio of 10 students to one coach, and he has personally mandated even more strict requirements, with one coach for every squad of five students.
Now the team currently has six all-volunteer coaches, "And we have many more that would be willing to help out, and there are always parents," he said.
All students are welcome to the target team no matter their athletic ability; it allows students to wear a uniform and be a part of team who might not otherwise, Connolly said.
"One of the beauties of this league is that everybody participates," without tryouts and slots available only for the most skilled students, he said. However, students must pass a safety program and register before they participate.
Last year the team turned away about five students due to capacity, he said.
As team capacity falls under the superintendent's authority, the board turned to Superintendent Patricia Saelens, who noted Queen Anne's County was the only public school district in Maryland that offered clay target teams as an engaging extracurricular activity, not to mention scholarship opportunities.
Saelens thanked Connolly for his leadership and passion to bring the sport to students, but said at this time the district will not be expanding the program.
"I think we are very blessed and very lucky that we have had this opportunity in this district," she said.
The Queen Anne's School District is insured through the Maryland Association of Boards of Education (MABE), and although the target team covers its own insurance, the MABE attorney has cautioned districts against expanding target teams due to affiliation that could potentially expose districts to potential risk and litigation.
Currently Queen Anne's County School District pays an increased premium for any firearms within the district, including school resource officers funded through the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Department, according to Saelens.
MABE will be meeting again in April to consider revisions and amendments, including potentially increasing premiums, she said.
At the moment, the district will keep the team limit as it is and wait to see how the MABE discussion unfolds.
Connolly said he understood the decision and thanked the board and superintendent for their time.
The Queen Anne's County Board of Education will next meet for a work session March 20 at 5 p.m. and hold a regular meeting April 10 at 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Get a sneak peak at Chesapeake Forum's spring lineup
author: Staff Writer
content:
Get a sneak peak at Chesapeake Forum's spring lineup

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Events 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Forum's Preview Party will be held April 3, when its Spring 2024 class lineup will be unveiled at the Academy Art Museum in Easton from 3:30 to 5 p.m.The festive, catered event offers guests a chance to hear from Chesapeake Forum instructors, learn what's new and find out more about the program.
There are more than 30 classes on tap this spring through Chesapeake Forum, from birding to car maintenance.
Wayne Bell is back with his popular birding class, this time concentrating on the spring songbird migration. Several veteran teachers are also returning with new classes, including investment opportunities for seniors, more about the Civil War in Maryland, edible flowers, ancient Greek dramas, basic car maintenance and much more. Classes are usually one to three sessions, and in most cases, they can be attended in person at the Easton Family YMCA, on ZOOM or watched on a recording.
Registration begins April 4. Classes start on April 11.
In addition to classes, "Lectures on the Shore," Chesapeake Forum's speaker series, returns on May 9 with "Lights, Camera, Action," the story of the extraordinary Fine family — two generations of award-winning filmmakers.
Community members are invited to come along as the Fines journey through more than 40 years of documentary filmmaking, including the Oscar-winning "Inocente."
The mission of the Chesapeake Forum is to provide lifelong learning opportunities for residents of the Eastern Shore. The organization recently merged with the YMCA of the Eastern Shore.
The event on April 3 is free, but registration is required at chesapeakeforum.org.
To receive Chesapeake Forum's newsletter, send your contact information to info@chesapeakeforum.org.

title: TCPS looks into creation of clay target shooting club
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
TCPS looks into creation of clay target shooting club

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 562
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education is hoping to make a decision in May regarding a request for a high school clay target shooting club.At a Board of Education meeting Wednesday, the board heard from five members of the public asking that it approve the creation of the club. The board also heard from Talbot County Public Schools Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones about the district's research into whether this club could be created at TCPS.
During public comment, Sheriff Joe Gamble spoke on behalf of the Talbot County Sheriff's Office about the importance of having a space for a group of teens to come together and be a part of something.
"We all know kids want to be a part of a group, they want to be a part of something," he said. "The Sheriff's Office fully supports another venue for our youth to connect with other people of like-minded and like interests."
Austin Eader, a ninth grader at Easton High School, said that this week he gathered 191 student signatures and 24 teacher and staff signatures from people who support having the club.
Many of people interested in starting the club, including Talbot Rod & Gun Club President Joe Capozzoli, spoke at a board meeting in October requesting approval to create the club.
After that meeting, TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi instructed her staff to look into what it would take to make the club happen. At the meeting Wednesday, Assistant Superintendent for Curriculum and Instruction Helga Einhorn said Jones has been leading that charge.
Jones told the board that the district has been meeting with those interested in starting the club to gather more information. She said the biggest concern right now is figuring out if the club could in any way jeopardize the district financially — particularly from a risk management perspective.
She said that although they have heard about the training and safety precautions required to participate in the program, it still involves putting a firearm in students' hands.
"We have to be very thoughtful about that," she said.
The district has gone to its insurance provider, the Maryland Association of Boards of Education Group Insurance Pool. Jones said a discussion around the topic was held at a February MABE meeting, and MABE intends to hold a session and vote on this at its annual meeting in late April.
Jones said the district will need to consider whether MABE will continue to provide liability coverage if an incident were to happen and, if so, whether it would be at an additional cost. She said the district doesn't have these answers yet because MABE hasn't voted on it yet.
Jones said she should have these answers for the May Board of Education meeting.
Board President Emily Jackson said the board and district are at MABE's mercy at this point. She said that as long as MABE has this discussion in April, the board should be able to make a firm decision in May regarding the creation of the club.
At the end of the meeting, board member Deborah Bridges said she is on board with the creation of the team.
"I think it would be a wonderful addition to our county," she said. "I think it's important because girls can do it too. And there's limited access for females these days. And also for the children that can't do regular athletics, because they can be a part of it too." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Jymil Thompson resigns from Talbot County Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Jymil Thompson resigns from Talbot County Board of Education

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 311
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jymil Thompson has resigned from his District 1 seat on the Talbot County Board of Education.At a board meeting Wednesday, Board President Emily Jackson announced the news of Thompson's resignation.
"Our wonderful Dr. Jymil Thompson has been forced to resign his seat on the board as he was appointed interim superintendent of Dorchester County Public Schools," she said.
Jackson said the board will miss him and wishes him the best of luck in his new position.
Last month, the Dorchester County Board of Education voted to to appoint Jymil Thompson as interim superintendent of DCPS. He is serving the final months of David Bromwell's term as superintendent. Bromwell officially stepped down from the position March 1.
Before taking on the role of interim superintendent, Thompson served as assistant superintendent for DCPS. He began that role in September.
Thompson, who was sworn in to the Talbot County Board of Education in December of 2022, said in an interview that he will miss working on the Talbot County Board of Education.
"I've always been on the other side of the fence in relation to education," he said. "But on the board side, I learned a lot about policy, budgeting and things of that nature. So it was a very valuable experience."
He said his experience as a board member is beneficial to his new role as interim superintendent, particularly when it comes to understanding the relationship between a superintendent and board of education.
TCPS Executive Assistant Charlene Gould said Thursday that the governor's office has been notified of the District 1 vacant seat. The governor's office is responsible for appointing someone to fill that seat until Thompson's term expires in 2026.
Thompson said his advice for whoever fills his seat is to listen.
"I just learned to listen," he said about when he started on the board. "And then make decisions after I listened to what people had to say." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Rotary event encourages students to explore local jobs, careers
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Rotary event encourages students to explore local jobs, careers

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local Rotary Clubs welcomed high school students for a day of opportunities and exploration with the third annual Career Day at Chesapeake College on March 15.Understanding that not all students will go to college or join the military, the Centreville Rotary Club and the Rotary Club of Kent Island once again sponsored a career day at Chesapeake College hosting students from Queen Anne's County High, Kent Island High and Wye River Upper School to discover potential careers.
Event organizer Doug Storck of the Centreville Rotary Club welcomed the opportunity to partner with Chesapeake College and highlight the surrounding businesses that students may not have ever considered for employment opportunities. The day is always well received by students and organizations alike, he said.
Career coaches work with students throughout the year to identify those who would most benefit from the program, he said.
Storck was grateful for the collaboration and thanked the high school administration for leading the way for their students to be on the track to greatness.
"They are here because they care about the success of their students," he said.
Throughout the day of career discovery, students received one on one individual learning opportunities from professionals through mock interviews and financial guidance workshops.
Chesapeake College also presented information on what vocational classes can do for career growth and continual development.
A career fair with 30 local businesses welcomed students to discover hiring opportunities and highlighted skills through a multitude of interests available to them right in their own backyard.
Founder of local IT company Corsica Technologies, guest speaker Dale Walls shared what perseverance can mean for your own story of success.
Walls recounted his own rocky childhood after which he found structure and direction in the United States Marine Corps before going on to found Corsica Technologies.
Since stepping down as CEO, Walls has continued his impressive resume, running marathons, coaching youth football and raising a family.
Encouraging students to take charge of their lives, Walls noted it was perfectly okay not to know what you wanted to do with your life as a high schooler, as long as you were moving forward trying to identify the kind of person you wanted to be.
To do that, he reiterated the importance of setting goals with clarity, having courage and leading the way for future self-success.
"You are the one who is going to get you there," he said.
The day of career exploration is very important to the Rotary Club mindset of "Service Above Self," according to Kent Island chapter President Candi Cook.
The job fair helps students explore the local area for career opportunities in one convenient place and helps eliminate the misconception that students need to leave the area to find quality jobs.
"There are plenty of opportunities for successful post-high school careers that don't require a college degree and taking on tons of debt," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a career day organized by Rotary clubs for high school students, focusing on job exploration, vocational guidance, and educational opportunities, which aligns most closely with the Education topic.

title: Maryland teachers learn from success in literacy labs
author: Matt Hubbard mhubbard@chespub.com
content:
Maryland teachers learn from success in literacy labs

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Hubbard mhubbard@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After schools in Cecil County were identified as a top performer in student literacy growth, educators from across Maryland gathered there for a Literacy Learning Lab.The effort was hosted by Cecil County Public Schools.
The lab comes in the wake of the Maryland Department of Education identifying CCPS as third in the state for student growth on state reading and writing assessments.
The two-day Literacy Learning Lab took place at the Cecil County School of Technology where educators from a number of Maryland's 24 school districts learned about CCPS's methodologies for identifying and addressing students with additional literacy learning needs in grades four through eight.
According to school officials, these methodologies have led CCPS to not only create a system which helps all students, but they also yield results that show consistent improvement in student literacy performance — identified by the state — year over year.
"What we do is not different from the rest of the state, it is where Maryland State Department of Education wants us to be and CCPS is closer to the ideal so we are viewed as a model," said Rhonda Asplen, CCPS's Instructional Coordinator for Secondary English Language Arts Literacy.
The system CCPS uses to identify student needs is Bookworms — a program that provides teachers with resources to implement reading and writing courses.
Bookworms is used in conjunction with assessments to enable CCPS educators to accurately assess students and make data driven decisions when placing students into one of the three tiers of CCPS's multi-tier support system.
One tier is for students proficient in reading and writing skills. The second tier is for students who need additional support and the last tier is for students who struggle the most with meeting grade level literacy requirements.
CCPS works in collaboration with the Professional Development Center for Educators at the University of Delaware where officials continue to develop the multi-tier system to ensure CCPS continues to make data informed decisions when matching students with literacy learning resources.
"We want to continue the work we are acknowledged for because our kids deserve it," said CCPS's Instructional Coordinator for Elementary English Language Arts, Sherry Eichinger-Wilson.
The work of both Eichinger-Wilson and Asplen have allowed CCPS to lead the state for meeting the requirements of the 2019 Ready to Read Act, the science-based program, Science of Reading, and the College and Career Readiness portion of Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a statewide funding initiative that aims to increase education quality and funding in Maryland.
"The focus is to make sure that what we offer in our program is aligned to the Science of Reading," Eichinger-Wilson said. "We have a vertical alignment from grades K-12 and we are continuing to evaluate the parts of our program to ensure that they are aligned and that we are meeting the needs of all of our students."
Cecil and Washington County are the only two counties in the state to be deemed as Literacy Learning Lab models for leveraging student support aligned with the Science of Reading to improve literacy outcomes for students in fourth through eighth grade.

title: Maryland’s teacher shortage: Will the Blueprint’s plan for better pay, training do enough?
author: AIDAN HUGHES and DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s teacher shortage: Will the Blueprint’s plan for better pay, training do enough?

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AIDAN HUGHES and DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 1505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fifth-grade teacher Melissa Carpenter works a 10-hour day on average during the week, and her job sometimes requires her to put in hours on weekends, too."I feel like teaching is one of those jobs where we go to work to do more work — to do work after work," said Carpenter, who teaches at William B. Wade Elementary School in Waldorf, in Charles County.
Carpenter's long hours are far from unique among Maryland's educators, as the state and nation grapple with a teacher shortage.
The U.S. Department of Education keeps a Teacher Shortage Areas database — and it found that for the current school year, Maryland was short of teachers in 28 subjects, which the state defines as "areas of certification." That's up from 17 five years earlier.
Some teacher certification areas — such as English as a second language, health science and special education — are short on teachers from pre-K through the 12th grade.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a landmark state law reforming public education — aims to fix that problem by "elevating the stature of the teaching profession" through higher pay, better training and stronger recruitment efforts.
However, experts and educators have mixed views about whether that will successfully address the root causes of the shortage.
"Money is a huge help, but it's not everything," said Simon Birenbaum, director of grading, assessment and scheduling at Baltimore City Public Schools. "Human capital is the biggest issue, and money can help with that problem, but recruiting, training and retaining high-quality teachers and staff has to be the primary focus. No amount of money can compensate for a lack of highly-skilled educators."
Documenting the shortageMaryland's teacher woes follow national trends. The National Center for Education Statistics reported 86% of U.S. K-12 public schools faced challenges in hiring teachers for the current school year.
Amid the shortage, the Blueprint calls for hiring an unspecified number of additional teachers to ease the workload of classroom veterans.
"You hear a lot about the teacher shortage — and how are we going to implement all these Blueprint programs, which require additional staffing, when we have a teacher shortage?" asked Addie Kaufman, executive director of the Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals.
Shortages stem, in part, from the fact that teachers are leaving the profession. In Prince George's County, 1,126 teachers resigned between July 2022 and July 2023 — up from 989 the previous year, The Washington Post reported. Meanwhile, 625 resigned in Montgomery County Public Schools, up from 576 a year earlier.
Dorchester County experienced the highest attrition rate in Maryland during the 2021-22 school year at 18%, according to a Department of Education report.
"I used to never have people just quit in the middle of the year," said Dorchester County Superintendent Dave Bromwell, who recently retired. "The pandemic told some people, you know what? If you're not happy, move on."
All those factors end up impacting teachers like Carpenter. She said her grade level saw an influx of students, with around 30 students in her own fifth grade class this year.
"Our class sizes are growing, and we don't have the support in place to help some of our struggling learners," she said.
'Teaching isn't approved'Schools are suffering from a long-term decline in the number of people interested in becoming teachers.
That decline has been ongoing since the mid-'70s, "but it gets worse and worse and worse, year over year," said Mike Hansen, an education policy expert at the Brookings Institution.
According to the State Department of Education, 9,134 people were enrolled in teacher preparation programs in the state in 2012. That number plummeted by about half by 2017, but rose to 6,037 by 2020.
Why is teaching becoming less appealing as a career? Zid Mancenido, a lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, has been studying that issue.
"One of the major findings of my research has been that people are taught over time that teaching isn't a great career," he said in a 2022 interview on the school's website. "There are all these tiny interactions they have over their lifetime that give them this feeling that teaching isn't approved, that they should be aspiring to other careers that might be more prestigious or well-paid."
Amid the shortage, many schools hire less-credentialed "conditional" teachers — those who have not yet received their professional certifications. Maryland's issuance of conditional certificates more than doubled between 2018 to 2022, a state Department of Education report said.
In Charles County, where Carpenter works, 12.4% of all teachers held conditional certificates by 2021 — a rate only surpassed by Baltimore City (13.4%) and Prince George's County (14.3%).
Carpenter said experienced teachers are leaned on to help the conditional hires.
"Which would be fine if you had one or two teachers who needed that support. But we have a massive amount of teachers who are conditional right now," she said.
The Blueprint's pay bumpIn order to address the teacher shortage, the Blueprint provides a number of measures that lawmakers hope will encourage people to become teachers and ensure that existing ones don't leave for more lucrative out-of-state positions — or exit the profession altogether.
A key Blueprint initiative increases teacher pay to a minimum of $60,000 by 2026. In some counties, that means a nearly $15,000 pay bump for new teachers.
David Larner, chief human resource and professional development officer at the Howard County Public School System, said the pay raise will attract teachers from other states and build up Maryland's teacher workforce.
"If our salaries are higher than salaries in surrounding states … then candidates are more likely to come," Larner explained.
However, Hansen, of the Brookings Institution, expressed skepticism about the likely impact of the measure on the state's teacher shortage.
Hansen argued that rather than a universal rise in minimum salary levels, money should be targeted where it's needed the most — attracting teacher talent in high-need schools and specialized fields like STEM subjects and special education. He also highlighted research that suggests salary is just one of many factors that can lead to teacher attrition.
"I think we need to be paying teachers more — I don't think paying a $60,000 minimum wage is the way to do it," he said.
Boosting careers and diversityThe Blueprint also aims to improve teacher quality by encouraging educators to obtain additional training.
The plan provides for a salary increase of $10,000 for teachers who become National Board Certified, an advanced teaching credential that fewer than 6% of Maryland teachers held at the start of 2023, according to the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. Teachers in high-need areas may see their annual salaries increase by up to $17,000 by becoming certified.
"We want to professionalize the career of teaching, and I think that is absolutely what we should be doing," said Stephanie Novak Pappas, principal of the Holabird Academy, an elementary and middle school in Baltimore.
However, Hansen questioned the Blueprint's emphasis on National Board certification.
"We don't have a lot of evidence that actually getting your NBC makes you a better teacher," Hansen said.
The Blueprint also calls on school districts to create a diverse workforce. The Accountability and Implementation Board — which oversees the Blueprint — will evaluate those efforts.
A diverse workforce has significant benefits, according to David Blazar, an education policy expert at the University of Maryland.
Blazar said that increasing the share of Black teachers has "exceptionally large impacts on students' short and long term outcomes," he said. "I'd say some of the largest impacts I've seen across all of the educational intervention literature."
But maximizing the benefits of a more diverse workforce will be complicated, Blazar said. Even if the state's teacher workforce came to match the demographics of its students, there would likely still be "clustering of Black teachers within certain districts, and within certain schools within districts," he said.
Hansen echoed those concerns, and said that teachers nationwide remain even more racially segregated than students. Rather than aiming to make the teachers within individual districts reflect the exact racial demographics as their students, he suggested that policymakers should "maximize exposure and access to a diverse set of teachers for every student" across different regions.
A work in progressBeyond the Blueprint, the General Assembly last year passed the Maryland Educator Shortage Reduction Act, which requires the state to set recruitment goals for teacher education programs, creates an alternative teacher prep program for early childhood educators and establishes a $20,000 yearly stipend for eligible student teachers.
Gov. Wes Moore, who proposed the legislation, said upon signing it that it is intended to place "world class teachers in every classroom."
Carpenter, the Charles County teacher, said future changes may be necessary, too.
"We will have new students next year, and they will [have] different needs. So we need to make sure that we are constantly evolving," she said.
Meanwhile, Sparkle Jefferson, an assistant principal at Flintstone Elementary School in Prince George's County, stressed that reinforcing the teacher workforce is key to the Blueprint's overall success.
"It lands in the hands of our educators, and if we don't have educators who are highly qualified or able to do the work, then the Blueprint work would never get accomplished," she said.
Local News Network Director Jerry Zremski contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: College students travel to every Easton in US
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
College students travel to every Easton in US

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Three students and a recent alumna at Lafayette College in Easton, Pennsylvania, had a crazy idea.What could be discovered traveling to every incorporated "Easton" in America? The last stop on their voyage of discovery was Easton, Maryland, where they met Mayor Megan Cook last weekend.
One of the group members, Remy Oktay, was a pilot, allowing them to travel by single engine airplane to each town. There was no way to get to these towns by commercial flight so barnstorming in the four-seater made sense.
The tour criss-crossed the United States, taking off from Easton, Pennsylvania, to fly to Easton, Illinois. Then it was on to Easton, Kansas and Missouri.
From there, they headed south to Easton, Texas, before heading north to Easton, Minnesota, and Easton, Wisconsin.
More Eastons were visited in Michigan, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire and New York.
"And now we are in Maryland," Oktay said. "This is the last stop."
Elisabeth Seidel said that Wikipedia lists 21 Eastons in the United States. They decided to visit the incorporated ones.
What makes a town? Is it a high school? A mayor? A Lion's Club? Often there was little on Wikipedia, the group found.
They took a one-hour walking tour of downtown and looked through a book of old photos with their guide from the Talbot Historical Society.
"She knew everything," Seidel said. "I am very interested in the preservation of local history."
The hardest part of the trip was keeping the weight down in the small craft. They kept collecting souvenirs along the way. Shipping the mementos back to school was the only solution to remain five pounds under regulation weight.
The trip was a mix of personal and academic. The students are not getting credit, but an alumnus paid some of their expenses. The school paid for hotels, food and transportation. They plan to cowrite an article for their school newspaper about the experience.
"We found an alum who is into aviation and was like, 'This sounds cool. Here are a few thousand dollars. Go have fun,'" Oktay said. Their biggest cost was aviation fuel.
The search for Eastons began with cookies.
"Trebor and I did an article for the newspaper. We tried all of the chocolate chip cookies in Easton, Pennsylvania, that we could find. We tried them all, ranked them all. We compared them. They were ranked on a scale of one to five milks," Seidel said.
Then they got to thinking what else they could explore.
"I had known there were other towns called Easton. It started off as a joke. We thought we could go to maybe three or four over spring break. Then we were talking to Remy, who is a pilot, ... and things spiraled from there," Seidel said.
When asked if they had a favorite Easton, the answers came quick: "No comment. Restricted information. We cannot say."
"There were real people that we have made friends with in the last 10 days," Trebor Maitin said. "Everyone has their own unique thing to bring to the table."
They found people to be friendly once Easton residents realized what their motive was.
"We have been stopping people in the streets and even doing some door knocks to chat with the locals and get a better understanding of the history," Lucie Lagodich said. "We have met people whose families have lived in these Eastons for generations."
Whenever they were in doubt about whom to contact in a town, they went to the local bar. As soon as they told their story, the bar stools would invariably swivel toward them.
"It is really amazing to see all these towns. It really changes the way you view America," Lagodich said.
"This trip has made me a better reporter and a better person," Maitin said. "I feel a lot more comfortable walking into a situation where not everybody looks like me." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a college project where students travel to various Easton towns, highlighting their academic initiative and involvement with local history, making Education the most fitting category.

title: Foundation of HOPE leading girls to success
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Foundation of HOPE leading girls to success

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Wednesday evening, Keasha Haythe, founder of the Foundation of HOPE, an after-school program for middle school girls on the Eastern Shore, led the program hosted at Easton Middle School's Library.Haythe introduced this week's guest speaker, John Englehart, assistant manager of human resources for Easton Utilities, to the cohort of girls.
During Englehart's presentation, Haythe stood in the back wearing a pink shirt and gray blazer. She smiled at the enjoyment that filled the room. Girls discussed and practiced the best ways to market themselves to achieve their career and education goals.
Haythe, an economic development veteran and certified economic developer, founded the Foundation of Helping Others Prosper and Excel. Its mission is to help young girls and women lead productive lives in their communities by providing cultural, social, spiritual and educational development.
The program serves sixth-grade girls attending middle school. This after-school program covers low self-esteem, bullying, social media, workforce development, economic and community development, financial literacy and more.
"We prepare them to be independent and self-sufficient as well as exposing them to opportunities, thought-provoking conversations and activities," Haythe said.
Haythe began the Foundation of HOPE over eight years ago. She said this program has been a community effort since the very beginning.
During the program's early days, Giuffrida's Pizza donated weekly food for the girls to snack on. From there, more and more businesses have assisted in the nutrition of the girls to make sure they are well prepared to learn.
Haythe said the success of this program would not have been possible without the generous support of volunteers, business partners, board members and donors.
During the pandemic, Haythe and her daughter worked together to create a curriculum for the program. The curriculum, divided into 16 weeks, covered healthy lifestyles, economic development, entrepreneurship and potential futures with education.
This week, representatives from Easton Utilities led a presentation by showing a clip from Englehart's favorite movie, "The Pursuit of Happiness." Through the film, Englehart showed the girls how to properly prepare themselves for the working world.
He said it was an honor to be invited to speak at the event and support such a commendable foundation. As a human resources professional, he is committed to fostering the growth and development of the next generation by equipping them with the skills and knowledge needed to pursue their goals.
"I hope it will inspire them to not only envision their future dream jobs but also understand the steps needed to achieve and excel in them," Englehart said. "Moments like these reaffirm my passion for HR and the pivotal role it plays in shaping the workforce of tomorrow."
His presentation included helping the girls create a career map to reach their goals, developing and practicing an elevator pitch for potential employers, and learning the best ways to write a resume by becoming "resume detectives" on practice resumes.
When Englehart finished his presentation, he passed out Easton Utilities swag bags before passing along a final message and gift.
He gave each girl his business card and told them that before they started applying for their first job, he would help them develop a resume and do practice interviews to prepare them for the workforce.
All the girls crowded around him as Haythe took a photo — big smiles on everyone's face. Haythe thanked Englehart for his time before cleaning the library with the assistance of the cohort of girls.
"This program allows me to use my passion for empowering women and girls through economic development strategies," Haythe said. "This after-school program is an alternative narrative from what they hear from peers and social media. They are setting career goals, and the Foundation of HOPE is here to help them achieve those goals." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes an after‑school program that provides girls with career guidance, financial literacy, and workforce development, which aligns primarily with educational initiatives.

key_people: Keasha Haythe (Founder, Foundation of HOPE)

title: Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo resigns
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo resigns

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — After three years and four months in office, Caroline County Board of Education member Donna DiGiacomo has resigned, citing concerns following a back-and-forth between DiGiacomo and Superintendent Derek Simmons at the board's March 5 meeting.She emailed her resignation to the Maryland Superintendent of Education Monday.
"My problem on the board is I care about the students and I care about teachers," she said in an interview Monday afternoon. "I got a lot of pressure to make it look like we all agreed. But the thing that got me that I finally said I cannot in any way, shape or form be associated with was at the March 5 meeting."
"The superintendent called some employees minions. I was like 'did you just say minions? Mindless people who just do what you say?'" she said.
The exchange between Simmons and DiGiacomo, which can be viewed in the recorded meeting on the board's website, resulted from a conversation in which the superintendent discussed the district's upcoming switch from Apple laptops to Google Chrome ones.
He talks about how many people it took to get the computers ready for summer.
"For getting the devices ready for summer, we don't quite need quite the large numbers of minions, as the devices come in more ready to go out the door. So it helps us on that end as well," he said in the meeting.
DiGiacomo asks, "Minions?... I guess just the word kind of offends me… 'Minions' offends me. It did offend me."
Simmons said, "I didn't mean to offend you. I was thinking Minion movies."
Members of the board laughed.
She said, "A minion is a person that does what they, without thinking. That is all. It is derogatory."
Simmons responded, "Wasn't meant to be offensive, Mrs. DiGiacomo."
She said, "I don't think anyone would be appreciative of that," before the board returned to their initial discussion.
Simmons did not directly respond to a request for comment about the exchange, though the school district did issue a press release following DiGiacomo's resignation.
DiGiacomo's term was supposed to end Nov. 30. She came to the position after 20 years as a high school English teacher.
"The main statement I am trying to make by resigning eight months early is I do not want anyone to think that I condone what is going on," she said.
"... I am not trying to start trouble. I just want people to know that I really did try my best," she said. "But I can't be a part of something that doesn't respect the employees. Calling people minions is not respectful. I don't want people to think I quit. It is a moral thing for me."
"I think the people who voted for me have the right to know why I made that decision," she said.
The Board of Education's statement on the resignation thanks DiGiacomo for her time on the board.
In it, Board President Richard Barton stated, "On behalf of the Caroline County Board of Education, we thank Mrs. DiGiacomo for the time she spent on the board and appreciate her service to the staff and students of Caroline County Public Schools."
The board also said, "regarding the vacancy this resignation creates, the board will discuss options as they pertain to Maryland law with the board attorney at their next meeting."
The next meeting is on April 2 at 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the resignation of a member of a county Board of Education, directly relating to school governance and policy, which falls under the Education category.

Derek Simmons (Caroline County Public Schools superintendent)
Richard Barton (Caroline County Board of Education president)

title: Dorchester County awards Teacher of the Year to Katelyn Robinson
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County awards Teacher of the Year to Katelyn Robinson

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EAST NEW MARKET — On Tuesday evening, Katelyn Robinson, Maple Elementary School teacher, screamed with pure joy as she was named Teacher of the Year by Dorchester County Public Schools administrators.Around her, peers, friends and family stood and cheered in celebration of her accomplishment.
Robinson's second-grade teacher, Barbara Mills, provided kind words through a prerecorded video.
"I knew then that Katelyn was just a bright ray of sunshine," Mills said. "She understood what we were trying to do in class was to make it a place that we wanted to come to every day, where we can learn and everybody can be themselves … I can't think of anybody that would be more deserving than you."
Along with naming a recipient for Teacher of the Year, Dorchester County Public Schools named Jordan Lewis, a teacher at Choptank Elementary School, and Haley Wright, a teacher at Maple Elementary School, winners of the First Class Teacher of the Year award, which recognizes teachers in their first year of teaching.
This was the first time in awards history that two finalists were awarded First Class Teacher of the Year.
Lewis was described as sweet, caring and helpful by her students and former teacher. Wright was described as an excellent, talented and helpful teacher by her students.
The evening was filled with excitement as members of the education community dressed up, ate a decadent dinner and were recognized for their work throughout the year.
Plenty of tears were shed as finalists for the Teacher of the Year and First-Class Teacher of the Year Awards were honored with acknowledgements from their students, mentors and former teachers that had inspired them.
Gavin Parker, principal of Choptank Elementary School, said he enjoyed the time he got to spend at the event.
"It's nice to recognize all the hard work that happens in the buildings," Parker said. "We go through a lot. We overcome a lot of challenges. But it's always nice to take some time in the spring to make sure we recognize not only the veteran teachers but the new teachers as well. And all the hard work that they do throughout the year." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a Dorchester County Teacher of the Year award, focusing on teachers, schools, and the education community, making Education the most relevant category.

key_people: Katelyn Robinson (Maple Elementary School Teacher)
Gavin Parker (Principal of Choptank Elementary School)

title: WKHS celebrates 50 years of student public radio
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News
content:
WKHS celebrates 50 years of student public radio

 March 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: News 
 
 1312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — It's just a normal early morning at 90.5 WKHS when we arrive to the radio station at Kent County High School. As the school's first of four instructional periods commences, so does the first student disc jockey take her place at the microphone in the facility's live on-air studio.Over the next few hours, she'll not only intro and recap songs from an extensive, vetted playlist, but she'll talk to the station's loyal listeners about what's going on at school, in the county and the greater world. The delivery is smooth and polished, and left to the reliability of just one's own ears, you'd never know that this DJ isn't even 18 years old yet.
Today, senior Emma Morris is joined by senior Averie Hitzges, and the subject of conversation for a bit is a reminder that it is the last day of the station's spring fundraising drive. As is the case with any enterprise of this nature, donations are not only welcomed, but they're vital.
To date, those donations have been coming in from loyal listeners and community partners for 50 years — an amazing feat, especially when you consider that the young people who are populating the air waves with their voices did not grow up listening to traditional radio at all.
So in a social culture where it's more likely you're going to listen to a podcast downloaded to your phone during drive-time than a local radio station, how does this eight-studio, 17,500-watt local station remain relevant and a vital part of the high school's Career and Technical Education program?
An essential part of that success can be attributed to the current station manager, Chris Singleton. At the helm since 2008, Singleton was quick to point out that he is just one of a long line of integral station managers WKHS has had the good fortune to work with since that first day in 1974 when they went on-air with their format of educational and public affairs-type programming, as well as a wide-ranging playlist that began mid-morning on the March 28.
Appropriately enough, that first tune played was Elton John's signature hit, "Rocket Man," relayed Singleton, who obviously understands the importance of a mission and knowing when it's time to come back down to Earth.
With every school year, he said, he does contend with a student body that might not understand the connection and importance of continuing the legacy of the radio station at the school.
"It's like having a kid attend culinary school, when they've never even tasted food," he analogized.
Obviously, his plan for getting kids invested is working, as when the bell rings the senior DJs are replaced with equally fresh-faced junior class DJs — and the next portion of the school-day broadcast continues.
Senior Lizzy Watkins, 18, is just one of the students who became invested in the program for the 2023-2024 school year. She was at the station that morning conducting a bunch of tasks; everything from providing the morning's weather forecast to working on an on-going project that flexes her creative muscles.
Watkins aspires to a career in graphic design and gets to try her hand, and brain, at projects geared to such things as part of her role at the station.
"So for me, because I'm going into graphic design and marketing, being here allows me to start to feel what it is that graphic designers do when they're being handed something from a customer who asks, 'Hey, can you do this?'"
Watkins said the process of being able to create and talk through the collaborative process is giving her valuable real-life experience and has helped build her self-confidence.
For junior, Jonah Elburn, 16, it's the sense of professionalism that he feels when enters the station each day.
"This is something that I love more than anything. It feels, and everyone says it, not like you're in high school, but you're in a working environment," Elburn said. "There's a professionalism that at least the vast majority of people that step through these doors have, the way everything has grown [here] as a business. This is not just another high school class. This is a business."
Soon after, the "business-of-broadcasting" tour took us down a hall where the stacks of LPs and 45s used to be kept for easy access to the then two-studio station. Things have changed quite a bit since then, but not until 2018 did the station have its most comprehensive infrastructure upgrade, Singleton said.
The $160,000 station remodel included the addition of six new studios, including an enlarged, on-air studio, a dedicated newsroom, production studios and various equipment upgrades.
Singleton said they were finally able to address the problem of flimsy, particle-board type walls replacing them with structures that were more acoustically sound, and they were able to incorporate an adjacent classroom into their footprint by taking down a wall. This classroom now houses the station's carefully curated collection of nostalgic radio receivers, audio consoles and other equipment from days gone by that provide a visual history of radio broadcasting.
On hand, and actually pitching in for every upgrade, was Singleton and another essential member of the staff, Ken Collins. Collins thoroughly enjoys his part-time role in sales and fundraising for the station, and shares many of Singleton's memories of what it took to get the station to the point where it could be celebrating its 50th year in student public radio.
Collins' role, said Singleton, was part of a larger initiative dating back to 2013, when Kent County Schools welcomed a new administrator, Dr. Karen Couch. It was at that time, said Singleton, that he was most concerned about the future of the broadcasting program at the high school. There had already been substantial talk about whether or not the station would remain a viable part of the curriculum.
Singleton was certainly hoping that a new administration didn't signal the demise of one of the school's oldest programs. The advent of new technologies and ways of thinking could easily have derailed the plans he already had for what was needed next to keep it going.
Fortunately, after much in-depth conversation with the superintendent, Singleton learned that he could count on her to support his efforts to keep the program going. Couch, who retires this year, would champion the program again by allowing the station to hire for the part-time fundraising position that Collins would eventually fill.
"This would not have happened if we didn't have superintendent-level support," Singleton said. "So, we're hopeful that the incoming superintendent could be just as passionate and just as enthusiastic. I think, hopefully coming off of this 50th anniversary wave and with all the positive community dynamics, the new superintendent will pick up on that and go, 'Yeah, this is something we probably need to keep going.' And until they give me a reason not to, we'll just keep on going."
The next big thing, said Singleton, is the biggest thing of all. Literally. The station's tower, actually the oldest piece of infrastructure being erected in 1973, now needs to be replaced. This is Singleton's newest mission.
"I would much rather be able to replace that proactively, than the alternative of just having it come down on its own."
And so, the station's story is still being written and the program continues to inspire the students who reach out to embrace it.
"For whom we are and what we have, I am pretty happy for where we are," said Singleton.
An official station birthday celebration will be held on Saturday, May 4, from 1 to 5 p.m. at Red Acres Farm in Worton. The event called Tune Fest will feature live music from five area bands: Sombarkin', Justin Singleton, Phillip Dutton & the Alligators, The Good Stuff and The Blake Thompson Band. Festival goers also will enjoy a menu of offerings from local food trucks and connecting with many of the station's staff members, past and present. Tickets are $25 per person. For more information, visit wkhsradio.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a high school radio station that is part of the school's Career and Technical Education program, highlighting student learning, curriculum support, and school administration involvement, making Education the most fitting category.

key_people: Chris Singleton (WKHS Station Manager)
Karen Couch (Kent County Schools Superintendent)
